Article_Name: Turbión del río Piraí de 1983, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Piraí River in 1983
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Piraí River in 1983, also known as The Great Flood of 1983, was a natural disaster that occurred in the early hours of March 18 of that year, mainly in the city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra and neighboring regions of the Santa Cruz department, in eastern Bolivia. In a study published in 2016, it is mentioned that there were actually two floods in 1983, the first on February 1 and the second on March 18. This event occurred due to the historic rise of the Piraí River, which flows west of the city of Santa Cruz. Due to torrential rain in the river's upper basin, it caused destruction along a stretch of more than 100 kilometers between the valleys and the alluvial plain, and as it advanced over flat terrain, the overflow reached a front about 10 kilometers wide, moving earth in its path. The flood destroyed the Tarumá bridge and wiped out the town of El Chorrito, in the municipality of El Torno, and reached Santa Cruz, flooding the botanical garden, the Ambrosio Villarroel neighborhood, and the entire western area of the city. The flood also caused hundreds of deaths and left 3,000 families homeless.

The families affected by the flood that year were relocated to the east of the city, where the Plan 3000 neighborhood was created. Due to the 1983 flood, defensive structures were built in the western part of the city, in addition to the establishment of a protective forest strip called the ecological belt of the Piraí River, which is a one-kilometer-wide vegetative wall.

Article_Name: Inundación en Río Negro de 1899, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Río Negro in 1899 was a meteorological event that occurred in the month of July of that year, affecting large regions of the then National Territory of Río Negro due to heavy rainfall that took place in the north of Argentine Patagonia, causing the destruction of the town of General Roca, Fort San Javier, Fort Pringles, and the localities of General Conesa and Viedma.

The rise of the Negro River, as a consequence of intense rains in the upper Limay basin during the months of May and June, advanced from the Alto Valle, sweeping everything in its path. The population of General Roca was flooded between July 16 and 20. The flooding of the Negro River valleys occurred according to the varying altitudes of each depression. By July 20, news of the total destruction of Fort Pringles (now Guardia Mitre) and Fort San Javier reached Viedma. The town of General Conesa was completely submerged on July 23. Governor José Eugenio Tello ordered the construction of defensive embankments along the coastal area of the city of Viedma. However, on July 18, the city began to be attacked by the water. On July 21, at eight in the morning, the embankments ordered by the governor broke, and the waters advanced over the city. The government house was abandoned by employees in boats, and the prisoners from the jail were transferred to the Patagones police station. The residents who had remained in the city were rescued by vessels such as the Limay steamer. On July 25, the only building still standing was the Salesian College, which managed to withstand the waters. That same day, the flood reached parts of Patagones; however, the high areas of the city remained intact. On July 27, the waters reached their highest level, and only three days later, they began to recede. In addition to being flooded by the river, Viedma was primarily inundated by the El Juncal lagoon, a large body of water located behind the city, stretching from the Zanjón de Oyuela to near the mouth of the Negro River. After the flood, the capital of the territory began to rebuild, but the people of Viedma faced the great challenge of drying the lagoon. Its drainage and evaporation took until the 1930s.

Whole_Text.header: Question of the capital of the Territory
Whole_Text.content: The governorship established the government of the Río Negro territory in Carmen de Patagones, but President Julio Argentino Roca decreed on September 4, 1899, the provisional transfer of the capital to Choele Choel, the only settlement in the valley that had been spared from the waters. Subsequently, through another decree dated November 2, Roca appointed a special commission to study the new location of the capital. General Roca, Choele Choel, San Antonio, and Viedma were presented as alternatives. Finally, based on the report prepared by the commission, the president decreed on May 10, 1900, Viedma as the definitive capital of the territory. The reinstatement of the capital in that locality took place on December 2 of that year, when the provincial authorities arrived in Viedma.

The town of General Roca was rebuilt 5 km west of its original location by order of Colonel Jorge Rodhe, considered the refounder of the city. The selected site was officially approved by Decree No. 3619 on September 25, 1899.

Info_Box:
Duration: July 19-22, 1899 (122 years ago)  
Affected areas: Viedma, General Roca, San Javier, Conesa

Article_Name: Riada del Tamarguillo de 1961, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Tamarguillo flood of 1961 was the last of the major floods in Seville and one of the largest suffered by the city in its recent history. A third of the urban core was flooded due to the breach of the Tamarguillo stream's defense wall.

The Tamarguillo is a stream that originates in the elevation of Los Alcores a few kilometers from Seville, and its course and mouth have been modified by humans on several occasions over the last century and a half to protect the city from its overflow. In 1961, when the flood occurred, the Tamarguillo entered the city through what is now the Tamarguillo Park, collected the waters of another stream, the Tagarete, ran through the city along the Tamarguillo Ring Road, and flowed into the Guadaira River.

On November 16, 1961, heavy rainfall began in the southern region of Spain and continued in the following days. Due to the rising water levels of the Tamarguillo stream and in anticipation of flooding, numerous homes in the northern area of Seville were evacuated. On the morning of November 25, the water began to overflow the channel and erode the walls of the earthen embankment that served as a defense.

Around 3:45 PM on November 25, a partial breach occurred in the protective wall of the Tamarguillo stream at a location between the Carmona road and the current Kansas City Avenue, approximately near the Rafael Gordillo roundabout and very close to the La Corza neighborhood, which was the first area affected by the flood. This breach widened to about 50 meters. This initial breach was followed by two smaller ones, a few hours later, on the other side of the Carmona road. The first waters quickly reached the neighborhoods of La Corza, El Fontanal, Árbol Gordo, San José Obrero, Miraflores, and the entire northern part of the city from the Ronda de Capuchinos. Independently of this point, that same day, two other critical points emerged further south in the city. The first was caused by the overflow of the same Tamarguillo in an area near the Su Eminencia road, whose waters reached Cerro del Águila, Prado de San Sebastián, and María Luisa Park. The second occurred as a result of the overflow of the Guadaira River, with its waters merging with those of the Tamarguillo in María Luisa Park and reaching the Puerta de Jerez. During the night, an old Guadalquivir riverbed that ran from the Alameda de Hércules and La Campana to Plaza Nueva was flooded, with a maximum water level of three meters in the Alameda. On the morning of November 26, the flooding of the city reached its maximum extent. On Monday, the 27th, water levels began to slightly decrease, and by Tuesday, the improvement was noticeable, revealing the damage caused by the water. That afternoon, the main breach in the Tamarguillo was sealed. No official end date for the Tamarguillo flood was given, but as of November 30, water still remained in some neighborhoods. It has been estimated that the approximate volume of water that flooded the capital was 4,000,000 m³, reaching a height of three to four meters in the most affected areas. According to official figures, the flooded area was 552 hectares, one-third of the total city, and affected 150,000 residents to varying degrees. More recent investigations have increased the number of affected hectares to 3,448, a surface area about six times larger than the official data.

Operation Clavel was a relief campaign for those affected by the November 1961 floods, organized by Manuel Zuasti, director of the Radio España station, and the popular journalist Bobby Deglané. It culminated in a large caravan of 142 trucks, 150 cars, and 82 motorcycles carrying food, supplies, and toys for the victims. It departed from Madrid on December 18 and arrived in Seville the following day amid great anticipation.  
As it entered the city, a small plane accompanying the caravan became entangled with high-voltage cables and crashed into the large crowd waiting for its passage. The accident resulted in twenty fatalities and over one hundred injuries.

Article_Name: 2021年8月臺灣暴雨 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The August 2021 Taiwan heavy rain refers to a natural disaster event in Taiwan caused by the peripheral circulation of Tropical Storm Lupit and the southwest airflow it brought in August 2021, resulting in continuous heavy rainfall. During the heavy rain, the government of the Republic of China urgently established the Central Disaster Response Center. The areas with the heaviest rainfall were in the southern mountainous regions. The accumulated rainfall from this heavy rain event was second only to the 2009 Typhoon Morakot disaster. The main period of impact from this heavy rain event was from August 6 to August 8, 2021, resulting in 4 deaths and approximately NT$742.43 million in agricultural losses.

On the afternoon of August 4, the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation issued a sea typhoon warning for Tropical Storm Lupit, located northwest of Dongsha Island, and announced plans to issue a land typhoon warning for Kinmen, Matsu, and Penghu the following afternoon. On August 5, the Central Weather Bureau stated that due to Lupit making landfall along the Guangdong coast of mainland China, its intensity slightly weakened, and its storm circle showed signs of shrinking. As a result, the typhoon warning was lifted at 5:30 PM. During the warning period, the Central Disaster Response Center was activated at Level 2, and a price stabilization mechanism for daily necessities was implemented. 

On the evening of August 5, meteorological data showed that Lupit's outer circulation brought southwesterly moisture, causing significant wind and rain in the outlying islands and southern Taiwan. The Central Weather Bureau indicated that Lupit, downgraded to a tropical depression, would bring southwesterly airflow to western Taiwan as it moved northeastward. Peng Qiming, General Manager of Weather Risk Management Development Co., noted that Lupit had a well-structured moisture system extending 800 kilometers, with strong convection in the center accompanied by lightning. Central Weather Bureau Director Cheng Ming-dian also pointed out that the airflow axis was over the Taiwan Strait but had already significantly impacted Taiwan's western coastal areas.

Subsequently, at 10 AM on August 6, the Central Weather Bureau issued a tropical depression advisory for Lupit, which was located 70 kilometers west of Kinmen and moving northeastward at a speed of 7 kilometers per hour. Later that afternoon, President Tsai Ing-wen announced that the central government planned to further activate the "Flood Disaster Central Disaster Response Center" that evening. The Central Weather Bureau stated that Lupit might strengthen again after moving into the northern waters of Taiwan, leaving open the possibility of reissuing a typhoon warning. At 5:30 PM that day, the bureau initiated "large-scale or severe heavy rain operations."

Ultimately, during Lupit's impact on Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau recorded a maximum wind speed of only 15 meters per second in Penghu, and no weather station on Taiwan's main island reached the wind speed threshold. Scientifically, this was insufficient to classify it as a tropical storm, and the bureau maintained its classification as a tropical depression. After Lupit moved out to sea near Taiwan's northeastern coast, the Central Weather Bureau reported that it had re-strengthened into a tropical storm. At a forecast press conference, the bureau also stated that the combined effects of Lupit and the southwesterly airflow brought abundant moisture to Taiwan, warning all regions to be vigilant against disaster-causing rainfall.

After the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation issued a sea typhoon warning for Lupit on August 4, a total of 5 shipping routes and 26 voyages were suspended [17], which increased to 5 routes and 40 voyages the next day [18]. On the afternoon of the 5th at 3:30 PM, the Council of Agriculture issued a heavy rain and landslide warning, indicating that 60 potential landslide streams were under red alert, 94 under yellow alert, with 1 large-scale landslide area under red alert and another under yellow alert [19]. On the same day, the Coast Guard evacuated 539 people, 213 vehicles, and 19 boats from the shore [20]. Due to the influence of Lupit's outer circulation and the southwest airflow, Uni Air and Mandarin Airlines announced on the 6th that domestic flights for the following day would be adjusted, with several island flights canceled or rescheduled [21]. 

In the early hours of the 7th, a squall line from Lupit and the southwest airflow began moving from the Taiwan Strait toward Taiwan's mainland [22]. Lupit's center made landfall in the Hsinchu and Taoyuan areas on the morning of the 7th [23], marking the first recorded instance in meteorological history of a tropical cyclone making landfall in mainland China and then in Taiwan [24]. Heavy rainfall in Taiwan persisted, causing disruptions to the Taiwan Railway, where fallen trees between Houli and Fengyuan blocked the tracks, halting services from 6:30 AM until resuming at 9:12 AM [25]. Taiwan High-Speed Rail also suspended operations between Miaoli and Taichung from 12 PM due to a landslide in the Tongxiao section at 8:07 AM [26][27]. Taiwan Power Company reported that some power poles and lines were crushed by landslides and road collapses, with cables washed away by floods, resulting in power outages for approximately 93,066 households [28]. In Dahu Township, Miaoli County, a landfill was destroyed, burying 2 recycling trucks and 4 garbage trucks [29]. In Fengshan District, Kaohsiung City, an abandoned house on Guangyuan Road collapsed after being struck by lightning. The Kaohsiung City Public Works Bureau's illegal construction handling team promptly demolished the collapsed structure [30]. In Liugui District, a landslide entered a residential house, prompting the Fourth Combat Zone of the Republic of China Armed Forces to assist with post-disaster recovery, including clearing mud and debris and cleaning the environment [31]. In Taitung City, Taitung County, the "Beinan River Water Cover Area" dust prevention measure was completely destroyed by rising river water. After inspecting and assessing the Zhonghua Bridge over the Beinan River, multiple excavators were immediately deployed for emergency repairs [32]. 

The Directorate General of Highways of the Ministry of Transportation reported at 12 PM on the 7th that road disasters included 9 preemptive closures, 10 blocked sections, and 9 damaged sections [33]. The main road disasters occurred on Provincial Highway 27, with multiple landslides causing interruptions [34]. On Provincial Highway 8, the Central Cross-Island Highway experienced fallen trees and scattered rocks [35]. The most severe damage was on Provincial Highway 20, where the Mingba Kelu Bridge in Taoyuan District, Kaohsiung City, was washed away [36]. The section near Shengjing Bridge to Taoyuan No. 1 Bridge was also impassable due to landslides, and a road collapse occurred at the 68-kilometer mark from Laonong to Jiaxian [37]. In the mountainous areas of Miaoli County, continuous heavy rain caused landslides, with a small truck in Zhuolan Township on Provincial Highway 3 struck by falling rocks [38]. In Chiayi County, 21 people were stranded for six days due to a road collapse on the access road to the Alishan Youth Activity Center [39]. 

The outer circulation of Lupit and the southwest airflow led to the evacuation of 302 people in Majia Township, Pingtung County [40], and 152 people in Laiyi Township [41]. In Kaohsiung City's mountainous areas, 2,035 people were forcibly evacuated [42]. In Ren'ai Township, Nantou County, a couple fishing under a bridge drowned due to rising river water [43]. In Meinong District, Kaohsiung City, a man repairing water pipes on a mountain fell into a valley and died [44]. In Tainan City, three people jogging on the north breakwater of Anping Port were swept off the breakwater by rogue waves, resulting in one fatality [45]. 

The Central Weather Bureau lifted the "large-scale or severe heavy rain operation" at 8:30 PM on the 7th [46]. The Council of Agriculture reported at 9:30 PM that 368 potential landslide streams were under red alert, 157 under yellow alert, with 4 large-scale landslide areas under red alert and 1 under yellow alert [47]. 

On the 8th, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai visited the Qinhe section by land to inspect the disaster situation along the newly opened Gao 133 route in Liugui, the sheltering conditions in Taoyuan, and the large-scale landslide restoration work in the Maolin Wanshan area [48]. Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Luo Dasheng also inspected road damage in Shanlin and Jiaxian Districts on the same day, instructing the city government team and district offices to ensure disaster relief and reconstruction work [49]. Pingtung County Magistrate Pan Meng-an inspected the Sandimen New Bridge, which had reported cracks the previous day [50]. After observation and inspection by engineers, the bridge structure was deemed safe and reopened [51]. The following day, Premier Su Tseng-chang visited Pingtung, where he pledged to assist in resolving land acquisition issues for the flood detention pond project at Tajen University on Taiwan Sugar Corporation land [52].

The cargo ship "Shanbao No. 2," traveling between Budai, Chiayi, and Penghu, was unable to enter the port on August 6 due to low tide, as reported by the Budai Commercial Port security personnel. It had to remain at the harbor entrance until the tide rose. Subsequently, the ship ran aground on the northern breakwater of Budai Commercial Port. All nine crew members were evacuated, but due to poor sea conditions, oil extraction and other operations could not be carried out. The rescue team planned to conduct oil extraction and salvage operations on the afternoon of August 8. However, due to the difficulty of moving the ship, the shipping company decided to dismantle it on-site. The responsible maritime company estimated that the process would take at least 70 working days. The National Transportation Safety Board investigated the incident and found that the ship's log for the day of the accident and the previous day was not recorded, violating the safety management documents of Hai Sheng Company. They also noted that the Budai Management Office of the Taiwan International Ports Corporation's Kaohsiung Branch had not implemented control measures based on the safety improvement recommendations made by the National Transportation Safety Board after the previous Shengli ship incident.  

On August 8, rainfall across Taiwan gradually eased. The Central Disaster Response Center held its fifth work meeting at 11 a.m. and returned to the respective ministries' response mechanisms at 11:30 a.m. According to data compiled by the Agriculture and Food Agency of the Council of Agriculture from reports by various municipalities and county governments, the heavy rain event caused an estimated loss of approximately NT$742.43 million in agricultural products and private facilities. Before the impact of Tropical Storm Lupit on Taiwan, the Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs carried out water release and flood discharge operations for reservoirs with high sedimentation levels, such as Zengwen Reservoir and Wushantou Reservoir. On August 5, the Water Resources Agency also announced that, due to the influence of Typhoon In-Fa, Tropical Storm Lupit, and the southwest monsoon, Taiwan's water conditions had returned to normal, and the drought emergency response team, which had been in place for 324 days, was disbanded.  

The Dajia River Power Plant reported that as of 7 a.m. on August 8, the water level of the Deji Reservoir had reached 1,395.7 meters, with a storage volume of 140.58 million cubic meters, an increase of 17.18 million cubic meters from the previous day, marking the largest single-day increase in storage volume that year. The Southern Region Water Resources Office of the Water Resources Agency also noted that the Mudan Reservoir received a cumulative rainfall of 506 millimeters and a total inflow of 42.36 million cubic meters over the 10 days affected, approximately 1.6 times the reservoir's capacity.

Affected by consecutive days of heavy rain, incidents of road collapses occurred in various locations in Kaohsiung City, including Kaixuan Night Market and Fengshan Zungou. Among them, after the road in front of Kaixuan Night Market collapsed, the Kaohsiung City Public Works Bureau originally planned to fill and level the area with grout at 9:30 a.m. the following morning. However, after Vice Mayor Lin Chin-jung inspected the site, he ordered the road to be paved by 5:30 a.m., saying, "Otherwise, heads will roll!" Former Kaohsiung City Information Bureau Director Cheng Chao-hsin criticized Lin's remarks on Facebook, stating, "During my time serving in the Kaohsiung City Government, I only saw colleagues working together with high morale, and I never saw Mayor Han threatening to 'take someone's head' to make a point." Mayor Chen Chi-mai of Kaohsiung defended Lin, saying that Lin, as a former Public Works Bureau director, likely wanted the work to be completed quickly out of deep care and responsibility.

In response, Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung City Councilor Huang Shao-ting criticized, "After being labeled as the capital of deteriorating public safety, is Kaohsiung now becoming the city of sinkholes?" Mayor Chen Chi-mai replied that after the heavy rain, road repairs and leveling had already begun to ensure safer roads, emphasizing that this work is ongoing. The "WeCare Kaohsiung" Facebook page, which successfully campaigned to recall Han Kuo-yu, listed 13 news reports of sinkholes during Han's tenure as mayor, claiming that his achievements in flood control and road maintenance were self-aggrandizing myths. This prompted netizens to counter by listing nine sinkhole incidents that occurred after Chen Chi-mai took office.

KMT Chairman candidate Eric Chu, commenting on Kaohsiung's flooding issues, stated that many citizens had praised former Deputy Mayor Li Si-chuan of Han Kuo-yu's administration for doing an excellent job and suggested that Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) councilors and legislators should reflect on why "Uncle Chuan" could achieve results while the current administration cannot. In response, former Taichung City Government Information Bureau Director Chuo Kuan-ting and DPP Kaohsiung City Councilor Chiu Chun-hsien criticized Chu's remarks, accusing him of turning flood control into political rhetoric. DPP Legislator Hsu Chih-chieh further criticized Chu, saying, "For the sake of your party chairman election, there's no need to create blue-green division by posting a photo of Kaohsiung on Facebook, especially when you might not even know the exact location in the picture."

Whole_Text.header: Dispute over the implementation of disaster prevention leave
Whole_Text.content: On the day the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation issued a sea typhoon warning for Lupit, two roadside trees collapsed in Xinxing District and Sanmin District of Kaohsiung City. That morning, netizens reported flooding caused by strong winds and heavy rain in Kaohsiung, questioning why the Kaohsiung City Government did not suspend work and classes. The Kaohsiung City Government immediately activated a Level 3 Disaster Response Center the following day. On the morning of the 5th, several roads in Kaohsiung City were still flooded due to rainfall. Citizens flooded Mayor Chen Chi-mai's Facebook page, commenting, "This wind and rain should warrant a suspension of work and classes, right?" and questioned why disaster leave was not implemented as it was during the heavy rain on August 1. That afternoon, the Kaohsiung City Government only announced the suspension of work and classes in Liugui District, Jiaxian District, Maolin District, Taoyuan District, and Namaxia District. In response to citizens' concerns, Kaohsiung City Government Spokesperson Tung Chien-hung stated that the estimated rainfall on that day did not meet the criteria for suspending work and classes.

In April 2017, the Executive Yuan of the Republic of China approved the Forward-looking Infrastructure Development Program, aiming to strengthen private investment momentum and drive overall economic growth potential through the construction and improvement of various infrastructure by the government. Taipei City Councilor Lo Chih-chiang of the Kuomintang criticized President Tsai Ing-wen, saying, "She seeks attention during the Olympics but disappears during floods!" He stated that cheering for the Olympics is understandable, but the heavy rains and flooding in central and southern Taiwan should not be ignored. Legislator Ann Kao of the Taiwan People's Party also commented, "The NT$250.7 billion water environment budget is largely spent on beautifying the environment and creating waterfront spaces, rather than solving water management issues or improving flood prevention standards." She further criticized, "After enduring a drought, we now face floods and inundation. So where exactly has the Tsai administration spent all this money?" In response, Premier Su Tseng-chang retorted, "This is an amateurish statement," and explained that the water management budget is not solely for flood control but also includes water supply facilities. Regarding Ann Kao's remarks, Su further stated that the rainfall during the period reached 1,100 millimeters in a single day, which is unbearable for anyone, adding, "People should be more humble and not always go against the environment." Ann Kao countered, "That makes it even more necessary to spend money wisely and not on landscaping projects for ribbon-cutting ceremonies by officials." Chen Szu-yu, director of the office of Legislator Chiu Chen-yuan of the Taiwan People's Party, also raised doubts, pointing out that the highest rainfall in Taiwan was 1,084 millimeters in Pingtung County, not the 1,100 millimeters mentioned by Su, and criticized Su for mistakenly referring to "1,084 millimeters" as "1,084 centimeters," which drew criticism from netizens. The Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs stated that the government, through the Forward-looking Water Environment Program, has constructed many water management facilities. Although the power of climate change cannot be entirely prevented by engineering, the measures have reduced flooding areas and accelerated water recession. On the 12th, during an Executive Yuan meeting on the "0807 Flood Disaster Status and Recovery," Premier Su Tseng-chang instructed that the government had invested a total of NT$176 billion in water environment construction under the Forward-looking Infrastructure Development Program for stable water supply and flood control. He also noted that after experiencing a century-long drought, the flooding area during this disaster has significantly decreased, and water recession has sped up, demonstrating the effectiveness of the Forward-looking Infrastructure Development Program.

Article_Name: Inundación en Necochea-Quequén en 1980, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Necochea-Quequén in 1980 was an extreme hydrometeorological event that affected the southeast of the Province of Buenos Aires, mainly the coastal towns of Necochea and Quequén, between April 28 and 29, 1980. During it, several bridges crossing the Quequén Grande River and connecting both towns were destroyed.

In the southeast of Buenos Aires, it began to rain heavily on April 20, 1980, marking the start of a period of intense rainfall across much of the territory. In this area, in just eight days, about 30 billion tons of water fell. In Necochea, the rainfall reached 414 mm. Naturally, the water channeled into the river, seeking an outlet to the sea using the Quequén River's course. By the end of April, the river began to overflow, and its course became uncontrollable. This caused residents living along the banks of the Quequén River to start evacuating their homes. By April 28, the waters covered the entire riverbank and submerged houses, schools, and clubs; even the bus terminal had to be evacuated due to the flooding.

Beyond the houses and other constructions flooded for days along the banks of the Quequén River, various types of damage occurred in the cities, the countryside, and the road infrastructure. In the rural area, it is estimated that during this storm, 40% of the province of Buenos Aires was affected. In total, it is estimated that about 22,500 farms—large, medium, and small—were affected, with the latter two being the most impacted. The cities of Necochea and Quequén were especially affected by the destruction of the Ignacio Ezcurra Bridge, which was located near the river's mouth and the Port of Quequén, where a central section approximately 130 meters long collapsed. This bridge has not been rebuilt since then. That same day, the old railway bridge, which had been closed since 1966 and led to the Necochea station, also collapsed. Due to the strong pressure and force of the swollen river, the port was also affected. The advancing water, carrying logs, dead animals, furniture, and other debris, caused serious damage, undermining the old docks and embankments. In the port area, the grain conveyor belts of the National Grain Board were destroyed, rendering docks unusable and leaving the port inactive due to the blockage of the access channel caused by the accumulation of debris carried by the river's current to the mouth at the sea. Several vessels' moorings were also severed, leaving them adrift at sea. Of these, at least three sank, and several others ran aground in the following days along the Quequén coast. The Pesquera II, a mid-sized fishing vessel docked at the Port of Quequén, was torn away and carried by the current to the outer harbor, where it listed and sank, with no crew on board. A similar fate befell the Pesquera III, a mid-sized Soviet-made fishing vessel. Like the previous one, it was torn from the port and dragged to the Bahía de los Vientos beach, where it ran aground. On the same date, the fishing vessel Anna C also sank in the port's access channel. Meanwhile, the Caribea, which had been immobilized in the port due to legal issues since 1978, was dragged and stranded near the Colonia Pinocho in Quequén. In the outer harbor, the Pesquera II, Santa Elena I, Santa Rosa, the coastal vessel San Cayetano II, and the factory ship Knossos were stranded and severely damaged. The impact of the flood also had long-term consequences, as it caused a rupture in the tourism, port, and social dynamics, which remain disrupted due to the never-completed reconstruction of the Ezcurra Bridge.

Info_Box:
Duration: April 28-29, 1980  
Damages: Economic damages and road infrastructure  
Affected areas: Southeast of Buenos Aires, mainly Necochea and Quequén

Article_Name: 2023年9月嘉義暴雨 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The heavy rain in Chiayi in September 2023 refers to the natural disaster event caused by continuous heavy rain due to the tropical disturbance generated by the monsoon circulation affecting Chiayi County and Chiayi City in September 2023. During this heavy rain event, 2 people died, and agricultural losses amounted to approximately NT$30,275,000.

After Typhoon Haikui impacted Taiwan, the overall atmospheric environment in Taiwan became unstable due to the influence of the monsoon circulation. The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation also pointed out that during early September, tropical disturbance signals in the Northwest Pacific were active. A tropical disturbance formed in the northern South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 91W. The probability of this disturbance developing into a typhoon was low, and it moved slowly over the Taiwan Strait, bringing severe weather to central and southern Taiwan. Rainfall worsened starting on the 10th, and the Central Weather Bureau issued heavy rain and torrential rain warnings for nine counties and cities that afternoon. By 6:55 PM, the warnings were expanded to 10 counties and cities, with Chiayi County upgraded to an extremely heavy rain warning. As the low pressure in the strait gradually weakened, numerical weather forecasts also indicated that the tropical disturbance was unlikely to "revive," leading to an improvement in Taiwan's weather.

On the afternoon of the 10th, the Chiayi County Government announced the suspension of work and classes in Alishan Township, Fanlu Township, Dahu Elementary School, Xiding Elementary School, and Zhongxing, Zhonghe, and Guanghua Elementary Schools in Zhuqi Township due to continuous heavy rainfall in the mountainous areas, which caused multiple large-scale landslides and falling rocks. In Fanlu Township, Zhongpu Township, Xingang Township, and Shuishang Township, accumulated rainfall also exceeded 200 millimeters. As the rain intensified after nightfall, a mudslide occurred in Wenfeng Village, Zhuqi Township, burying a mourning household's residence. The coffin of the deceased could not be moved in time and was buried in the debris, only to be found at 10:50 a.m. on the 11th. In Chiayi City, a wooden house at the intersection of Lanjing Street and Xingzhong Street collapsed due to the heavy rain, crushing several vendor carts. In Zhongpu Township, Chiayi County, an outdoor banquet scene showed people still enjoying the feast despite the flooding. In the same township, a car was swept into a field, trapping two people who were later rescued. At the Yongqin No. 2 Bridge in Chiayi County, several vehicles were submerged and trapped in water. Firefighters deployed rubber boats for rescue operations, saving a total of 32 people. Near the Yongqin No. 2 Bridge, the Wujidehua Hall was flooded to about the height of the first floor. The Chiayi City Fire Department rescued three trapped individuals and, along the way, saved three more people awaiting rescue at Xingfu Ranch.

At 7:12 a.m. on the 11th, police and firefighters discovered a couple dead inside a van under the bridge of Chiayi Route 175 crossing Taiwan Route 82 in Shuishang Township, Chiayi County. It was determined that the couple drowned after their vehicle stalled and could not be restarted due to flooding. It was not until noon that the Directorate General of Highways announced the reopening of two-way traffic on Taiwan Route 82, while the mud and debris on Chiayi Route 175 were cleared by the Chiayi County Government and Shuishang Township Office before traffic resumed. Shuishang Township Mayor Lin Xiangting stated that the flooding in Geqiliao and the nearby Hongwa Village in Chiayi City's West District was severe, with water gushing out of manhole covers. She criticized Chiayi City for being "selfish" by discharging water into Shuishang Township. In response, the Chiayi City Government explained that mobile pumps had been deployed to assist with drainage since four years ago, but the cross-section of the Nanjing drainage system passing through Taiwan Route 1 and the railway was too small and still required improvement. Chiayi County Magistrate Weng Changliang conducted a disaster inspection on the 11th with township mayors and Executive Yuan policy advisor Chen Guanting, promising to permanently install pumps in Geqiliao, Shuishang Township, to discharge water into the Tougang branch line. Local residents expressed dissatisfaction with Chen Guanting, a Democratic Progressive Party candidate for the 2024 Legislative Yuan election, for inspecting the disaster site, while independent legislative candidate Lin Guoqing was absent. They criticized Lin's election approach, saying, "Ignoring the people's suffering is outrageous and infuriating."

On the 11th, the Chiayi County Government held a work meeting for the "0910 Heavy Rain Disaster Response Center" to address the disaster situation. Magistrate Weng Changliang stated that the meteorological forecast predicted only 70 millimeters of rainfall, but the actual rainfall exceeded 200 millimeters, leading to an inadequate response. He pledged to improve warning efficiency. The heavy rain caused the drowning of 60,000 egg-laying chickens at a livestock farm in Shuishang Township, and hundreds of pigs also perished in the flood. According to preliminary statistics from the Chiayi County Agriculture Department on September 12, the agricultural losses from this heavy rain event amounted to approximately NT$30,275,000.

Chiayi County Government stated on the evening of the 10th that due to flooding in more than half of the townships in the county and major road traffic disruptions, work and classes would be suspended on the 11th to facilitate subsequent rescue and recovery efforts. National Chiayi University also announced the suspension of work and classes. However, the neighboring Chiayi City Government announced that work and classes would proceed as usual on the 11th. A meeting of principals from national high schools and vocational schools in Chiayi City decided at 2 a.m. on the 11th to suspend classes but not work. However, Chiayi City Government's Director of Education, Kuo Tien-Tsai, stated that junior high and elementary schools would operate as usual, sparking criticism and complaints from residents. In response, Chiayi City Mayor Huang Min-Hui stated, "The shared living circle of the county and city is one of the considerations for suspending work and classes, but there are other aspects to consider. High schools and vocational schools also have their own considerations, and they report to the K-12 Education Administration of the Ministry of Education. We respect their decision." She further pointed out that according to the weather report, "The rain on that day was expected to gradually stop last night. Once the rain stops or lessens, or after the rain stops, the water will recede."

Article_Name: Inundaciones en la República Dominicana de noviembre de 2023, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods in the Dominican Republic in November 2023
Whole_Text.content: The floods in the Dominican Republic in November 2023 were a catastrophic event that, according to United Nations data, resulted in 34 deaths (including 4 Haitians and 4 Americans), 37,000 displaced people, more than 7,000 damaged homes, 4,000 hectares of crops, and over 460 million dollars in material damages. The cause of these floods was a series of stationary convective storms caused by moisture from the intertropical convergence zone (with anomalous activity due to the 2023-2024 El Niño Event) carried by an atmospheric river along a frontal shear line associated with a deep trough at all levels of the atmosphere that was located over the Dominican Republic. The torrential rains and severe flooding affected the entire country, but mainly Greater Santo Domingo (which received a record 431 mm of rain), the Lower Yuna Valley, Independencia Province, Montecristi, and San Pedro de Macorís. A significant event was the collapse of the lining of the tunnel on February 27 Avenue in Santo Domingo, which crushed several vehicles. According to the United Nations, following the floods, a cholera outbreak with more than 1,100 cases nationwide has been reported.

On November 17, 2023, the National Meteorology Office (Onamet) reported that a disturbance zone had a 60% probability of becoming a tropical depression or cyclone. This phenomenon was expected to generate significant rainfall accumulations in the country, between 120 and 170 millimeters. Despite its potential, no cyclonic development occurred, and the alerts were discontinued by the National Hurricane Center. However, the moisture flow was associated with a trough, resulting in a stationary storm line that caused torrential rains between the night of November 17 and the early hours of November 19. On November 18, the floods caused by the weather system affected the Dominican Republic, causing various tragedies, including the collapse of bridges and the overflowing of rivers. In Greater Santo Domingo, flash floods inundated entire neighborhoods, swept away vehicles, and caused the collapse of the tunnel on February 27 Avenue. In the Bajo Yuna area, 2,927 families remain isolated due to flooding caused by the overflow of the Yuna River. At least one person died when a vehicle was swept away by the strong water current in the lower Yuna River area. In San José de Ocoa, the floods caused the collapse of houses in the Los Ranchitos sector. In San Juan de la Maguana, several homes located around the Tenguerengue stream were flooded due to the rise of the Jinova River. In San Pedro de Macorís, the main streets of the province were flooded due to heavy rains.

In Santo Domingo, the collapse of the north wall of the ramp at the underpass of Avenida 27 de Febrero with Avenida Máximo Gómez occurred, resulting in the crushing of several vehicles. There were 9 fatalities in the incident, of which 2 were of Haitian nationality and 4 of American nationality, the latter belonging to the same Puerto Rican family identified as prosecutor Michael Orozco Marín (30), his wife María Martínez Vázquez (32), and his in-laws Ramón Martínez Cesani (75) and Awilda Vázquez Burgos (68). This construction had structural defects, as reported in 1999 by geologist Osiris de León and the Dominican College of Engineers, Architects, and Surveyors (CODIA) to the then Secretary of Public Works, Diandino Peña, who proceeded with a cosmetic fix to the structural problems of the project.

The floods resulted in the loss of at least 30 lives, the destruction of 17 homes, and the displacement of 7,915 people. Additionally, 1,583 homes were affected, and 29 communities were cut off. The collapse of the tunnel on February 27 Avenue resulted in the death of nine people. The floods of the Yuna River left 2,927 families isolated. The floods in San José de Ocoa, San Juan de la Maguana, and San Pedro de Macorís also caused significant damage.

The government of the Dominican Republic declared three days of national mourning for the fatalities caused by the floods. President Luis Abinader assured that all agencies were active to provide solutions to the affected areas. Additionally, he ordered the demolition of the Avenue ramp for its reconstruction.

Article_Name: 2016年邢台洪灾 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2016 Xingtai flood refers to the flood disaster that occurred in Xingtai City, Hebei Province, China, from July 19 to 21, 2016. The flood, triggered by continuous heavy rainfall, caused widespread damage in Xingtai City, affecting all counties, cities, and districts within its jurisdiction. Particularly on the night of July 19, the Qili River experienced a levee breach, flooding 12 villages, including Daxian Village in Dongwang Town, resulting in multiple deaths or disappearances, with the disaster being extremely severe. As of 7 a.m. on July 24, statistics showed that the flood had caused 130 deaths and 110 missing persons in Xingtai City, with the affected population in Hebei reaching 9.04 million. [1]

On July 19, 2016, at 8:00 PM, the Huanghuai cyclone formed in Henan. As this extratropical cyclone developed, it slowly moved northeastward and reached its peak in Hebei at around 2:00 PM on July 20. The Huanghuai cyclone caused extreme heavy rainfall in many northern regions, including Hebei.

Since July 19, Xingtai City has experienced the strongest rainfall since the start of the flood season. The Xingtai Meteorological Observatory issued a red rainstorm warning signal at 14:00 on July 19. As of 16:00 on July 20, the city's average rainfall was 167.7 millimeters, with the maximum rainfall recorded at Shangweisi in Lincheng County at 673.5 millimeters. Multiple areas, including Shahe City, Neiqiu County, Lincheng County, Qiaodong District, Qiaoxi District, Xingtai County, Longyao County, and Nanhe County, experienced rainfall exceeding 350 millimeters. Several data points have surpassed the values of the "63·8" and "96·8" extraordinary rainstorms. From 8:00 on July 18 to 8:00 on July 21, the average rainfall in Xingtai City during the event was 204 millimeters.

The water levels of all six large and medium-sized reservoirs in Xingtai City exceeded the flood limit, with a sharp increase in the average inflow rate. The maximum inflow occurred between 1:00 and 3:00 on July 20. The peak inflow rate of Zhuzhuang Reservoir was 7,780 cubic meters per second, Lincheng Reservoir was 3,215 cubic meters per second, Yegoumen Reservoir was 3,053 cubic meters per second, and Dongshiling Reservoir was 1,108 cubic meters per second. [6] At 19:10 on July 19, the peak flow rate at the Luoluochuan Podi Hydrological Station was 1,650 cubic meters per second. At 0:10 on July 20, the peak flow rate at the Xitaiyu Hydrological Station on the south branch of the Zhihe River was 800 cubic meters per second. At 0:00 on July 20, the peak flow rate at the Liulin Hydrological Station on the Xiaoma River was 361 cubic meters per second. At 19:50 on July 20, the peak flow rate at the Duanzhuang Hydrological Station on the Dasha River was 1,140 cubic meters per second. At 4:30 on July 22, the peak flow rate at the Xingjiawan Hydrological Station on the Beili River was 205 cubic meters per second. At 2:00 on July 21, the peak flow rate at the Aixinzhuang Hydrological Station on the Fuyang New River was 450 cubic meters per second. Additionally, the maximum flow rate at the Linmingguan Hydrological Station on the Shaming River was 5,710 cubic meters per second, and the maximum flow rate at the Macun Hydrological Station on the Beisha River was 1,100 cubic meters per second. Significant flood processes also occurred in the Qili River and Baima River. Due to river channels exceeding the standard flood discharge capacity, breaches occurred in multiple river sections. [6] Flood detention areas were activated. The flood discharge areas of Nanhe, Baixiang, Ningjin, Longyao, and Renxian were successively inundated, and flood detention was carried out in Baixiang, Ningjin, Longyao, and Renxian. [6]

Continuous heavy rainfall has caused the largest flood in Xingtai City since August 1996, resulting in widespread disaster affecting all counties, cities, and districts within Xingtai City. As of 4:00 PM on July 24, the flood has caused 130 deaths, 110 missing persons, and affected a population of 1.678 million; over 28,000 houses have collapsed, more than 8,000 houses have been severely damaged, and approximately 17,000 houses have been moderately damaged; the affected agricultural area exceeds 110,000 hectares, with direct economic losses exceeding 1 billion yuan. On the night of July 19, the floodwaters of Qili River breached the embankment and flooded 12 villages, including Daxian Village in Dongwang Town, causing multiple deaths or missing persons and extremely severe damage.

After the flood occurred, Xingtai City initiated a Level I emergency response for flood control and rescue. Under the guidance of the city's flood control office, flood control and drought relief command institutions in subordinate counties, cities, and districts relocated people from dangerous areas according to the plan. The stationed troops arranged 28 assault boats and over 280 soldiers, organized 1,200 local cadres and residents to carry out emergency repairs on dikes with risks, and evacuated trapped residents. The Xingtai Economic Development Zone dispatched 15 working groups to inspect disaster conditions in 12 flooded villages, including Daxian Village, house by house, resettled relocated people, and fully launched epidemic prevention work in the disaster area. On July 21, due to the impact of continuous water levels exceeding the warning level, the dike sections in Nanzhangzhuang Village of Nanhe County's Nanlihe River and Gaomiao section of Dashao River in Shahe City experienced collapse risks. Soldiers stationed in Xingtai, along with local cadres and residents, organized emergency repairs, even using scrapped buses filled with sandbags to build underwater dikes, effectively controlling the collapse risks. The Hebei Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China and the provincial government established a flood control and disaster relief working group to guide and assist in post-disaster reconstruction, resettlement of residents, and follow-up handling in Xingtai and other areas, as well as to verify and address hot issues of public concern. On July 24, entrusted by Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Communist Party of China and President of the State, and Li Keqiang, member of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China and Premier of the State Council, State Councilor and Director of the National Disaster Reduction Committee Wang Yong led a State Council working group to visit disaster-stricken areas in Handan, Xingtai, Shijiazhuang, and other places in Hebei Province to console affected residents and guide their resettlement.

On the night of July 19, a flood overflowed the banks of the Qili River and entered villages, causing multiple deaths or disappearances. This disaster only came to public attention through reports by ordinary users on social media, rather than official announcements. It was not until 7 p.m. on July 22 that the official Weibo account of the Xingtai Municipal Party Committee's Publicity Office, "Xingtai Release," mentioned the death toll for the first time in its flood disaster report. The delay in the official reporting of the disaster has been widely questioned. [13][14] On July 20, Wang Qingfei, Deputy Secretary of the Party Working Committee of the Xingtai Economic Development Zone, stated in a media interview that the Qili River flood had not caused any casualties. This statement angered affected villagers. On the morning of the 22nd, some affected villagers and families of the deceased from Dongwang Town and Wangkuai Town blocked roads. Coincidentally, Wang Qingfei was on his way to nearby areas to direct disaster relief efforts, leading to an incident where Wang Qingfei and several disaster victims knelt to each other. After persuasion from government staff and police, the villagers ended the road blockade around 11 a.m. Later, Wang Qingfei explained to the media that kneeling was an effort to appease the public and gain their understanding. [15][16]

Whole_Text.header: Villagers block the road, officials kneel, flooding incident exposed.
Whole_Text.content: Due to the flood that struck Daxian Village around 2 a.m. on the 20th, villagers were awakened from their sleep and fled for their lives, but 8 people unfortunately lost their lives, including 5 children under the age of 10, and a 3-year-old girl remains missing. After the flooding incident, Wang Qingfei, Deputy Secretary of the Party Working Committee of the Xingtai Economic and Technological Development Zone, told the media that the villagers had been evacuated and "no casualties" occurred, igniting the anger of the villagers. On the 22nd, they collectively blocked the main road, paralyzing traffic and demanding a response from the Xingtai municipal government. Wang Qingfei eventually appeared, kneeling on the ground with villagers who were crying in grief. The incidents of "villagers blocking the road" and "officials kneeling" brought attention to the flooding incident in Daxian Village.

Whole_Text.header: The cause of the breach of the Qili River embankment
Whole_Text.content:
After the flood overflowed the banks of Qili River, rumors circulated online claiming that the flood was directly caused by the discharge of an upstream reservoir and questioning why downstream villages were not notified in time about the reservoir's discharge. The Xingtai authorities responded, stating that the only upstream reservoir, Dongchuankou Reservoir, is an open-type reservoir where discharge cannot be controlled, and there is no issue of human scheduling of the discharge. The floodwaters entering Qili River came from two sources: one from the overflow of Dongchuankou Reservoir and interval inflows, and the other from the flood diversion channel in Xingtai's urban area. These two sources converged to form a major flood. Additionally, the sudden narrowing of Qili River at Daxian Bridge caused the flood to overflow the banks and breach, leading to water entering villages in the development zone.

Around the time of the Spring Festival, Xingtai City began a centralized urban heating project. The construction unit, in order to allow the heating pipeline to pass through Qili River, piled the excavated soil in front of Daxian Bridge to build a dam, blocking the river channel horizontally. The original earthen dam was also removed and piled into the river channel. The Xingtai flood control department had twice urged the clearing of the river channel, but the construction unit failed to act in time. Many villagers believe that the lack of local flood control awareness, the removal of the dam, the blockage of the river channel, and the near-filling of the bridge opening were the main reasons why the upstream floodwaters suddenly surged near Daxian Village and rushed into the villages.

After the Hebei Provincial Party Committee and Provincial Government workgroup arrived in Xingtai, they reviewed relevant meteorological data and conducted on-site inspections of the Qili River channel, the breach site, and the upstream Dongchuankou Reservoir. They preliminarily concluded that the breach of Qili River on the night of July 19 was caused by a flood peak formed by localized heavy rainfall rather than human factors.

Whole_Text.header: The government is ineffective in emergency disaster relief.
Whole_Text.content: After the flood in Qilihe, local villagers questioned the official warning measures before the flood entered the village. Villagers stated that apart from a broadcast warning about half an hour before the flood entered the village, they did not receive any other warnings. An official from the Water Resources Bureau of the Xingtai Economic Development Zone said in a media interview that the development zone did not receive a notice from the higher-level flood control office to evacuate residents from the night of July 19 to the early morning of July 20. Meanwhile, an official from the Xingtai City Flood Control and Drought Relief Command Office stated that the city flood control office did issue an evacuation notice to the economic development zone at that time but could not recall the specific time. On July 23, the deputy mayor of Xingtai City stated at a press conference that the city flood control office notified the development zone to organize the evacuation of residents at 1:40 a.m. on July 20, and the relevant departments of the development zone immediately entered Daxian Village. Multiple villagers in Daxian Village reported to the media that during the approximately seven hours from the early morning of July 20, when the flood entered the village, until around noon that day, rescue forces were slow to arrive, and most of the rescue work was organized spontaneously by villagers after the floodwaters receded slightly. In response, the head of the Xingtai Municipal Party Committee's External Publicity Office stated in an interview with reporters that rescue forces rushed to the disaster area immediately after the flood broke out, "It was definitely notified in time to evacuate, but the specific rescue situation is not yet clear."

On the afternoon of July 24, staff from the Ningjin County Water Resources Bureau in Xingtai City, while following the instructions of the city's flood control command and the flood prevention plan to close the Fu You Sluice at Gengzhuangqiao Town, were obstructed by some villagers from the flood detention area and clashed with police maintaining order at the scene.

Whole_Text.header: The government apologizes and holds accountability.
Whole_Text.content: On the evening of July 23, Xingtai Mayor Dong Xiaoyu admitted at a press conference that the government had underestimated the intensity of the short-term heavy rainfall, lacked sufficient emergency response capabilities for the flood disaster, and failed to accurately and promptly report and verify the disaster situation. He deeply reflected on these shortcomings and apologized to the families of the victims, the affected residents, and the public. The Xingtai Municipal Party Committee and the Municipal Commission for Discipline Inspection initiated accountability procedures, suspending and investigating those responsible for inadequate performance during the flood response. Duan Xiaoyong, Secretary of the Party Working Committee and Director of the Management Committee of Xingtai Economic Development Zone, Zhang Guowei, Secretary of the Party Committee of Dongwang Town, and Guo Tongheng, Deputy Secretary of the Party Committee of Wangkuai Town, were suspended and investigated.

Article_Name: Riada de San Calixto, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The great flood of the Segura in 1651, also known as the San Calixto flood, was a devastating natural disaster that affected the lower valley of the Segura River in the early hours of October 14 of that same year. This event occurred due to an isolated depression at high levels (DANA), which caused intense rainfall in the region, estimated at more than a thousand liters per square meter in a few hours. The overflowing waters of the Segura flooded much of the valley, causing severe damage in towns such as Murcia, Orihuela, Molíns, Algorfa, Almoradí, Benijófar, Rojales, and Guardamar del Segura. The impact of the flood was devastating. It is estimated that at least a thousand people died, mainly in areas located near the riverbed, due to the collapse of houses and the sweeping away of people by the strong current.

On the night of Saturday, October 14, an intense storm surprised the city's population while they slept. Unlike previous occasions, there was no time for a general alert or the activation of a parish emergency organization, and the defenses, already weakened by a previous flood on September 20, were in critical condition. The force of this flood far exceeded the previous one, breaking the dikes and defensive structures that still remained. The storm began to unleash its force at three in the morning. Shortly after, the waters of the Segura, Mula, Guadalentín rivers, and the Nogalte and Sangonera ravines converged, increasing the flow of the Segura River and causing a violent surge that swept away everything in its path. The current broke dikes and the river's weir, in addition to causing severe damage to the Malecón. Buildings located near the river were flooded, forcing the evacuation of several convents, such as San Agustín and those of the nuns of Verónica and the Mother of God. The material damage was immense. In Murcia, the flood destroyed the parishes of San Antolín, Santa Eulalia, San Juan, San Lorenzo, San Miguel, and San Andrés, and demolished hundreds of houses. The cathedral also suffered the onslaught of the waters, which entered during the celebration of a mass, forcing the officiant to take refuge in the tower with the Blessed Sacrament. Although nearly a thousand deaths were reported, mainly in neighborhoods and hamlets near the river's course, other estimates suggest that the deaths numbered several hundred. The waters reached heights of up to three stadia, remaining at that level for hours. At nine in the morning, after a brief respite in the rains, the river level continued to rise until three in the afternoon, that is, twelve hours after the storm began.

Once the flood had subsided, the Murcia City Council focused on two urgent priorities: repairing the city's defenses to prevent a future catastrophe and cleaning the water and mud accumulated in the streets. The presence of stagnant water raised concerns about possible outbreaks of diseases. During the first three days after the flood, the water level remained high, and although it later began to recede, the city's streets remained flooded due to a change in the course of the Segura River, which now flowed through the city via the broken weir. To divert the water flow, a commission was sent, which decided to break the counter-weir on October 28, helping to drain the city. The repair of the Malecón, one of the key defenses, was essential. To ensure its prompt reconstruction, the City Council required all citizens to participate in the work or hire someone to do it on their behalf, with jurors organizing the work groups. This order caused discontent among the hidalgos, who resisted performing physical labor, claiming that their privileges exempted them from such obligations. However, the City Council responded that, in the face of the emergency, no one was exempt, as there were no "privileges to avoid the risks and damages of the flood." Even the Count of Castro and other councilors hired people in their place to support the work. To reassure the nobility, the City Council clarified that participating in the reconstruction of the dyke did not harm their privileges, as it was a "virtue" in service of the public good and the protection of the city. This act reflects a more modern perspective of the time: although the system of privileges was accepted and defended, in the face of extreme necessity, the common good could prevail, albeit without affecting the essence of those privileges. Among the testimonies of the time is that of María Ángela Astorch, a Barcelonan nun of converso origin and abbess of the Capuchins of Murcia, who described in detail the effects of the flood in a memorial addressed to King Philip IV. In her writing, Astorch denounced the state of ruin and misery in which the region had been left. The flood occurred at a critical moment, as the Segura Valley was recovering from a deep economic crisis, worsened by the expulsion of the Moriscos in 1609. However, despite the magnitude of the tragedy, the Spanish Crown did not allocate aid for the recovery of the territory.

Article_Name: Inundaciones de la provincia de Badajoz de 1997, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods in the province of Badajoz in 1997
Whole_Text.content: The floods in the province of Badajoz in 1997 were a natural disaster that took place between November 5 and 6, 1997, severely affecting the city of Badajoz (Extremadura, Spain) and its surroundings. This event was caused by a process of explosive cyclogenesis that generated an episode of torrential rains.

The meteorological phenomenon that triggered the floods was a subtropical-origin storm that underwent an explosive cyclogenesis process as it moved toward the Iberian Peninsula. This storm, accompanied by highly organized storm systems, caused intense and persistent rainfall in Extremadura, with particular significance in the province of Badajoz.

During the night of November 5 to 6, torrential rains saturated the already wet soils from previous precipitation. Numerous points in the province recorded rainfall exceeding 100 l/m², notably the city of Badajoz, where up to 125 l/m² and wind gusts of 130 km/h were recorded, and Valverde de Leganés, where the 136 l/m² caused the overflow of the Las Piletas stream, which ran underground through the town. The Rivillas and Calamón streams overflowed, devastating the Cerro de Reyes neighborhood in the south of the capital of Badajoz.

The floods caused the death of 3 people in Valverde de Leganés and another 22 in Badajoz. Hundreds of families were affected by the destruction of homes and businesses. The Cerro de Reyes neighborhood in the capital of Badajoz was the most affected, but the flood also devastated the neighborhoods of Antonio Domínguez, San Roque, and Pardaleras. The response from the authorities included the construction of new homes and the investment of more than 100 million euros to expropriate houses near the waterways, demolish them, and adapt the stream banks into parks as exclusion zones against possible future floods.

Article_Name: Riada de Alicante de 1997, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Alicante flood of 1997 was an episode of torrential rains that occurred on September 30, 1997, considered one of the most severe natural disasters in the history of the city of Alicante (Spain). This phenomenon, caused by a cold drop, resulted in a tragic toll of four deaths, hundreds of injuries, and significant material damage that transformed the urban landscape and infrastructure planning of the city.

The event was caused by a pocket of cold air in the upper layers of the atmosphere that interacted with the moisture accumulated in the Mediterranean Sea after a hot summer. This phenomenon, known as a cold drop, is common in southeastern Spain, but the intensity and concentration of the rainfall exceeded previous records. During the storm, up to 267 liters per square meter were recorded in six hours, with a maximum intensity of 156 liters per square meter in just an hour and a half.

The day began with heavy rains around 8:00 in the morning, coinciding with the start of daily activities. At that time, the city was bustling, with workers heading to their jobs and children on their way to school. In just over an hour, the water flooded streets, basements, and commercial premises, paralyzing traffic and leaving vehicles floating as if they were made of paper.

Although there was a brief respite mid-morning, the rain intensified significantly around 1:00 PM, causing the city to collapse completely. The most affected areas included Playa de San Juan, La Albufereta, Sangueta, and the center of Alicante, where water flooded the construction site of the Alfonso el Sabio parking lot, turning it into a gigantic pool. In some places, such as the Juncaret, Bonhivern, and Orgegia ravines, the water reached over 1.5 meters in height. In urban areas, such as Plaza de la Montañeta, the water swept away vehicles and urban furniture. At the train station, more than 400 people were trapped, and the University of Alicante was completely flooded, requiring the evacuation of students and professors.

The flood left a toll of four dead, including a mother and her son who were swept away by a sewer, and more than 200 injured. The material losses were incalculable, with entire neighborhoods flooded, businesses destroyed, and communication routes cut off. The sewer system collapsed, and railway and airport operations were suspended.

The security forces, such as the Police, firefighters, the Civil Guard, and Civil Protection, worked tirelessly during the emergency. Human chains were organized to rescue trapped people, and in some areas, inflatable boats were used to reach isolated residents. Citizen solidarity was key to facing the catastrophe, with dramatic rescue images and collective efforts standing out.

After the disaster, the Anti-Flood Plan was implemented, an ambitious infrastructure project designed to mitigate the impact of future torrential rains. The plan included the construction of 40 kilometers of underground collectors, 18 kilometers of them beneath the urban core, and additional works such as the San Gabriel rainwater reservoir, with a capacity to store 60,000 cubic meters of water, and the floodable park of La Marjal, which acts as a containment area in San Juan Beach.
