Article_Name: Ola de calor en Argentina de 2023, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heat wave in Argentina in 2023 was an extraordinarily late extreme heat phenomenon that occurred from February 28 to March 20 of that year, mainly in the central region of the country, as well as in the northern and coastal areas. It was the longest heat wave experienced in Argentina since the heat wave in 2013, affecting especially the provinces of Buenos Aires, Santa Fe, Córdoba, and all the northern provinces where multiple cities recorded record temperatures. It was characterized as an unusual heat phenomenon, not only because of the duration of the event but also because of the magnitude of temperatures during the month it occurred, as in March in Argentina, temperatures tend to drop due to the beginning of autumn. The heat wave is associated with the Atlantic anticyclone, a new extremely intense La Niña phenomenon in the Pacific, and the regional effects of climate change. A heat wave is characterized by a marked and sustained increase in temperatures, especially the maximums, occurring in several cities, above what is considered extreme.

According to the National Meteorological Service, the heat wave is due to the presence of high pressures that create an atmospheric blockage interacting with a constant influx of warm air coming from the north through a high-pressure system in the South Atlantic Ocean, which results in persistent and unusually late high temperatures for this time of year.

The National Meteorological Service reports, through its daily updates, information on the development of the heatwave. It covers the center and north of the country, encompassing 18 provinces, with two more added if the north of Patagonia is considered.

During the heatwave, new records of national electricity demand were set, exceeding 28,500 MW. On March 1, a massive blackout occurred, affecting more than 6 million users in the north and center of the country, impacting half of the nation. According to the Secretariat of Energy, a grassland fire affected a power line, prompting the Atucha I plant to suspend its activities preventively. Intense increases and decreases in the number of households without power were also recorded on the following days.

Amid the heatwave, the combination of high temperatures and a historic drought triggered forest fires in areas such as the Costanera Sur Ecological Reserve and the Iberá Wetlands, which affected agriculture in Argentina's weakened economy and caused a considerable increase in the price of various agricultural products such as eggs or vegetables. Soybean and corn crops, the country's main harvests, are suffering the impact of extreme heat. The period of extremely high temperatures and the absence of rain allowed the proliferation of Thysanoptera, tiny insects that invaded the province.

Article_Name: Ola de calor en Argentina en 2013, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heat wave in Argentina in December 2013 was a phenomenon that occurred from December 11, 2013, to January 2, 2014, in the northern and central regions of the country, as well as in the northern part of Patagonia. It was the second longest heat wave experienced in Argentina since records began in 1906, affecting at least 52 cities across the country. For the first time since the creation of the heat alarm system, a red-level alert was in effect for several consecutive days both in the city of Buenos Aires and in the city of Rosario in Santa Fe. The cause of this heat wave was the Madden-Julian oscillation, which caused the South Atlantic anticyclone to settle over the continent, creating an atmospheric blockage that led to high temperatures and scarce precipitation in the central and northern parts of the country, while halting subpolar and subtropical frontal systems, resulting in unusual summer snowfalls in Tierra del Fuego and torrential rains in Brazil.

Starting from December 11, a marked increase in temperatures began to be recorded, especially the maximums, in a vast area of the central and northern Patagonian region, affecting southern Córdoba, southern Santa Fe, southern Entre Ríos, a large part of the province of Buenos Aires, La Pampa, eastern Mendoza, eastern Neuquén, and Río Negro. From the 19th, this anomalous situation began to expand towards northern Argentina and intensified again over the central part, affecting 18 provinces, subsiding around December 30 in the central part and between January 1 and 2 in the extreme north of the country with the passage of a cold front that caused a change in the air mass. As a result, most localities located between 30°S and 40°S recorded 1 or 2 heatwaves during the period, with durations ranging from 5 to 18 consecutive days, and average minimum temperatures exceeding 4°C and average maximum temperatures exceeding 6°C compared to the normal for the season. The long persistence of this heatwave (22 days) made the event exceptional, breaking several records regarding the highest number of consecutive days with minimum and maximum temperatures above the average in several meteorological stations in the affected area. The National Meteorological Service reported, through its daily updates, information on the development of the heatwave. Meteorological agencies in Uruguay and Paraguay also declared a state of alert due to the heatwave.

It was the first heat wave whose health hazard level was categorized as extreme (red alert). The National Meteorological Service and the Ministry of Health warned the population of the cities and surrounding areas of Buenos Aires and Rosario about the risks to avoid and the basic precautions to follow in the face of intense heat. This occurs in exceptional cases of heat waves, which can affect all healthy people, not just at-risk groups. Up to that point, several deaths had been recorded with heat stroke episodes as direct causes of death. In Santiago del Estero, eleven deaths associated with heat stroke occurred. In Entre Ríos, seven more cases were reported, largely due to cardiorespiratory arrests and decompensations caused by the intense heat, as well as one fatality from heat stroke in the district of Avellaneda, and in the province of Salta, one fatality was reported due to sunstroke. In various locations, several drownings were also recorded (largely due to thermal shock) as several people attempted to cool off in some rivers in the provinces of Córdoba (9 cases), Santa Fe (4 cases), Buenos Aires (5 cases), Entre Ríos (4 cases), Mendoza (3 cases), Corrientes (4 cases), San Luis (1 case), Salta (1 case), Santiago del Estero (1 case), and Jujuy (1 case). In the city of Buenos Aires, two people died from carbon monoxide poisoning after turning on a generator to alleviate the intense nighttime heat. The following day, a similar case occurred, where a 50-year-old man lost his life for the same reason, and several days later, an elderly person was found dead in their apartment in the Villa del Parque neighborhood due to power outages and the intense heat. In the district of Avellaneda, three people died in a fire while trying to light the place with candles since they had no electricity due to power outages. Meanwhile, for the same reason, four people died in a house fire in Quilmes, and one more person in the city of Buenos Aires. In the city of Pergamino, an elderly person also fell victim to a fire caused by an electrical failure in a ventilation device. Also in the city, SAME recorded a peak in emergency calls; most of the emergencies were related to fainting and low blood pressure, typical symptoms of heat stroke, and because pre-existing health conditions worsened, such as the emergence of a dengue outbreak in a region as southern as the province of Entre Ríos, a large province where such disease (dengue in Argentina is almost always a zoonosis carried by people who have previously been in much more northern areas than Argentina). In Rosario, 70 swimmers cooling off in the Paraná River on Christmas Day were attacked by a school of piranhas, carnivorous fish of the genus Serrasalmus —to which piranhas also belong—. These fish were fleeing to cooler areas due to the high water temperatures caused by the heat wave. The following day, another attack by these fish occurred at a beach on the Paraná River in Posadas (Misiones), injuring 15 people.

On December 20, around 200,000 direct residential customers of Edenor and Edesur were left without electricity service. Between December 21 and 27, the number of users without electricity service fluctuated between 50,000 and 70,000. On December 23, the Ministry of Federal Planning reported that the Argentine Interconnection System broke the power demand record when consumption peaked at 23,793 megawatts. Power outages also occurred in cities in the interior of the country, such as Córdoba, Rosario, and San Miguel de Tucumán. On December 23, the Argentine Interconnection System recorded a power demand record for a weekday, with electricity consumption peaking at 23,793 megawatts at 2:20 PM. Additionally, on December 28, it recorded a power demand record for a Saturday, with electricity consumption reaching 21,264 megawatts at 2:10 PM. As a consequence of the relentless heat, there were heavy rains with strong electrical activity in several localities in the central part of the country, and San Miguel de Tucumán experienced high wind activity. On New Year's Eve, the city of Rosario experienced a heat index of 55°C.

On December 23, Buenos Aires legislator Marcelo Ramal presented a bill for an electricity emergency in the City of Buenos Aires. This initial project proposed the creation of a crisis committee composed of: one representative from each legislative bloc, representatives from the consultative councils of the Communes and affected neighborhoods, elected representatives of workers and technicians from energy distributors, and academics from the Faculty of Engineering at UBA. The committee would have authority over the distribution companies and would organize an energy restoration operation. The project included the formation of 60 emergency crews (4 per commune) to repair damaged lines and substations, as well as the provision of 1,500 generators (100 per commune). The costs related to these operations would be financed through a tax on gambling establishments in the City, which are currently exempt. However, only five legislators (in addition to Ramal, Gustavo Vera, Virginia González Gass, Pablo Bergel, and Alejandro Bodart, the latter two with their own projects) signed the request for the Legislature to hold a special session to address this issue. The project was ignored by the remaining legislators, prompting the five signatories to hold a press conference. Chief of Staff Jorge Capitanich pointed to the electricity providers, Edenor and Edesur, as responsible for the outages and urged users to direct their complaints to the companies. He announced an administrative holiday for December 30 starting at 12 p.m. Working groups were created within the framework of the climate emergency, unifying the tasks of security forces (police, army, civil defense, and firefighters) with the availability of 500 patrol cars, 17,000 agents, and 3,200 cameras. Days later, the head of government of the City of Buenos Aires, Mauricio Macri, declared an energy emergency due to the energy collapse affecting his city. Similarly, Capitanich announced the executive branch's intention to nationalize the management of the electricity service if Edenor and Edesur did not resolve the supply issues. When asked about Nicolás Caputo, a shareholder in Edesur and the main beneficiary of public works in Buenos Aires, responsible for the power outages, he avoided responding or referencing the responsibility of energy distribution companies like Edesur, owned by his close friend with whom he shares business interests. As a result of the prolonged power outages, numerous protests occurred due to public discontent in most neighborhoods of the City of Buenos Aires, disrupting traffic on streets, highways, and bridges. One of the most affected roadways by the protests was the Buenos Aires-La Plata Highway, where a total vehicle collapse was recorded. In the city, there were various demonstrations by residents, including street and avenue blockades. By the first days of January 2014, some neighborhoods in the City of Buenos Aires had been without electricity for more than two weeks, leading residents to block the Sarmiento railway line as a form of protest, as well as in the Province of Buenos Aires. Ramal, the author of the law proposing the energy emergency, criticized Macri's measure, considering that "what Macri did is a caricature of an energy emergency, not a real emergency," as "no extraordinary measures were taken to restore the service nor resources allocated to address an emergency." The national and city governments agreed to coordinate assistance tasks for residents who remained without power. Mauricio Macri himself requested a change in the time zone for the City of Buenos Aires, the Argentine coast, and the provinces of Buenos Aires, Santa Fe, and Córdoba. The National Minister of Planning, Julio De Vido, strongly rejected the proposal, explaining that "having two time zones would cause disruptions and costs greater than the benefits, as it would not be logical, for example, to have one time in Córdoba and another in Santiago del Estero." The planning minister then asked "Argentine companies" with shares in Edesur to "take responsibility as Argentines" for the power outages. "I am referring to the Caputo Group, Escasany Group, Miguens Bemberg Group, Guillermo Reca, and Guillermo Vázquez."

Edenor and Edesur companies have been identified as responsible for the outages. It was publicly reported that the companies under-executed investments for which they had resources amounting to 240 million pesos, through the Infrastructure Fund, "as a form of extortion to achieve a tariff increase." The planning minister warned that, due to "negligence and serious non-compliance" in service during the heatwave, the distribution companies would have to pay 490 pesos to residential users who were without power for 12 to 24 hours. Edesur was required to compensate users with a total of 221 million pesos, while Edenor had to compensate them with 77 million. After the outages caused by the heatwave, starting in 2014, Edenor initiated an investment plan that allowed a 32% reduction in outages.

Article_Name: Canicule européenne de juillet-août 2021 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The European heatwave of July-August 2021 is a period of unusual summer heat of remarkable intensity that particularly affects Southern Europe.
A heat dome, a powerful anticyclone stalled over the same region accompanied by scorching air, settles in the heart of the Mediterranean and causes extreme heat in the countries of Southern Europe.

Between late June and early July, a first heatwave caused temperatures of 44 degrees for 11 days. According to data from the National Observatory of Athens, it was the 5th longest heatwave in Greece in 40 years. In early August, temperatures exceeding 45 degrees were recorded, with a peak temperature of 47.1°C reached in Langadás on August 3.

A heatwave driven by the anticyclone "Lucifer" is causing a significant increase in temperatures. On August 10, extreme temperatures of 47°C in Lentini and 46.7°C in Paterno were recorded by SIAS, the Sicilian agrometeorological service. On August 11, significant values were recorded in Italy. The town of Santa Maria Capua Vetere in Campania reached 42.2°C, followed by 44.5°C in Bova in Calabria, and finally 43.6°C in Ballao in Sardinia. It is in eastern Sicily where the highest values were recorded, with 47.4°C in Paterno and then a peak of 48.8°C recorded by SIAS in Floridia in the province of Syracuse, which would be the highest value recorded in Italy and Europe.

Starting from August 12, the heat dome affects Spain. On August 13, 45.5°C is recorded in Granada in Andalusia, 44.8°C in Aguilar de la Frontera, and 41.7°C at Madrid airport. However, August 14 turns out to be the hottest day, with heat peaks reached: 46.9°C in Cordoba, matching the record of July 13, 2017, 42.7°C at Madrid Barajas airport (new record), 47.4°C in Montoro, and up to 47.6°C at 4:48 PM at the La Rambla weather station (Cordoba) in Andalusia, recorded by AEMET, which would represent the new national record in Spain. On August 15, the heat peak shifts to the Mediterranean. New temperature records occur in the Segura Valley, in the Region of Murcia: 47°C in Murcia-Alcantarilla and 46.2°C in Murcia-Guadalupe. On August 16, it reaches 44.3°C in Tenerife.

The heatwave is also affecting the Balkans, with temperatures reaching 40°C. Albania has had to deal with no fewer than 75 forest fires, which have mobilized 300 firefighters. The authorities have requested help from the European Union, reports the Reuters agency. Numerous fires have also mobilized emergency services in Serbia, Bosnia, Macedonia, and Croatia.

In France, it is in the southeast that the heatwave settles; in mid-August, 40.7°C is recorded in Porto-Vecchio in Corsica, 40.9°C in Varages in the Var, and a temperature peak is reached on August 13 in Trets with 41.2°C in the Bouches-du-Rhône.

Fires are occurring in Greece, burning thousands of hectares on the island of Euboea, causing the evacuation of 3,000 people by sea. Since July 29, there have been 586 fire outbreaks and more than 93,700 hectares devastated by flames. In Sicily and Calabria, large-scale fires are spreading. On the night of August 11 to 12, more than 500 fires were recorded, resulting in the death of 4 people. Spain is also facing flames between Navalacruz and Riofrio. A massive fire with a perimeter of 90 km has devastated 12,000 hectares of vegetation and led to the evacuation of 1,000 residents. In France, in the Var region, 6,300 hectares have burned, leading to the evacuation of 7,000 people. Additionally, the fires have caused the death of 2 people. In Finland, the region bordering the Kalajoki River has experienced the worst forest fires since 1971. In August 2021, Finland reported about 12.5 times more burned forests since the beginning of the year compared to the average established over the period 2008-2020 (488 ha, instead of 39 ha per year). The fires also pose a threat to biodiversity.

According to the latest IPCC state report, July 2021 was the hottest month ever recorded. This confirms the IPCC's predictions of a +1.5°C increase in the planet's temperature around 2030, which will result in the saturation of CO2 absorption by forests, soils, and oceans. The rise in sea levels and the accelerated warming of the Arctic are consequences of this climate escalation.

Article_Name: Ola de calor en Europa de junio de 2022, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heatwave in Europe in June 2022 was an unusually early episode of extreme heat that affected Portugal, Spain, France, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. In Spain and France, countries affected by drought, high temperatures favored the outbreak of wildfires.

The heatwave was due to an interaction between high pressures that generate atmospheric stability and Cyclone Álex, the strong insolation of the boreal summer, and a mass of air coming from North Africa, which entered the Iberian Peninsula loaded with suspended dust and caused haze in the central and southern parts of the peninsula.

The special warning for high temperatures was activated by Aemet on June 10, but only for 12 provinces, with yellow alerts in Aragón, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, Extremadura, and Madrid, and orange alerts in Andalusia. In this initial stage, the unusual heat did not affect the Canary Islands, Galicia, the western Cantabrian coast, and parts of the Mediterranean peninsular coast. Initially, Aemet forecasted that the heatwave would last until Wednesday, June 15, without ruling out the possibility of it continuing for the rest of the week. On June 11, high temperatures were already recorded in the southwest of the peninsula, with 41°C in Seville. Alerts remained active for Aragón, Castilla y León, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, and Madrid at the yellow level, and orange for Extremadura and Andalusia. However, the meteorological conditions did not meet the official criteria to declare the start of the heatwave. On June 12, thermometers recorded 43.2°C in Almadén (Ciudad Real), the highest value on the official start day of the heatwave. Temperatures above 40°C were also recorded at 47 Aemet network stations. Additionally, the agency issued special notice number 3/2022 with information about the phenomenon, its forecast, and announced the start of the national plan for preventive actions against the effects of excessive temperatures on health, including a level assignment map. In the province of Almería, a 62-year-old man died after collapsing and showing symptoms of dehydration while hiking on the Antenas trail near the Totem of Aguadulce. On June 13, Aemet announced in its official report a possible end date for the heatwave on Thursday, June 16, while noting that "due to the behavior of a DANA (isolated depression at high levels) located in Madeira, whose evolution cannot be precisely determined." On June 14, the heatwave extended to southern Galicia and the interior of the Cantabrian region. Tropical nights also continued, with thermometers not dropping below 20°C in many provinces, particularly in Jaén, where a minimum of 27°C was expected. Furthermore, it was forecasted that the peak of the heatwave would be reached on Friday, June 17, breaking some temperature records in cities like Zaragoza, Lleida, and Córdoba. The only areas in Spain that had so far escaped the heatwave were Asturias, the Canary Islands, and the autonomous cities of Ceuta and Melilla. In its daily report, Aemet forecasted the end of the meteorological episode for Saturday, as the DANA in the Atlantic, which injects hot African air, approached the peninsula, causing instability and a drop in temperatures. In Vega de Valcarce, a 69-year-old German pilgrim possibly died from heatstroke while walking the Villafranca del Bierzo stage of the Camino de Santiago. Rubén del Campo, Aemet spokesperson, stated that it was the "most intense heatwave for mid-June in at least the last 20 years." On June 15, the "Iberian exception" was applied for the first time, whereby the regulated price of electricity is calculated with a cap on gas for its generation. The PVPC (Voluntary Price for Small Consumers) means higher electricity bills due to compensation for thermal power plants and increased use of gas and coal during the heatwave. Once this unusual heatwave subsides, it will be seen if PVPC-referenced bills decrease when all air conditioners are no longer running simultaneously. On June 18, the extraordinary heatwave that affected Spain between June 11-12 and June 18 came to an end, being described as "intense, extensive, and extraordinary" by the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), which also highlighted that this spring heat episode was one of the earliest recorded in the country. On June 20, Monday until 12 p.m., the Zaragoza City Council extended the orange alert of the Civil Protection Emergency Plan for the heatwave, which had been activated on Tuesday, June 14, due to the high temperatures affecting the city, exceeding 40°C on several days and not dropping below 25°C on some nights. On July 6, the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) published a report detailing the month of June, highlighting the intense heat episode that extended from the first day of the month until June 19, with both maximum and minimum temperatures well above normal, particularly high during the central days of the month, due to an invasion of warm air from North Africa. The heatwave in the Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands between June 11 and 18, 2022, was the earliest occurrence in the series, matching records with the one that occurred on June 11, 1981.

On June 16, Météo-France activated a red alert in 12 departments and an orange alert in another 25 due to a heatwave. The departments under red alert are mainly located in the southwest, along the Atlantic coast, and the south, while the severity is generally lower the further north and east. This is the earliest heatwave on record and the fourth time a red alert for heat has been issued since the protocol was established following the 2003 heatwave. On June 17, the red alert was activated in 14 departments, with the Hautes-Pyrénées and Pyrénées-Atlantiques added to the twelve from the previous day. Additionally, an orange alert was activated in 56 departments.

On June 14, in response to the Met Office's forecast of high temperatures, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issued level 2 health alerts in several regions for the period between midnight on Thursday the 16th and midnight on Saturday the 18th. The affected regions were London, the East Midlands, London and the East, Southeast, and Southwest of England. On June 15, the UKHSA issued level 3 alerts for London, the East, and the Southeast of England, maintaining level 2 alerts for the East Midlands and the Southwest of England. According to the Met Office forecasts, the heat peak would arrive on Friday, reaching the threshold necessary for the consideration of a heatwave, before temperatures dropped significantly on Saturday the 18th. On June 17, London exceeded 32°C on the hottest day of the year so far. According to Stephen Dixon, a Met Office spokesperson, temperatures above 30 degrees "are not unusual, but it is uncommon to see such high temperatures so early in the year." Dixon added that the temperatures on that same day would be the highest since the summer of 2020.

On Wednesday the 15th, a heat wave alert was activated in the Italian-speaking canton of Ticino. The following day, Thursday, June 16, the French-speaking cantons of Geneva and Vaud issued their own alerts. On the 16th, the Federal Office of Meteorology and Climatology (MeteoSwiss) reported that temperatures between 31 and 33 °C had been recorded in the southern Alps, central Valais, and the Lake Geneva region, but the threshold to be considered a heat wave (average temperature of 25 °C throughout the day) had only been exceeded locally. On Friday, June 17, MeteoSwiss activated orange and yellow heat wave alerts for most of the country. Maximum temperatures between 32 and 37 °C were expected from that same day until the following Tuesday in low-altitude areas of Valais and French-speaking Switzerland, and between Saturday and Tuesday in the Basel region.

In Spain, after the heatwave of 1981, it is the earliest heatwave on record. The episode began on Sunday, June 12, 2022, when temperatures above 40°C were recorded at 47 stations of the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet) network, located in Andalusia, Extremadura, and Castilla-La Mancha. This heatwave follows two other related climatic episodes in Spain in 2022: the widespread drought in the winter of 2021-2022 and the hottest May of the 21st century. The heat caused hundreds of swift chicks to prematurely leave their nests, falling to the ground as they did not know how to fly. The Seville-based NGO Ecourbe, dedicated to biodiversity conservation, reported that up to one hundred chicks were collected from the ground in a single day in Córdoba and Seville. Comisiones Obreras of Extremadura demanded that the reduction of the workday by one hour for construction workers be brought forward, as this reduction is applied from July 15 to mid-August. On June 15, the Madrid City Council activated the red alert protocol for meteorology, given the forecast of a combination of temperatures above 35°C and wind gusts of more than 55 km/h, and consequently closed nine parks in the Spanish capital. The high temperatures, along with the drought, created conditions of extreme risk for forest fires throughout peninsular Spain, except for Galicia, most of the border with Portugal, and isolated points along the coast. A fire in the Sierra de la Culebra (Zamora) forced the evacuation of eight municipalities, while another fire in the province of Toledo led to the evacuation of 3,200 people from the Puy du Fou España theme park. High temperatures in schools caused an increase in dizziness and fainting among children. Families, teachers, and experts called for a plan to adapt schools to future heatwaves, which they will face if no action is taken for the next school year. Air conditioning should be the last resort to lower temperatures in schools, as it accelerates climate change, which in the coming years will cause more frequent and extreme heatwaves. The Community of Madrid manages four public swimming pools in the capital. Until Thursday, June 16, the intention was to keep them closed until the end of June. Swimming in pools alleviates the unpleasant thermal sensation caused by extreme heat, so public complaints led the Sports Councilor, Marta Rivera de La Cruz, to change the plan for opening these public pools. She apologized to the people of Madrid: "It is true that the heatwave should have brought forward that opening." She announced that next year they will open at the beginning of the month, as was historically done until 2019. On Monday, June 20, hospitals in Zaragoza recorded an "unusual peak" in emergencies due to the heatwave. Some patients had to wait more than 60 hours to be admitted due to a lack of beds, with conditions caused in elderly and chronically ill people by the prolonged heatwave of the previous week. This new workload due to the heatwave adds to the burden that hospital emergency staff have been enduring for more than two years.

In the twelve French departments on red alert due to the heatwave, the Ministry of National Education and Youth established several preventive measures. Among them, it allowed primary and secondary school students not to attend classes on Friday, June 17, if parents so wished. Likewise, several departments have implemented restrictions on outdoor physical activity. The Gers prefecture recommended canceling any outdoor physical or sports activity. The Gironde prefecture urged its residents not to exercise outdoors and banned any public events outdoors or in non-air-conditioned venues. In Tarn, the broadcast of the Top 14 rugby championship semifinal between Castres Olympique and Stade Toulousain on a giant screen was prohibited. Finally, several departments, even without being on red or orange alert, have recommended that drivers reduce their speed on the road.
Northern Italy experienced the worst drought in the last 70 years. The flow levels of the Po and Tiber rivers recorded very low levels for this time of year, with the Po reaching critical levels.

The Royal Ascot equestrian event took the unprecedented step of relaxing its dress code, allowing men to remove their hats and jackets after the royal procession. It also allowed spectators to enter the enclosure with drinks.

Article_Name: Tempête du 26 novembre 1954 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub concerning Europe and meteorology or climatology. edit - edit code - edit Wikidata The storm of November 26, 1954, is a violent meteorological event that affected northwestern Europe in November 1954[1].

This storm is centered over northwestern Europe between Ireland and Sweden. Wind gusts are recorded at 140 km/h in Cherbourg. Atmospheric pressure drops to 729 mmHg (the average atmospheric pressure at sea level is 1,013 hPa or 760 mmHg). This storm is rated at force 12 on the Beaufort scale.

The damage is significant. On the southeast tip of Great Britain, the lightship indicating the Goodwin Sands runs aground. In France, this storm affects fishermen at sea. Thus, the ports of Finistère are particularly bereaved, with 64 fishermen missing in the southern part of the department. The fishing port of Concarneau is particularly affected: five boats disappear, and the neighboring town of Névez counts 17 missing. On December 16, 1954, a ceremony is held in the church of Concarneau, bringing together 7,000 people.

Article_Name: Tempête du 6 au 8 novembre 1982 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The storm from November 6 to 8, 1982, is a meteorological event that affected part of Europe in November 1982. It caused violent winds of over 100 km/h, exceptional rainfall, and significant swells in the Gulf of Lion and the Provençal coast. In addition to numerous damages, the storm resulted in a total of 41 deaths. Due to its magnitude, it is the most violent and destructive storm in southern France in a century[1],[2],[3].

A depression forms off the coast of Europe, in the North Atlantic Ocean, on November 6, 1982, reaching an atmospheric pressure of 960 HPa, making it an Atlantic storm of the Ss type (Dreveton classification)[1]. It moves southeast and makes landfall at Cape Finisterre, Spain, the next day at 7 PM[1]. At the same time, high pressure systems stagnate over Eastern Europe, trapping cold air at ground level, particularly in the Po Valley: it is −1°C in Venice at 7 AM on November 7[1]. Changing direction, the storm moves northeast and reaches Brittany during the night of November 7 to 8 while weakening, eventually dissipating the following day over the British Isles[1]. The storm reaches its peak on November 7 while over France[2].

During its passage over France, east and south winds swept across the country, particularly in its southern half. Except for a few regions (Corsica, Alpes-Maritimes, Landes, Alsace, and Nord-Pas-de-Calais), the entire country experienced winds exceeding 100 km/h. Some exceptional values were recorded, such as 216 km/h at Mont Aigoual, but in plains and mid-altitude mountains, speeds over 130 km/h were measured, such as in Sète (166 km/h), Bouches-du-Rhône (162 km/h), Millau (155 km/h), Saône-et-Loire (151 km/h), and Pyrénées-Orientales (144 km/h). In the wake of strong winds at sea, swells intensified in the western Mediterranean, with wave heights of 9 to 14 meters or more off the coast of Languedoc, 6 to 9 meters in Camargue, 4 to 6 meters in Roussillon and Provence, and 2.5 to 4 meters on the Côte d'Azur. Heavy rains accompanied the winds, with a maximum three-day accumulation of 610 millimeters in Py in the Pyrénées-Orientales. The rest of the Pyrenees were heavily soaked, and a significant Cévenol episode developed with accumulations of 300 to 500 millimeters. Rainfall was also notable in the Provençal hinterland and Corsica. These precipitations caused the flooding of numerous rivers, particularly in the Cévennes and eastern Pyrenees. Foehn effects were observed on the western slopes of mountain ranges, such as in Corsica and the Pyrenees, leading to significant disparities in rainfall over short distances.

Weather conditions cause extensive destruction in Andorra and around thirty French departments: collapsed buildings, uprooted trees, washed-away roads, overturned chimneys and antennas, stranded ships, destroyed oyster farms, etc. The port of Sète is heavily affected by the swell. Power outages impact 700,000 households, or 2 million people. The human toll includes fifteen deaths and sixty injuries in France and twelve deaths in Andorra.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴電母 (2010年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Dianmu (English: Severe Tropical Storm Dianmu; Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Ester; International designation: 1004; JTWC: WP052010) was the fourth tropical cyclone to form in the 2010 Pacific typhoon season. Dianmu is the 100th name on the tropical cyclone name list, provided by China, meaning "Mother of Lightning," responsible for overseeing thunder and lightning.

Tropical disturbance 96W formed on August 2 near 8°00′N 136°00′E / 8.0°N 136.0°E / 8.0; 136.0 [3], initially moving northwest under the easterly flow brought by the subtropical ridge to the north. In a generally unfavorable atmospheric environment, it initially lacked organization and developed slowly. After several days of slow development, it intensified into a tropical depression within the monsoon trough on August 6. The tropical depression gradually strengthened in a favorable environment, becoming a tropical storm on August 8 and was named Khanun by the Japan Meteorological Agency. Khanun turned northward under the influence of the southerly flow brought by the subtropical ridge to the east. At this time, Khanun was still within the monsoon trough, with vigorous convection and good spiral structure, but concentrated in the eastern part, with the low-level circulation center partially exposed. Khanun intensified into a severe tropical storm at noon on August 9, with its structure further consolidating in the afternoon as the low-level circulation center developed under the convection and began forming an eye. Khanun reached its peak intensity on August 10, with maximum sustained winds near its center reaching 95 km/h and maximum gusts of 130 km/h. 

On the evening of August 10, Khanun moved to the northwest of the subtropical ridge, turning northeast, passing about 10 km west of Jeju Island [4], and crossing southern South Korea the next morning. At this time, Khanun began to weaken due to strong vertical wind shear and the terrain of South Korea, with convection starting to dissipate and shift eastward, exposing the low-level circulation center. Khanun made landfall in Busan at noon, passing about 15 km northwest of the city [5]. Later that afternoon, Khanun entered the Sea of Japan. Affected by low sea surface temperatures and strong vertical wind shear, Khanun weakened into a tropical storm early on August 12 and crossed Japan that afternoon, eventually transitioning into an extratropical cyclone early the next day [6].

Due to the astronomical high tide, areas along the Zhejiang coast such as Aojiang, Zhenhai, and Zhapu will experience tide levels close to or slightly exceeding the warning line. Therefore, authorities have issued a yellow storm surge warning and advised preparations for wind protection.

Affected by Typhoon Khanun, the wind in Naha began to strengthen on August 8. According to local airport meteorological data, strong southeast winds persisted starting the morning of August 9, later shifting to south winds later in the morning, with brief periods of gale-force winds, followed by sustained strong winds throughout the day. The day was mostly cloudy with occasional heavy rain. As Typhoon Khanun moved away, the wind in Naha began to weaken on August 10, with strong winds subsiding in the morning and showers decreasing.

Typhoon Khanun passed over Jeju Island on the evening of August 10. During the passage of the eye, local winds temporarily calmed, and the sea level pressure dropped to 989 hPa. On August 11, Khanun also crossed the Korean Peninsula, becoming the first tropical cyclone to directly impact South Korea this year and the first since Typhoon Kalmaegi in 2008. As Khanun approached, the sea level pressure in Busan began to drop on August 10, decreasing from 1011 hPa in the morning to 1007 hPa in the evening. The southeast wind also began to strengthen in the evening, reaching gale force on August 11.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴圓規 (2004年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Kompasu (English: Tropical Storm Kompasu, International Number: 0409, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 12W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Julian) was the 9th named tropical cyclone of the 2004 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kompasu" was provided by Japan, meaning the constellation Compass.

Kompas developed into a tropical depression approximately 620 kilometers southeast of Kaohsiung early on July 14. It strengthened into a tropical storm that afternoon and moved westward, crossing the Luzon Strait. After entering the South China Sea, Kompas generally took a northwest path toward the Guangdong coast. On July 16, Kompas turned to move northwest by north and made landfall in Sai Kung, Hong Kong, with maximum sustained winds near the center at 23 meters per second (approximately 85 kilometers per hour) and a minimum central pressure of 992 hPa. It weakened into a tropical depression that evening and then dissipated inland in Guangdong.
The highest typhoon signal issued locally: Typhoon warning for sea and land.

The Hong Kong Observatory issued the Standby Signal No. 1 at 10:55 pm on July 14, when Kompasu was located about 720 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. Due to the subsiding air currents of Kompasu, the weather was dry and very hot from July 14 to 15. As Kompasu approached, the Observatory issued the Strong Wind Signal No. 3 at 5:15 am on July 16, when Kompasu was about 170 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. At 5:20 am, the Observatory stated that it would consider issuing the Gale or Storm Signal No. 8 between the morning and noon. At 7:55 am, the Observatory further stated that Kompasu would come very close to Hong Kong, making the issuance of Signal No. 8 highly likely, and Kompasu's spiral rainbands began bringing showers to Hong Kong. Winds at Waglan Island gradually strengthened to gale force in the morning, and the Observatory issued a "Special Announcement on Tropical Cyclone" at 9:45 am, announcing that Signal No. 8 was expected to be issued by 11:45 am or earlier, when Kompasu was about 80 kilometers southeast of the Observatory. At 11:45 am, the Observatory issued the Northeast Gale or Storm Signal No. 8, when Kompasu was about 60 kilometers southeast of the Observatory, and subsequently changed to the Northwest Gale or Storm Signal No. 8 at 2:45 pm. Around 3:00 pm on July 16, Kompasu made landfall in Sai Kung. At the same time, it was closest to the Observatory headquarters, located about 25 kilometers east of the headquarters. After landfall, Kompasu moved across the northeastern New Territories. The Observatory changed to the Southwest Gale or Storm Signal No. 8 at 4:45 pm, when Kompasu was about 30 kilometers north of the Observatory. As Kompasu began to move away from Hong Kong and weakened into a tropical depression, winds within the territory gradually subsided, and the Observatory changed to the Strong Wind Signal No. 3 at 7:20 pm on July 16, when Kompasu was about 55 kilometers north of the Observatory. Subsequently, all tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 8:20 pm.

During Kompasu's closest approach to Hong Kong on the afternoon of July 16, strong winds were generally experienced within the territory, with gales over offshore waters and on high ground. The highest hourly mean wind speed recorded at Tap Mun was 47 kilometers per hour, with the highest gust reaching 79 kilometers per hour. Waglan Island recorded the highest hourly mean wind speed of 88 kilometers per hour, with the highest gust reaching 106 kilometers per hour. The minimum instantaneous sea-level pressures recorded at the Observatory headquarters, Waglan Island, and Ta Kwu Ling were 1,000.5 hPa, 995.7 hPa, and 1,001.0 hPa, respectively. Kompasu's rainbands and remnants brought heavy squally showers to Hong Kong on the afternoon of July 16 and the following day. The Observatory issued the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal twice, from 5:00 pm to 6:50 pm on July 16 and from 2:20 am to 3:30 am on July 17. The Observatory headquarters recorded over 120 millimeters of rainfall in total.

Additionally, during Kompasu's impact on Hong Kong, 12 people were injured, including two who were struck by falling objects in Tsuen Wan and North Point. The Leisure and Cultural Services Department received 19 emergency assistance requests for trees blown down by strong winds, blocking roads or posing dangers, with 4 cases on Hong Kong Island, 6 in Kowloon, and 9 in the New Territories. There was one minor flooding incident on Lockhart Road in Wan Chai, and no reports of landslides across the territory. The Home Affairs Department opened 25 temporary shelters, accommodating a total of 276 residents. Regarding maritime transport, most ferry services within the harbor and to outlying islands were suspended at one point. For land transport, the MTR, East Rail, West Rail, and Light Rail maintained limited services (the railway company was then known as KCR, now MTR), and public transport services gradually returned to normal in the evening.

The Observatory issued a "Special Announcement on Tropical Cyclone" at 9:45 am on July 16 and issued Signal No. 8 at 11:45 am. Many citizens only learned about the issuance of Signal No. 8 while commuting to work or after arriving at their workplaces (some had already been working for one or two hours), prompting them to rush home. Some citizens questioned why the Observatory could not issue Signal No. 8 earlier, before the start of work and school hours. Since Kompasu was only a tropical storm with a small circulation structure, its gale radius was only about 60 kilometers, and its strong wind radius was only about 150 kilometers. Therefore, slight changes in its path could significantly affect the wind conditions in Hong Kong. If Kompasu's path had shifted, making landfall east of Hong Kong along the eastern Guangdong coast instead of in Hong Kong, it might not have been necessary to issue Signal No. 8. As a result, the Observatory could only state that the chance of issuing Signal No. 8 was high without specifying the exact time. At 9:00 am on July 16, when Kompasu was about 100 kilometers east-southeast of the Observatory headquarters, winds in Hong Kong only reached moderate to fresh levels (not meeting the lower limit of Signal No. 3). Therefore, the earliest the Observatory could issue a Signal No. 8 alert was at 9:45 am. During the period when Signal No. 8 was in effect, only offshore waters and high ground experienced gale-force winds. After Kompasu weakened into a tropical depression, Signal No. 3 was issued at 7:20 pm on the same day.

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 2:25 a.m. on July 15, when Kompasu was located about 700 kilometers east-southeast of Macau. As Kompasu approached, the Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau upgraded to Typhoon Signal No. 3 at 11:30 a.m. on July 16, when Kompasu was about 110 kilometers east-southeast of Macau. By 1 p.m., Kompasu was centered 100 kilometers east of Macau, moving northwest at a speed of about 20 kilometers per hour, gradually approaching Macau. The wind intensified, and the Meteorological Bureau announced that there was a high chance of hoisting Typhoon Signal No. 8 based on the typhoon's trajectory. While residents were generally expecting Kompasu to bring Typhoon Signal No. 8 to Macau, Kompasu, true to its name, abruptly changed its course by 90 degrees, heading directly toward Hong Kong. It made landfall at the High Island Reservoir in Sai Kung at 3 p.m. After changing its course, Kompasu's impact upon landfall posed no threat to Macau and moved inland into Guangdong. At 4 p.m. on the same day, Kompasu was closest to Macau, located about 95 kilometers northeast of the city. As Kompasu weakened and moved away, the Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau lowered all signals at 9 p.m. on July 16. Kompasu was the only tropical cyclone in 2004 to prompt the hoisting of tropical cyclone signals in Macau.

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Yutu (English: Severe Tropical Storm Yutu, International Number: 0107, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 10W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Huaning) was the seventh named storm of the 2001 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Yutu" was provided by China, referring to the Jade Rabbit on the moon. Chang'e, the wife of the legendary tribal leader Houyi, stole her husband's elixir of immortality and fled to the moon with the Jade Rabbit. It is said that they still reside in the Moon Palace.

At 18:00 UTC on July 22, a tropical depression formed over the northeastern waters of Luzon Island. The tropical depression moved west-northwest. At 18:00 UTC on July 23, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm over the northwestern waters of Luzon Island and was named "Yutu." At 06:00 UTC on July 24, Yutu intensified into a severe tropical storm over the southeastern waters of Hong Kong. At 00:00 UTC on July 25, Yutu reached its peak over the southern waters of Hong Kong. Yutu had a compact circulation with an eye diameter of approximately 60 kilometers. Shortly afterward, Yutu made landfall near Bohe Town, Dianbai County, Maoming City, Guangdong Province. At 18:00 UTC, Yutu weakened into a tropical storm. Yutu turned westward. At 00:00 UTC on July 26, Yutu weakened into a tropical depression in southern China. By 12:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated. [1]
At 8:10 PM on July 23, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning. At 5:20 PM on July 24, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the sea typhoon warning.

Affected by Typhoon Rusa, approximately 4,650 houses were destroyed in Guangdong Province, with cities such as Maoming, Yangjiang, and Zhanjiang within the province estimated to have suffered a total loss of 700 million yuan.

Typhoon Utor was the second typhoon in July 2001 that required the issuance of the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal. This was the first time since 1966 that two No. 8 signals were issued in July. On July 23, a tropical depression formed about 600 kilometers northeast of Manila, Philippines, moving west-northwest at a speed of 25 kilometers per hour. By midday, it entered the Luzon Strait and strengthened into a tropical storm that evening, named "Utor." After entering the South China Sea, Utor shifted westward and strengthened into a severe tropical storm before noon on July 24, and further intensified into a typhoon within a few hours. Utor had a compact circulation with an eye diameter of about 60 kilometers. 

On July 25, Utor moved west-northwest, approaching the western coast of Guangdong. Early on July 26, Utor weakened into a severe tropical storm and made landfall near Zhanjiang around 5 a.m. It further weakened into a tropical storm in the afternoon and moved inland, eventually dissipating into a low-pressure area that evening.

In Hong Kong, the Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9:50 p.m. on July 23, when Utor was about 720 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. On July 24, as Utor continued to approach, its outer rainbands brought heavy showers and thunderstorms to Hong Kong in the afternoon, prompting the Observatory to issue the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 3:50 p.m. That evening, local winds strengthened significantly, with offshore areas experiencing strong winds. 

In the hours before midnight, Utor's central wind speed rapidly increased from 120 kilometers per hour to 148 kilometers per hour, with a gale radius of about 160 kilometers. At 12:30 a.m. on July 25, the Observatory issued the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal. By early morning, offshore and highland areas experienced gale-force winds, and the wind direction shifted from northeast to southeast. At 10:40 a.m., the Observatory issued the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, marking the last time the No. 8 signal was issued in this manner. Utor was closest to Hong Kong at noon, located about 180 kilometers south-southwest of the city. That day, gale-force winds were recorded in southern waters and highland areas of Hong Kong. Under Utor's influence, Cheung Chau recorded a maximum hourly mean wind speed of 68 kilometers per hour and a maximum gust of 115 kilometers per hour. Tai Mo Shan recorded a maximum hourly mean wind speed of 79 kilometers per hour and a maximum gust of 112 kilometers per hour. Torrential rain associated with Utor brought over 60 millimeters of rainfall to areas near Tsuen Wan, while most parts of Hong Kong recorded over 20 millimeters of rainfall. At 7:40 p.m. that evening, the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal was reissued.

During Utor's impact, 10 people in Hong Kong were injured in various accidents, and there were 11 reports of fallen trees. On Lower Albert Road, a six-meter-tall tree was blown down, temporarily disrupting traffic. Two trees were also blown down on Observatory Road in Tsim Sha Tsui, crushing a car and the canopy of a hotel. There were two incidents of scaffolding collapse in Yau Tong and Kwai Chung. Additionally, over 160 people sought refuge in temporary shelters across the city. During the period when the No. 8 signal was in effect, about 30 flights were canceled, and over 150 flights were delayed.

The Observatory hoisted the No. 8 signal on Wednesday, July 25, for a duration of 19 hours and 10 minutes, overlapping completely with mainstream working hours and the operation times of the commercial stock market. Since it was a regular working day (Monday to Saturday), most citizens received a day off. However, due to Typhoon Yutu's relatively small circulation (a gale radius of only 160 kilometers) and a path that was further south than expected (initially predicted to pass about 150 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong, but ultimately passing about 180 kilometers southwest-southwest of Hong Kong), Yutu only brought gales to the southern waters and highlands of Hong Kong. The impact on Hong Kong's urban areas was significantly less than the traditional impression of No. 8 signal wind strength. Urban weather stations such as Sai Kung, the airport, Tsing Yi, and the Kowloon Star Ferry Pier recorded maximum hourly average wind speeds of 49, 44, 43, and 41 kilometers per hour, respectively, which were still some distance from the gale threshold of 63 kilometers per hour. Moreover, Macau, which was closer to Yutu than Hong Kong, only hoisted the No. 3 signal. Authorities in other nearby cities (such as Shenzhen and Zhuhai) also did not issue similarly severe warnings to the public.

As a result, the business sector, led by then Liberal Party Chairman James Tien and then Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce CEO Eden Woon, criticized the Observatory for mistakenly hoisting the No. 8 signal under weather conditions that were not particularly severe. This caused most industries and the stock market to halt operations unnecessarily that day, reducing business profits and resulting in significant economic losses (estimated at HK$3 billion to HK$4 billion). Even then-Chief Secretary for Administration Donald Tsang (later Chief Executive) joined the criticism, stating that caution should be exercised in hoisting typhoon signals in the future. 

Following this incident, the Observatory, to avoid further criticism from the business sector, gradually adopted a more conservative approach to hoisting/issuing signals, basing decisions solely on wind strength within Victoria Harbour. However, the Observatory overlooked the fact that wind strength in the harbor was already shielded by buildings, resulting in lower wind readings compared to other exposed urban weather stations. For example, during Severe Tropical Storm Vongfong in 2002, the Observatory decided at 4 p.m. on August 19 that Vongfong had almost reached its closest point to Hong Kong, passing about 400 kilometers southwest of the city, and refused to issue the No. 3 strong wind signal as winds in the harbor had not reached strong wind levels. However, by around 8 p.m. that evening, Vongfong reached its closest point to Hong Kong, located about 390 kilometers west-southwest of the city, and made landfall near Zhanjiang. At 7 p.m., Kai Tak recorded an hourly average wind speed of 41 kilometers per hour, reaching strong wind levels, while the Kowloon Star Ferry Pier recorded an hourly average wind speed of 40 kilometers per hour at 1 a.m. on August 20, just shy of strong wind levels. Despite strong winds being recorded in the harbor, the Observatory did not mention this in its tropical cyclone warning, only stating that strong winds were affecting offshore and highland areas in the southwest of Hong Kong. The Observatory's increasingly conservative approach to hoisting/issuing signals indirectly contributed to the Prapiroon incident in 2006.

At 2 a.m. on July 23, a tropical depression formed northeast of Luzon and quickly moved westward at a speed of 38 kilometers per hour, heading directly toward the South China Sea. By 8 p.m. on the same day, it strengthened into a tropical storm while crossing the Balintang Channel (approximately at 20.1°N, 121.0°E), with a central pressure of 995 hPa and maximum wind speeds near the center of 65 kilometers per hour. It then steadily moved westward, and by 2 p.m. on July 24, it strengthened into a severe tropical storm in the South China Sea, 400 kilometers southeast of Macau (approximately at 20.5°N, 117.0°E), with a central pressure of 978 hPa and maximum wind speeds near the center of 112 kilometers per hour. Three hours later, it rapidly intensified into a typhoon near Dongsha, with a central pressure dropping to 960 hPa and maximum wind speeds near the center reaching 150 kilometers per hour. Between 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. on July 25, Typhoon "Yutu" passed closest to Macau, about 160 kilometers south to southwest of the city. It then slightly shifted to a west-northwest direction, heading toward the Leizhou Peninsula. At 2 a.m. on July 26, it weakened into a severe tropical storm over the sea west of Macau (approximately at 21.3°N, 111.3°E). Two hours later, it made landfall along the southern coast of China between Yangjiang and Zhanjiang. "Yutu" turned northwestward inland in China and gradually dissipated, weakening into a tropical storm at 11 a.m. on July 26 and further into a tropical depression by 5 p.m. During its impact on Macau, there were minor damages such as fallen trees and signboards, as well as flooding in low-lying areas.

Article_Name: 颱風愛茜 (1975年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Elsie (International designation: 7515, China designation: 7514, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 17W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Mameng) was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 1975 Pacific typhoon season and one of the few typhoons to directly hit Hong Kong in October.

On October 9, 1975, a tropical depression formed approximately 740 kilometers southwest of Guam, moving west-northwest, and strengthened into a severe tropical storm on October 10, named Elsie. On October 11, Elsie intensified into a typhoon and underwent explosive intensification within the next day, with its central pressure dropping by 69 hPa to 898 hPa in 24 hours, and its central wind speed increasing to about 240 kilometers per hour. Subsequently, Elsie crossed the Bashi Channel into the South China Sea. Its intensity weakened slightly, with maximum wind speeds of about 205 kilometers per hour and a circulation diameter of 555 kilometers. After entering the South China Sea, Elsie was guided by the westward-extending subtropical ridge, shifting to a more westerly direction and crossing the northern part of the South China Sea.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 Standby Signal at 10:45 PM on October 12, as Typhoon Elsie was centered about 740 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong, moving northwest at a speed of about 14 kilometers per hour towards the northeastern part of the South China Sea. After crossing the Bashi Channel, Elsie took a more westerly path. The Observatory replaced the Standby Signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 8:00 PM on October 13, when Elsie was centered about 350 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. Although Hong Kong was experiencing only light to moderate westerly winds at the time, Elsie was still expected to be intense and might pass close to Hong Kong, prompting the Observatory to warn residents to complete wind protection measures. At 4:30 AM on October 14, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 8 Northwest Gale or Storm Signal, as Elsie was centered about 190 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. At that time, Hong Kong experienced moderate to fresh northwesterly winds. As Elsie approached during the day, wind strength in Hong Kong increased rapidly, with gale-force winds recorded starting at 9:00 AM, when Elsie was centered about 130 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. Elsie remained well-organized and continued moving westward. At 11:00 AM, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 9 Gale or Storm Increasing Signal, indicating that wind strength in Hong Kong would significantly increase, as Elsie was centered about 70 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. By early afternoon, with clear signs that the eye of the storm would pass over the southern part of Hong Kong Island and its waters, the Observatory hoisted the No. 10 Hurricane Signal at 2:15 PM, with hurricane-force winds recorded offshore and in high-altitude areas. Elsie came closest to Hong Kong at 2:30 PM, centered about 50 kilometers south of the Observatory, moving westward at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour. During the afternoon, Tai Mo Shan recorded wind speeds of 130 kilometers per hour, with maximum gusts of 180 kilometers per hour, while Stanley recorded wind speeds of 141 kilometers per hour, with maximum gusts of 219 kilometers per hour. The instantaneous sea-level pressure at the Observatory headquarters dropped to a minimum of 996.2 hPa after 3:00 PM and quickly rose after the typhoon passed. 

Elsie began to weaken after passing south of Hong Kong. As Elsie moved away, Hong Kong experienced easterly winds in the late afternoon, and wind strength began to moderate. At 5:05 PM, the Observatory replaced the No. 10 Hurricane Signal with the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, as Elsie was centered about 50 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. Later, at 8:10 PM, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal, as Elsie was centered about 70 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. On the evening of October 14, Elsie resumed a west-northwest path and further weakened into a tropical storm. After 10:00 PM, it crossed the coast of southern China about 110 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong. Wind strength in Hong Kong continued to weaken, and all signals were canceled at 2:00 AM on October 15, as the storm was centered about 150 kilometers west of Hong Kong. With a cool northeast monsoon beginning to affect the southern China coast, Elsie weakened into a tropical depression within the next hour and eventually dissipated inland about 190 kilometers west of Hong Kong by early morning.

Before Elsie's approach, Hong Kong experienced sunny and hot weather on October 12 and 13. On the morning of October 14, the weather turned cloudy with scattered showers, and rain became more frequent and accompanied by strong winds during the day. As Elsie moved closer to Hong Kong, heavy rain began in the early afternoon. The heaviest rain occurred between noon and 2:00 PM as Elsie passed south of Hong Kong. As Elsie moved away, rain weakened slightly later in the afternoon. On October 15, the weather remained overcast with light rain and occasional squally showers. Due to the influence of the easterly wind surge, the weather did not improve significantly the following day.

Under the influence of Elsie, five ocean-going vessels in Hong Kong dragged their anchors, and 46 people were injured on land due to debris and collapsed scaffolding, but there were no fatalities. Over 1,000 people sought refuge in storm shelters.

After passing south of Hong Kong, Nesat continued to move almost due west and weakened into a severe tropical storm. On the night of October 14, when it was closest to Macau, it was only 28 kilometers south of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters. The Meteorological Bureau hoisted the No. 9 signal for the third consecutive year. Macau recorded a rainfall of 91.8 millimeters that day. During its impact on Macau, it caused minor property damage but no casualties.

Article_Name: 颱風雪麗 (1968年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Shirley (English: Typhoon Shirley, International Number: 6809, Mainland China Number: 6808, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 13W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Huaning) is a tropical cyclone that appeared in the Northwest Pacific. It is one of the few typhoons whose eye directly swept through the urban area of Hong Kong, and it is the first tropical cyclone since Typhoon Alice in 1961 to directly pass over the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters and trigger the issuance of the No. 10 typhoon signal.

On August 17, 1968, a tropical depression formed approximately 1,200 kilometers east of Manila, moving westward. At 6:03 AM on August 18 (Hong Kong time), a reconnaissance aircraft reported a sea-level pressure of 991 hPa near the eye, and the tropical cyclone was named Shirley. After forming, Shirley moved west-northwest, heading directly toward the northern part of Luzon Island in the Philippines. At that time, Shirley's diameter was approximately 580 kilometers. On the morning of August 19 (Hong Kong time), a reconnaissance aircraft recorded a sea-level pressure of 962 hPa near the eye, and Shirley officially intensified into a severe tropical storm. At 3 PM that afternoon, a weather station on Luzon Island, located 120 kilometers west of the eye, recorded a wind speed of 74 kilometers per hour.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 6:10 am on August 20, when Shirley was located about 650 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. As Shirley continued to approach, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 3 signal at 6:15 pm. Shirley changed direction to move northwest towards Hong Kong in the early morning of August 21, and the Observatory replaced the No. 3 signal with the No. 7 signal at 7:00 am, when the storm was about 280 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. Shirley intensified into a typhoon in the afternoon. Due to its strengthening circulation, the Observatory replaced the No. 7 signal with the No. 9 signal at 2:40 pm, indicating stronger gale-force winds. When it was confirmed that the eye of the storm would pass over Hong Kong, the Observatory replaced the No. 9 signal with the No. 10 signal at 4:10 pm, when Shirley was about 80 kilometers southeast of the Observatory. Shirley's eye passed over the Observatory between 7:00 pm and 9:30 pm, during which Hong Kong experienced a sharp drop in wind speed, with light winds prevailing and calm conditions lasting for about two hours, though it remained cloudy with rain. The typhoon appeared to weaken slightly. The Observatory recorded the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure of 968.7 hPa at 7:00 pm, the lowest on record for August. Shirley continued moving northwest at dusk, with most areas experiencing strong southerly winds starting at 10:00 pm. As Shirley weakened into a severe tropical storm at midnight, the Observatory replaced the No. 10 signal with the No. 6 signal at 11:45 pm, when the storm was about 90 kilometers northwest-north of the Observatory. As the winds gradually subsided, the Observatory replaced the No. 6 signal with the No. 3 signal at 5:25 am the next morning, when the storm was about 200 kilometers northwest of Hong Kong. Shirley significantly slowed down over Guangdong and finally weakened into a low-pressure area later in the morning. All signals were canceled at 12:10 pm. Shirley's passage over Hong Kong resulted in four injuries and caused a ship near the waters of Stonecutters Island to collide multiple times with another vessel.
Affected by Sherry, Macau recorded the highest hourly average wind speed of 74 kilometers per hour and the highest gust wind speed of 130 kilometers per hour.

Article_Name: 颱風波密拉 (1961年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Pamela (English: Typhoon Pamela, International Number: 6120, Mainland China Number: 6122, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 20W) was a well-known intense typhoon in the 1960s and one of the typhoons that caused significant wind damage in Taiwan, with the disaster area concentrated in northern Taiwan.

On September 6, 1961, a tropical depression formed over the waters near Guam, moving northwest at a speed of 25 kilometers per hour. However, the guiding airflow became unclear, and from the 7th to the 9th, its speed was only 5 kilometers per hour. During this time, its development was very slow, and it was not until the afternoon of September 9 that it intensified into a mild typhoon (by today's standards, it would not yet be considered a mild typhoon). At this point, it was located about 850 kilometers southwest of Iwo Jima. The typhoon then began to intensify rapidly, with its maximum wind speed increasing from 15 meters per second to 35 meters per second by the following morning. Its speed also began to accelerate, moving northwest-west at 15 kilometers per hour. At this time, Pamila had already become a moderate typhoon.

On the morning of September 11, Pamila had moved to the waters south of Naha. A strong high-pressure ridge to the north guided it to move west-northwest, with a pressure of 950 millibars and a maximum wind speed of 50 meters per second at its center. It had developed into a strong typhoon by the standards of the time. It suddenly accelerated, increasing from a slow pace to 33 kilometers per hour, and its westward path posed a serious threat to Taiwan. By 8 p.m., Pamila had reached a pressure of 930 millibars, with a peak maximum wind speed of 60 meters per second, and was located about 270 kilometers east of Hualien. At 2 a.m. on the 12th, it made landfall in the area between Yilan and Hualien. Later, it made a second landfall in mainland China. After making landfall in mainland China, Pamila gradually weakened and dissipated.

What is truly astonishing is not just that Typhoon Pamela passed directly through the Central Mountain Range, but that despite being a relatively fast-moving typhoon, which generally causes more wind damage than rain, it brought only 100 millimeters of rainfall yet caused severe flooding in the Taipei area. Areas such as Sanchong, Luzhou, Xinzhuang, Yonghe, Shilin, and Dazhi experienced serious flooding. Many of the flooded areas were within the Dahan River basin. In addition to the natural factor of heavy rain, it is said that human factors also played a role. The newly completed Shimen Reservoir upstream of the Dahan River misjudged the situation and suddenly released water. At a time when information was not well-developed, the public was unprepared, leading to catastrophic flooding and casualties in the Dahan River basin. According to data from the police department at the time, Typhoon Pamela caused 153 deaths, 140 missing persons, and 1,874 injuries across Taiwan. A total of 12,349 houses were completely destroyed, and 26,442 houses were partially destroyed, resulting in severe casualties. Many fishing boats also capsized and were damaged. Yilan County bore the brunt of the disaster and suffered unprecedented losses. After the disaster, the Executive Yuan established the "Taipei Area River Flood Control Plan Review Committee" to actively implement the Taipei flood control plan.

In general, many typhoons passing through Taiwan's Central Mountain Range encounter varying levels of difficulty due to the circulation at different altitudes, which can easily induce a secondary low-pressure center to guide the typhoon across the mountains. However, Typhoon Pamela moved at a very fast speed, crossing the Snow Mountain Range before a secondary low-pressure system could form. By 8 a.m., it had already exited to the northwest of Taichung, spending only a little over five hours on land, which was quite astonishing. During this time, the typhoon's structure was also damaged, downgrading it to a moderate typhoon. While crossing the Snow Mountain Range, due to the influence of wind and terrain, the Foehn effect occurred in the Taitung area, causing temperatures to rise from 27°C at 1 a.m. to 32.3°C at 2 a.m., which lasted until 6 a.m. By 2 p.m., Pamela had entered the mainland and rapidly weakened, transforming into an extratropical cyclone by the next morning.

The highest average wind speed of Typhoon Pamela was recorded in Keelung City at 35 meters per second, followed by the landfall point in Yilan County at 34.8 meters per second, with the maximum instantaneous gust reaching 44.8 meters per second. In terms of rainfall, Wulai in Taipei County received the most, with 347.2 millimeters during the typhoon's passage over Taiwan. Su'ao Township recorded 319.8 millimeters, Yilan City had 203 millimeters, Taipei City only received 100 millimeters, and the plains in the southwest and eastern regions barely exceeded 50 millimeters. Hengchun Township experienced almost no rainfall (0.9 millimeters).

Additionally, when Pamela formed, its development was slow during the first three days, and its structure was not very strong. However, it rapidly intensified into a severe typhoon within just two to three days (one of the fastest-developing typhoons in recent years was Typhoon Zeb). It also accelerated from its initial slow movement. The meteorological bureau originally predicted that Pamela would continue moving northwest, but unexpectedly, the high pressure to the north prevented it from moving northward, causing it to shift westward and threaten Taiwan. At the time, meteorological technology was lacking, and there was insufficient maritime data to make accurate predictions. The bureau had to rely on meteorological data from the U.S. military to issue typhoon warnings for Pamela. The bureau initially predicted landfall at 9 a.m. on the 12th, but as the typhoon approached eastern Taiwan, it slowed down to search for a landfall point. However, it unexpectedly made landfall in the Yilan-Hualien border area at 2 a.m., catching meteorologists off guard. It then rapidly crossed the Snow Mountain Range, leaving meteorologists astonished and drawing criticism from the public for the large prediction error. Furthermore, the severe flooding in the Dahan River basin in Taipei was attributed to human factors, highlighting that the issues surrounding Typhoon Pamela were not only about its path but also about human negligence.

Article_Name: 熱帶低氣壓618 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Depression 618 (English: Tropical Depression 618) is a tropical depression that formed in Hong Kong waters in 2000. This tropical depression formed in nearshore waters and was only upgraded by the Hong Kong Observatory.

On June 18, 2000, a trough of low pressure affected the northern South China Sea and the coastal areas of Guangdong. At 9 PM that evening, one of the atmospheric vortices within the trough intensified into a small tropical depression over the waters south of Lantau Island, approximately 35 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters. The Hong Kong Observatory assessed its central wind speed at 60 kilometers per hour. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also rated this tropical disturbance as "low," indicating a certain probability of developing into a tropical cyclone, but it was ultimately not upgraded to a tropical depression. The tropical depression moved northward, passing between Lantau Island and Hong Kong Island, then crossing Tsing Yi Island, and made landfall near Tsuen Wan before 10:15 PM that evening. It passed through Pat Heung and Kai Kung Leng. The tropical depression left Hong Kong around midnight, entering Shenzhen near Lok Ma Chau. Subsequently, Tropical Depression 618 continued into inland Guangdong and quickly dissipated.

Tropical Depression 618 caused the Hong Kong Observatory to issue the first tropical cyclone warning signal of 2000, and it was also the first tropical cyclone to directly affect Hong Kong (passing within 100 kilometers) after the millennium. Due to the formation of a tropical depression within Hong Kong's territory, wind speeds increased rapidly, prompting the Observatory to directly issue the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 9:15 PM. This was the first time since 1993 that the No. 3 Signal was directly issued. At that time, the tropical depression was located about 35 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters. The tropical depression had a diameter of approximately 200 kilometers, with a strong wind radius of about 25 kilometers and a central wind speed of 60 kilometers per hour. The tropical depression came closest to the Observatory headquarters at around 10 PM that night, passing about 10 kilometers west of the headquarters, and then made landfall near Tsuen Wan before 10:15 PM (initial reports suggested landfall around 10:30 PM). It crossed the western New Territories, with winds shifting to the southwest and gradually weakening by early morning. Sustained winds in the eastern regions briefly reached gale force, with a 10-minute average wind speed of 70 kilometers per hour recorded in Sai Kung. 

As the tropical depression moved inland and began to dissipate, the Observatory announced at midnight that the No. 3 Signal would be lowered shortly, and all tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 1:45 AM the following day. During the impact of Tropical Depression 618 on Hong Kong, incidents such as scaffolding collapse in Siu Sai Wan and wooden boards falling from a construction site in Chai Wan occurred, but no injuries were reported. 

It is relatively rare for a tropical depression to form so close to land. The last tropical cyclone to form in close proximity was Tropical Storm Lisa in 1996, which formed about 160 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong, requiring only the issuance of the No. 1 Standby Signal. This tropical depression was later referred to as "Tropical Depression 618."

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau considered the low-pressure area's gale radius to be small and did not upgrade it, thus no signal was issued, resulting in a discrepancy in the level 2 cyclone warning between Hong Kong and Macau. On the afternoon of June 18, under the influence of a low-pressure trough, the Macau Meteorological Bureau issued a red rainstorm warning signal at 3:00 PM, which was subsequently canceled at 5:15 PM. The accumulated rainfall across various districts in Macau that day reached 84.8 to 126.6 millimeters. The lowest recorded pressure in Macau that day was 1005.2 hPa.
