Article_Name: 熱帶風暴菲特 (2001年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Fitow (English: Tropical Storm Fitow, International Number: 0114, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 18W) was the 14th named storm of the 2001 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Fitow" was provided by Micronesia and refers to a beautiful and fragrant flower.

On the morning of August 28, a tropical depression formed over the South China Sea. The tropical depression moved westward, then turned northwest, and passed near Changsa Town, Wenchang City, Hainan Province, at 5 p.m. on August 29. The tropical depression then turned northwest. At 2 a.m. on August 31, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm in the Beibu Gulf and was named Fitow. At noon on August 31, Fitow made landfall near Qisha Town, Port District, Fangchenggang City, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region. After landfall, Fitow quickly weakened. By 2 p.m., Fitow had weakened into a tropical depression. By 5 p.m. on September 1, it had completely dissipated. [1] However, the China Meteorological Administration believed that Fitow had not completely dissipated, later re-entered the sea off the eastern Leizhou Peninsula, and made landfall again in Sanya City, Hainan Province, at 5 a.m. on September 10, before dissipating after making landfall in Vietnam at 2 a.m. on September 12. It affected Hainan Province for 16 days, making it the longest-lasting tropical cyclone to affect Hainan Province since 1949. It made landfall on Hainan Island twice and stayed on land for over 72 hours, also making it the longest-lasting tropical cyclone to make landfall on Hainan Island since 1949. [2][3]

The No. 1 Standby Signal was hoisted at 10:15 PM on August 28. Under the combined influence of Fitow and a continental anticyclone, strong winds were experienced offshore and in high areas of Hong Kong. On August 29, the outer rainbands of Fitow brought heavy rain to Hong Kong, with over 100 millimeters of rainfall recorded in the Sha Tin and Shek Kong areas on that day. Fitow was closest to Hong Kong on the evening of August 29, located about 320 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. Under the influence of Fitow, the Hong Kong Observatory recorded the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure of 998.8 hPa at 5:18 AM on August 29. As Fitow gradually moved away from Hong Kong, local winds weakened, and the No. 1 Standby Signal was canceled at 4:45 AM on August 30. However, the outer rainbands of Fitow continued to bring occasional heavy rain to Hong Kong, and the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal was issued at 12:55 PM that afternoon, remaining in effect until 5:20 PM. In Hong Kong, on August 28, Fire Services Officer Chiu Shun-on tragically lost his life while rescuing a 15-year-old boy from drowning at Tai Long Wan in Sai Kung.

Whole_Text.header: After the storm, there was even a heavy rainstorm.
Whole_Text.content: After Typhoon Fitow dissipated, its remnants formed an active trough of low pressure along the southern coast of China, bringing heavy rain and severe thunderstorms from the night of September 1 to the early morning of September 2. The Hong Kong Observatory issued a Black Rainstorm Warning Signal at 10:45 PM on September 1, which was not canceled until 4:30 AM. Rainfall across Hong Kong reached 100 millimeters, with areas such as Tsuen Wan, Kwai Chung, and Sha Tin recording up to 200 millimeters. During the rainstorm, there were over 19 cases of flooding and 11 landslides. One landslide occurred in Tai Wai, where 11 villagers had to be urgently evacuated. In Sai Kung, a slope collapsed during the rainstorm, severely damaging a stone house. A section of the overhead power cable on the Kwun Tong Line of the MTR was struck by lightning, causing a temporary power outage. One train service between Quarry Bay Station and Lam Tin Station was disrupted, and approximately 400 passengers had to walk 500 meters along the tracks to the station. The trough of low pressure lingered along the southern coast of China, causing unstable weather for several days. Red Rainstorm Warning Signals were issued on September 3 and September 7. The weather in Hong Kong only improved on September 8 as the trough moved away.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Signal No. 1 at 10:30 PM on August 28. As Typhoon Fitow gradually approached Macao, the bureau upgraded to Signal No. 3 at 1:30 PM the following afternoon. Fitow was closest to Macao between 10 PM on August 28 and 1 PM on August 29, located approximately 300 kilometers southwest of Macao. As Fitow gradually moved away from Macao, the winds weakened, and Signal No. 3 was lowered at 6 AM on August 30.

Article_Name: 颱風嘉曼 (1974年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Carmen (Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Tering) was one of the named tropical cyclones in the 1974 Pacific typhoon season and one of the few typhoons to affect the northern South China Sea in October. Due to Carmen's impact, Hong Kong and Macau had to hoist the second-highest No. 9 tropical cyclone warning signal for two consecutive years. The storm formed on October 14 over the Philippine Sea, further developing into a typhoon and moving toward central Philippines, where it made landfall. While affecting the Philippines, Carmen weakened temporarily due to terrain effects but reorganized after entering the South China Sea. However, as it approached the coast near the Pearl River Estuary, it was suddenly deflected westward by cold air from Guangdong Province, avoiding landfall, and dissipated south of Shangchuan Island on October 20, with a lifespan of about six days. Carmen caused at least 13 deaths, 9 injuries, and economic losses of 64 million pesos in the Philippines. It brought significant damage to South China but also alleviated drought conditions with its rainfall, prompting the Hong Kong government to fully lift the water rationing measures for that year. [Note 1]

A tropical depression formed on October 14 over the Philippine Sea, 805 kilometers east-southeast of Manila, Philippines. After forming, it moved westward at a speed of approximately 13 kilometers per hour, heading toward central and northern Philippines. [1] The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration began monitoring it and assigned it the Philippine name "Tering" as it formed within the Philippine Area of Responsibility. [2] The next day, the system shifted to a northwestward movement, and both the Royal Hong Kong Observatory and the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm, with the latter naming it "Koinu." [3] On the same day, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a mild typhoon. [4][Note 2] The Hong Kong Observatory further upgraded Koinu to a severe tropical storm on the same day. [1] By October 16, Koinu had intensified further. The Hong Kong Observatory analyzed satellite imagery and noted that its circulation was well-organized. Subsequently, reconnaissance aircraft reported a continuous drop in central pressure, prompting the Observatory to follow the U.S. in upgrading it to a typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon on the same day. [3][4][1] Koinu maintained a northwestward direction on the same day and made landfall in central Luzon. It later exited to the sea, entering the northern South China Sea. [1] Koinu's structure was damaged due to the terrain of the Philippines, leading the U.S. to downgrade it to a tropical storm. However, as it moved over the South China Sea, it reorganized, and the U.S. re-upgraded Koinu to a typhoon. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau maintained its classification as a typhoon and a moderate typhoon, respectively. [4][1] Later on October 17, Koinu steadily moved to the waters south of the Pearl River Estuary, accelerating to a speed of nearly 17 kilometers per hour. The Hong Kong Observatory observed that its spiral rainbands continued to develop and intensify. [1] On October 18, the Hong Kong Observatory's weather radar captured Koinu's cyclone center, with an eye diameter of nearly 100 kilometers, and indicated that Koinu was turning northwestward, moving closer to the Pearl River Estuary. [1] However, the U.S. and the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it again to a tropical storm and a mild typhoon, respectively, on the same day. [4] At that time, Guangdong Province was under the influence of cold air, which affected Koinu. As it approached the coastal area near the Pearl River Estuary, it suddenly turned westward without making landfall and began to weaken rapidly during the day on October 19. The U.S. and the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it to a tropical depression within the same day, while the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. [3][4][1] The next day, the Hong Kong Observatory reported that Koinu had weakened into a low-pressure area south of Shangchuan Island. [1]

After Kammuri made landfall in central Luzon, it affected parts of the Philippines. Flooding occurred in low-lying areas of Manila due to continuous heavy rain, and a bus skidded while traveling in the rain, injuring 35 people. In Mindoro Island to the south, including San Jose City, water levels reached four to five feet, causing severe damage to roads and bridges. In Baguio City, landslides occurred in some residential areas. According to Agence France-Presse, a six-year-old girl and her 16-year-old brother lost their lives due to landslides caused by the typhoon, and some members of two families were injured. The Philippine authorities later reported that the storm caused 13 deaths, 9 injuries, and affected 7,766 households or 28,486 people nationwide, with economic losses amounting to 64 million pesos.

The Observatory hoisted the No. 1 Standby Signal at 10:55 am on October 17. [9] As Kaman moved directly towards the coast of South China, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 4:30 pm the same day, when Kaman was steadily moving northwest in the evening. [10] Due to Kaman's increased northward movement, advancing towards the Pearl River Estuary, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 10:10 am on October 18. [11] Kaman began to turn northwest by north in the evening, moving closer to Hong Kong. At 4:30 am on October 19, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 9 Gale or Storm Increasing Signal. [12] Kaman was closest to Hong Kong at around 9 am, located approximately 130 kilometers southwest by south of Hong Kong, marking the farthest distance of a storm center from Hong Kong for a No. 9 Signal in history. [1] Affected by a cool and dry northerly airstream, Kaman began to turn west and slowly moved away from Hong Kong. As it was expected that the wind in Hong Kong would not further intensify, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 8 Southeast Signal at 11 am and then with the No. 3 Signal at 3 pm the same day. [13] Kaman continued to weaken under the influence of the airstream and became a low-pressure area south of Shangchuan Island on the morning of October 20. All signals were removed at 10 am that day, with all times in daylight saving time. [14][1] In response to the typhoon, the Education Department announced the suspension of classes in all schools across Hong Kong on October 18 and 19. The Foreign Exchange Bankers' Association announced the temporary closure of all banks in Hong Kong. The four major stock exchanges and the Gold and Silver Exchange suspended trading from the afternoon, some maritime routes ceased services, and some flights were canceled. Land transportation and the Kowloon-Canton Railway provided limited services until gradually stopping in the evening. [15] Some government departments deployed personnel to maintain emergency services and remain on alert, while typhoon shelters in various districts were opened for those in need. [16] Kaman brought continuous heavy rain to Hong Kong. A young man who swam from mainland China to Hong Kong was found lying on the beach at Sharp Nose Point during the No. 9 Signal and was confirmed dead after being sent to the hospital. [17] Another girl was swept away by floodwaters in Kam Tin. [18] The storm caused severe flooding in low-lying areas of urban Kowloon and the New Territories. Authorities also received numerous reports of landslides or road damage, as well as incidents of ships breaking anchor and collisions between two vessels, but no injuries were reported. [19] A severe landslide occurred on the slope behind Lai Sing House in Tai Hang Road due to the storm, submerging the underground parking lot in mud. Hundreds of residents of Lai Sing House had to evacuate overnight. [20] The Third Resettlement Area near Chai Wan Estate was affected by the storm, with seawater flooding the area and causing waterlogging. 800 residents had to evacuate to nearby police stations and Chai Wan Estate for temporary shelter, with the number of evacuees later increasing to over a thousand. After the incident, the resettlement area was left muddy, and many homes were in disarray. [21] More than ten days later, Typhoon Ellen struck Hong Kong, prompting the Observatory to hoist the No. 8 Signal again. As both Kaman and Ellen brought abundant rainfall, a record for the highest October rainfall since the Observatory's establishment was set, along with a significant 220 billion gallons of potable water. The Public Works Department's Water Supplies Department announced the complete cancellation of water rationing measures for that year. [22]

The Macau Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 9 at 7:15 a.m. on October 19, which was downgraded to Signal No. 8 at 2:15 p.m. the same day, and further downgraded to Signal No. 3 at 4:30 p.m. that afternoon. During the tropical cyclone's impact, the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge was temporarily closed and only reopened for traffic at 6:30 p.m. on the 19th after the Signal No. 3 was issued. Most shops suspended operations, Macau's streets were paralyzed for a time, and the Emperor Entertainment Group temporarily ceased operations until the evening of the 19th, while the Grand Lisboa remained unaffected. Additionally, Jai Alai and greyhound racing events were also suspended due to the impact of the storm. Signal No. 3 was finally lowered at 8:30 a.m. on October 20, and the city gradually returned to normal. Apart from some damage to farmland and fish ponds, the overall damage across Macau was minimal.

According to the records of the Guangdong Meteorological Observatory in mainland China, the "22nd Typhoon of the Year" (Typhoon 7422, referred to as Carmen) did not make landfall in Guangdong, but its circulation affected the coastal areas of Guangdong, especially around Taishan County. During the typhoon, 44 counties and cities in the province experienced gale-force winds of level 8, and 10 counties and cities experienced winds of level 10. At the same time, 73 counties and cities experienced heavy rain, and 35 counties and cities experienced torrential rain. Among them, Huidong County recorded an extraordinary rainfall of 323.8 millimeters on October 19. In the following days, under the combined influence of the typhoon and cold air, temperatures in Guangzhou and Shaoguan areas dropped to 20 degrees Celsius or below. This affected the late rice harvest, reducing its yield, and the flooded area of rice fields reached 215,000 hectares.

Article_Name: 颱風姬羅莉亞 (1957年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gloria (English: Typhoon Gloria, International Number: 5715, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 14W) was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 1957 Pacific typhoon season. Gloria formed on September 17, 1957. It later crossed the Philippines as a Category 2 typhoon and entered the South China Sea. When Gloria reached the Pearl River Estuary, Hong Kong recorded hurricane-force winds for one hour during the hoisting of the No. 8 signal, prompting the Royal Hong Kong Observatory to directly raise the No. 10 signal. Meanwhile, the Macau Meteorological Bureau did not record sustained hurricane-force winds and thus only raised the No. 9 signal. The observatory recorded 12 hours of strong winds, 14 hours of gale-force winds, and one hour of hurricane-force winds. On September 22, Macau recorded a pressure of 970.8 hPa, an east wind at 110 km/h, gusts reaching 144 km/h, and a maximum daily rainfall of 79.3 mm, causing flooding in low-lying areas of Macau. Typhoon Gloria made landfall in Macau at 9 p.m. on September 22, with maximum wind speeds at the center reaching 162 km/h. It then passed through Zhongshan, Panyu, and Guangzhou before dissipating inland.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 10:20 a.m. Hong Kong Summer Time on September 21, 1957. Less than three hours later, at 1:10 p.m., it was replaced with the No. 3 signal. At 4:00 a.m. on the 22nd, the No. 7 signal was hoisted. At 12:30 p.m., the No. 8 signal was hoisted. Twenty minutes later, at 12:50 p.m., the Observatory directly hoisted the No. 10 signal, making it the only typhoon to directly hit Hong Kong since 1946 without the No. 9 signal being hoisted. It was also the only No. 10 signal in Hong Kong during the entire 1950s, lasting nearly 8 hours. The Observatory replaced the No. 10 signal with the No. 8 signal at 8:45 p.m. and then replaced it with the No. 3 signal at 6:00 a.m. on the 23rd. As Gloria moved away from Hong Kong, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 11:15 p.m.

During the impact of Gloria, the storm surge caused by the storm reached a tidal difference of 2.30 meters, combined with the occurrence of astronomical tides, resulting in a stronger storm surge phenomenon. Macau recorded the highest tide level at 4.35 meters, causing road flooding with a depth of 1.15 meters. [2]

In the northeastern part of Macau, over 200 acres of vegetable fields were flooded, affecting 200 farming households and over 1,000 people. Approximately 5,000 pigs of various sizes drowned, and dozens of wooden houses in the city were destroyed or collapsed. During the storm, a police officer on duty drowned in Hac Sa Wan, a man in Ilha Verde was electrocuted to death, and a man was killed when a shanty house collapsed on Rua da Pedra. When Typhoon Gloria swept through Macau, a seawall near Hac Sa Wan on the eastern side of the Border Gate was breached in three places, flooding the vegetable fields, with water levels reaching six to seven feet at their deepest. Two hundred farming households fled in panic, with cries of distress echoing continuously. Authorities dispatched military police and four small boats for rescue operations, saving 132 people, but a Portuguese police officer, Rodolfo, accidentally fell into the water and drowned in the line of duty. Farmers in Hac Sa Wan suffered losses of approximately one million Macau patacas in property and livestock. In areas such as Mong Ha Hill and the New Reclamation Zone, many crops were also destroyed by the wind, resulting in significant losses. Dozens of wooden houses in Lin Ma Hang and the area near White Pigeon Nest Hill were destroyed, leaving over a hundred disaster victims. In the Ilha Verde wooden house area, a man was electrocuted and died outside his home at 8 p.m. on September 22. Numerous signs in the city were destroyed, and all the trees on Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro were broken or toppled. A century-old tree in Camoes Garden was uprooted, and a large tree on Rua do Campo collapsed. A six-foot-long boulder from the Ruins of St. Paul was blown down by the strong winds, embedding itself more than a foot deep into the ground. Many power lines in the city were destroyed, leaving one-third of the city's telephones out of service.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴貝姬 (1993年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Becky (English: Severe Tropical Storm Becky, International Number: 9316, Taiwan Number: 9317, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 22W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Yeyeng) was the 18th named storm of the 1993 Pacific typhoon season.

On September 14, 1993, a tropical disturbance formed in the Caroline Islands and intensified into a tropical depression the following day, designated as 22W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. It moved west or west-northwest at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour. Initially, Becky remained at tropical depression strength, with maximum winds only reaching gale force. However, after entering the waters of the Balintang Channel, it strengthened into a tropical storm and was named "Becky." At that time, its movement speed significantly increased, moving west-northwest at 30 kilometers per hour into the northern South China Sea. On September 17, Becky intensified into a severe tropical storm about 50 kilometers southwest of the Dongsha Islands and accelerated again, moving at 34 kilometers per hour toward the western coast of the Pearl River Estuary. On the same day, it made landfall in Chixi Town, Taishan City, Guangdong Province. Becky quickly weakened into a tropical storm about 200 kilometers northeast of Zhanjiang City. On September 18, it weakened into a tropical depression near Liuzhou City in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region and dissipated a few hours later in northern Ha Giang Province, Vietnam.

2. The data for Cheung Chau and Chek Lap Kok is incomplete. The Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9:30 am on September 16, when Becky was located about 660 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. Initially, the weather was generally clear with light winds. As Becky approached, the northeast wind strengthened, and squalls and thunderstorms began to affect Hong Kong. The Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 10:30 pm that night. Due to continued strengthening winds, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 2:50 am on September 17. According to the Observatory's tropical cyclone report, Becky was closest to Hong Kong at around 7 am, located about 110 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. In fact, some citizens and former Observatory staff pointed out that Becky was closest to Hong Kong at around 9 am, located about 90 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory, consistent with the Observatory's radar positioning and clear media reports at the time. However, the Observatory overturned the real-time positioning in the 1993 Tropical Cyclone Annual Report and did not acknowledge that Becky had reached hurricane-force winds, meaning it entered within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong at typhoon strength, meeting the conditions for issuing a higher signal. A former Observatory staff member pointed out that starting at around 8 am that morning, Cheung Chau experienced several hours of sustained hurricane-force winds. Before the Cheung Chau wind station went into maintenance mode, it recorded a maximum hourly average wind speed of 139 kilometers per hour, indicating that Becky had reached typhoon strength and brought hurricane-force winds to southwestern Hong Kong. This proves that the Observatory's classification of Becky as a severe tropical storm was a significant underestimation of its intensity, and not issuing the No. 10 Hurricane Signal was a serious mistake. At 8 am that morning, Shek Lau Wan and Wong Chuk Hang also recorded maximum hourly average wind speeds of 99 and 62 kilometers per hour, respectively, which were higher than the 87 and 54 kilometers per hour recorded during Super Typhoon Mangkhut in 2018. The Observatory headquarters also recorded a minimum instantaneous sea-level pressure of 997.3 hPa. As the wind shifted to the southeast, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal at 7:30 am. On that day, Hong Kong generally experienced gale to storm-force winds, with hurricane-force winds persisting in the western and southern areas, offshore waters, and highlands until Becky made landfall in western Guangdong. Showers decreased in the afternoon, and the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 3:10 pm, replacing the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, when Becky was located about 270 kilometers west of Hong Kong. All tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 5 pm. During Becky's impact on Hong Kong, 1 person died, and 130 people were injured. [2]

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 12:00 noon on September 16. On September 17, as Typhoon Becky approached with strong winds and heavy rain, the bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 3 at 12:30 a.m. and Typhoon Signal No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 6:30 a.m. Due to the continued strengthening of winds and the typhoon's closer approach to Macao, Typhoon Signal No. 9 was hoisted at 9:00 a.m. At the same time, the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge recorded the highest hourly average wind speed of 124 km/h, marking the first time hurricane-force sustained winds were recorded in the region. The main station at Mount Fortress recorded a maximum hourly wind speed of 73 km/h, while the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge recorded the highest gust of 166 km/h at 9:23 a.m., with the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure at 982.3 hPa. During this period, coinciding with astronomical high tide, low-lying areas such as the Inner Harbor, San Kio, and Ilha Verde experienced seawater flooding. The water level on Rua Cinco de Outubro even reached thigh height, and the Macao Water Supply Company's plant in Ilha Verde was affected by flooding, temporarily halting water supply. Numerous incidents of structural collapse occurred across the city: one side of the exterior wall and windows of the Global Hotel near Tap Seac Square were blown down by strong winds; a large tree fell in the parking area at Senado Square, crushing several cars; a large section of scaffolding collapsed near the CEM building on Rua do Almirante Sérgio; and many shanties along the Lin Ma Hang and Fai Chi Kei waterfronts were destroyed. The seawall near the old Outer Harbor Ferry Terminal on Avenida da Amizade was severely damaged by waves, and the terminal facilities were also affected. Subsequently, as Typhoon Becky moved away from Macao, the Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau replaced Typhoon Signal No. 8 Southwest Gale or Storm Signal at 10:30 a.m., then Typhoon Signal No. 3 at 1:30 p.m., and finally canceled all signals at 4:00 p.m. Typhoon Becky caused a total of 43 injuries in Macao, with 2 people seriously injured, and over 1,700 people had to take shelter at the Ilha Verde disaster relief center. Due to damage to facilities, hydrofoil ferry services between Hong Kong and Macao remained suspended as of 9:00 p.m. on September 17 and only fully resumed the following day. At the Transmac bus depot in Areia Preta, nearly 50 buses were completely flooded and paralyzed. After overnight emergency repairs, 30 buses were operational the next day.

When Becky struck Hong Kong and Macau, the meteorological departments of both regions underestimated its intensity. On the morning of September 17, 1993, Becky passed about 90 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong and approximately 45 kilometers south-southwest of Macau. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Macau Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau only issued the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal and the No. 9 Signal. However, hurricane-force winds persisted in the western and southern areas of Hong Kong, offshore waters, and highlands, while Macau experienced widespread hurricane-force winds. This not only met the criteria for the No. 10 Signal in both regions but also indicated that Becky was indeed a typhoon. This highlights the poor forecasting ability and accuracy of the meteorological departments in Hong Kong and Macau at the time regarding rapidly intensifying and accelerating tropical cyclones near the coast, as well as their low responsiveness to sudden situations. Although many years have passed since Becky struck Hong Kong and Macau, many residents and weather enthusiasts in both regions still point out in forums that the meteorological departments underestimated its intensity and question the rationale for not issuing higher signals, which continues to spark considerable debate.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴森拉克 (2014年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Sinlaku (English: Tropical Storm Sinlaku, International Number: 1421, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP212014, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Queenie) was the 21st named storm of the 2014 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Sinlaku" was provided by Micronesia and refers to a goddess in the Kosrae legend of Micronesia.

On November 23, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 2:00 PM on November 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area. At 1:00 PM on November 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 21W. At 4:30 PM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Bayabas, Surigao del Sur, Philippines. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. 

At 1:00 AM on November 27, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Jagna, Bohol, Philippines. At 2:00 AM, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. Without prior indication that "a tropical depression seems to be forming," the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression at 4:00 AM. At 6:00 AM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Argao, Cebu, Philippines. At 7:30 AM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Jimalalud, Negros Oriental, Philippines. At 10:30 PM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Taytay, Palawan, Philippines. 

At 8:00 AM on November 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sinlaku. At the same time, the Central Meteorological Observatory and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. The Central Weather Bureau also upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 10:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

At 8:00 AM on November 29, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 12:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11:00 PM, Sinlaku made landfall along the coast of Tuy Hoa, Phu Yen Province, Vietnam. 

At 2:00 AM on November 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 3:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 AM, the Central Meteorological Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Central Meteorological Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Central Meteorological Observatory ceased numbering it. At 4:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 10:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

Subsequently, in the best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, the intensity of Sinlaku was downgraded to a tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center revised down to 45 knots.

On the morning of November 26 at 7:30 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named the system that had entered its area of responsibility as Queenie, upgraded it to a tropical depression, and issued the first tropical cyclone advisory. [6] At 3:50 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued Signal No. 1. On the afternoon of November 28 at 4:30 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted Signal No. 1. At 7:00 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued the final tropical cyclone advisory for the system.

On the morning of November 28 at 10:00, the Central Meteorological Observatory issued a blue typhoon warning signal. On the morning of November 30 at 6:00, the Central Meteorological Observatory lifted the typhoon warning signal.

At 10:00 AM on November 28, the Hainan Meteorological Observatory issued a Level 4 typhoon emergency response. At 10:00 PM on November 29, the Hainan Meteorological Observatory lifted the Level 4 typhoon emergency response.

The Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center upgraded Sonca to a tropical depression and issued a notice at 8 a.m. on the 27th (local time 7 a.m.). It was upgraded to a tropical storm at 8 a.m. on the 28th, and it is expected that Sonca will make landfall along the coast from Phu Yen Province to Khanh Hoa Province on the afternoon of the 29th. At 11 p.m. on the 28th, Sonca's wind speed increased to 83 kilometers per hour, maintaining its intensity until the afternoon of the 29th. At 5 p.m. on the 29th, the Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center reported that Sonca's wind speed weakened to 70 kilometers per hour before making landfall, and it landed near Binh Dinh Province to Phu Yen Province at 11 p.m. with a wind speed of 65 kilometers per hour. The final warning for Sonca was issued at 8 a.m. on the 30th. 

Regarding the disaster situation, preliminary reports indicate no casualties. Dozens of houses were damaged, hundreds of trees were toppled, blocking some roads. Heavy rain flooded roads, and approximately 210 hectares of crops were submerged.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴麗莎 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Lisa was one of the tropical cyclones of the 1996 Pacific typhoon season. Lisa formed as a tropical depression in the northern part of the South China Sea, about 170 kilometers northwest of Dongsha, on the morning of August 6. It moved northeast, passing near Shantou City, Guangdong, that evening, then made landfall in Chencheng Town, Dongshan County, Zhangzhou City, Fujian. It weakened and dissipated inland on August 7. Lisa caused the deaths of over 90 people in mainland China.

Shortly after Lisa formed in the South China Sea, Hong Kong hoisted the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9 a.m. on August 6. At that time, it was generally cloudy with moderate northerly winds. As Lisa made landfall near Shantou that evening, Hong Kong gradually shifted to southwesterly winds, and the No. 1 Signal was taken down at 8:30 p.m. Lisa was closest to Hong Kong at around 10 a.m. on August 6, located approximately 160 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. The Observatory headquarters recorded the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure of 998.7 hPa at 6 p.m. that evening. During Lisa's impact, no major damage was reported in Hong Kong.

Article_Name: 1911年台灣南部颱風 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 1911 Taiwan Southern Typhoon (English: 1911 Formosa Typhoon), designated as Typhoon B051 by the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan, was a typhoon that struck southern Taiwan in August 1911. It caused severe impacts in the south, resulting in at least 290 deaths, 262 injuries, and the collapse and destruction of numerous houses, making it the most impactful typhoon during the early Japanese colonial period. In particular, about 80% of public infrastructure in Tainan Prefecture was damaged, including the collapse of the first-generation wooden West Market building and damage to the Five Concubines Shrine at Chihkan Tower, among other severe disasters. Early houses were mostly wooden structures, which suffered heavy losses in this typhoon, leading to subsequent public building reconstructions using more durable materials and methods such as brick and reinforced concrete. [Ref 1]:78-80

In late August 1911, a typhoon formed in the southern Pacific Ocean. This typhoon passed through the Philippines, Taiwan, and East Asia, causing significant damage. On August 21, meteorological observations from Guam and Yap Island indicated that a typhoon was gathering west of the Mariana Islands, moving west or west-northwest. By August 23, the typhoon began affecting the Philippines, with areas about 500 miles (805 kilometers) east of Luzon experiencing pressure drops and wind direction changes due to the typhoon's circulation. On the 24th, signs of the typhoon's arrival were observed on the small northern Philippine island of Basco. Early on the 26th, the pressure at the Basco weather station began to plummet, wind speeds increased, and rainfall was recorded. Between midnight and 7 a.m., the wind direction shifted from north-northeast to north, then to northwest-north. By 7 a.m. on the 26th, the pressure recording paper dropped below the lower limit of 715 mmHg (953.3 hPa). At 8 a.m., the wind direction shifted to northwest, but the rain stopped. At 8:20 a.m., Basco entered the typhoon's eye, the sky became calm, and the sun was visible. Sustained wind speeds dropped to level 4, though strong gusts still occurred. At 9 a.m., wind speeds suddenly increased, and the wind direction shifted from northwest to west-southwest. For several hours afterward, hurricane-force winds persisted, with the wind direction changing to southwest. By noon, the pressure recording paper showed a rise above 715 mmHg (953.3 hPa), and the pressure continued to rise as the wind weakened and the typhoon gradually moved away from Basco. Due to the pressure recording paper dropping below its limit, the lowest pressure recorded locally is unknown. However, based on the pressure curve, it is estimated that the lowest pressure recorded in Basco may have reached 690 mmHg (920 hPa) or lower.

After passing Basco, the typhoon approached Taiwan, with Hengchun being the first to be affected. The pressure continued to drop. At 10 p.m. on August 26, Hengchun recorded a minimum hourly pressure of 702.9 mmHg (937.1 hPa) and a maximum 10-minute sustained wind speed of 34.4 meters per second. According to the Central Weather Bureau's path map, the typhoon did not make landfall in Hengchun but passed very close to its western coastal waters before possibly making landfall in southwestern Taiwan. At 4:45 a.m. on the 27th, Tainan recorded a minimum pressure of 726.8 mmHg (969 hPa) and a maximum 10-minute sustained wind speed of 38.2 meters per second (or 54.5 meters per second according to another source [Reference 2]), the highest sustained wind speed ever recorded in Tainan. Tainan's 24-hour rainfall on the 27th was 384.9 mm, ranking fourth in daily accumulated rainfall [Reference 1:81]. During the typhoon, Tainan's total rainfall was 423.8 mm, while Hengchun's total rainfall was 515.4 mm. The chief scientist at the Hengchun Weather Station stated that the typhoon's intensity was extremely strong, with almost no houses left undamaged. Unfortunately, the anemometer cups were blown away, so the maximum wind speed could not be recorded. However, he estimated that the maximum wind speed could have reached 70 meters per second.

After passing Taiwan, the typhoon moved northwest-north and made landfall in China. By August 28, its remnants were located southwest of Shanghai, moving northwest. On August 29, it moved west of Shanghai and dissipated inland.

79 houses were completely destroyed, 78 were severely damaged, and 366 were slightly damaged. 28 livestock and 62 small animals died, and 30 small boats were damaged. The buildings, public schools, monasteries, and churches in the historic town of Busuanga suffered severe damage. The church was blown down, leaving only bare walls. One-third of the houses made of sturdy materials were destroyed. The total estimated loss exceeded 50,000 pesos.

The typhoon caused severe flooding in the southern and northern regions, resulting in at least 290 deaths, 262 injuries, 23,601 houses completely destroyed, and 22,686 partially destroyed. Since most early buildings were made of wood, the Taiwan Governor-General's Office adopted brick and reinforced concrete for public building reconstruction plans after the disaster. For example, Taipei City experienced flooding due to the typhoon, with areas like Dadaocheng severely affected by collapsed houses. The government took this opportunity to implement urban improvement and street house reconstruction plans, introducing architectural and facade style elements from European architecture for street rebuilding. In 1912, the following year, areas such as Beidou, Nantou, and Daxi, which were affected by the typhoon and flooding, also drafted urban improvement plans. Tainan suffered severe damage from the storm. Preliminary statistics on building damage in the Fucheng area showed that 86 private houses were completely or partially destroyed, with many others flooded, and six warehouses damaged. Regarding public buildings, 80% of Tainan's administrative offices were damaged, including the Tainan Office Affairs Room, General Affairs Section, and the east and west markets. Historical sites such as the Five Sons Shrine of Chihkan Tower were damaged, and decorative ceramic figures on the roof of the Liangguang Guild Hall were peeled off. In the Anping area, nearly 200 houses were completely or partially destroyed, with two injuries and two deaths, and four ships capsized in the harbor. At that time, the largest market in Fucheng, the West Market, saw its entire first-generation wooden structure destroyed. Therefore, when rebuilding the West Market in 1912, durability was considered, and the most advanced R.C. construction method in Taiwan at the time was used to build three buildings, with the central building being two stories high. The storm also caused the Zhuoshui River railway bridge to be washed away, disrupting the north-south railway line.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴蒲公英 (2010年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Mindulle (International designation: 1005; JTWC: WP062010) was the fifth tropical cyclone to form in the 2010 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Mindulle" was provided by North Korea, meaning the dandelion flower. In Taiwan, it is translated as "Minduli."

As early as August 17, a broad low-pressure area formed northeast of Luzon, Philippines. At that time, this low-pressure area remained stationary in the Luzon Strait due to the influence of the high-pressure ridges over the western Pacific and southeastern China. On August 18, the high-pressure area over southeastern China weakened, and sudden rain began to appear in southern China, causing the system to start moving westward. However, it was also affected by strong vertical wind shear in the northern South China Sea, showing no signs of developing into a tropical cyclone. Despite this, the low-pressure area did not dissipate; instead, its storm circle continued to expand. Later, on August 20, the vertical wind shear affecting the northern South China Sea began to weaken, and the Japan Meteorological Agency classified the system as a tropical disturbance after it entered the South China Sea. By midnight on August 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, as it had already moved to the northern South China Sea near the Dongsha Islands. 

At 8 a.m. on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded the system to a tropical depression, as it was located about 670 kilometers south of Hong Kong, within the 800-kilometer range of Hong Kong. However, due to the weak intensity of the tropical depression and its storm circle being concentrated in the central South China Sea, it did not bring immediate severe weather to Hong Kong, only causing slight swells in the southern waters of Hong Kong. Therefore, the Hong Kong Observatory did not issue the Standby Signal No. 1. The United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified the system as a tropical depression in the afternoon of August 22, designating it as the sixth tropical cyclone warning (06W) issued in the western Pacific. 

On the morning of August 23, the system intensified into a tropical storm, named Pabuk, and was expected to generally move toward the Gulf of Tonkin. That evening, the Hong Kong Observatory and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded Pabuk to a severe tropical storm. On August 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for the system. On the morning of August 25, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and a low-pressure area, respectively.
This time, the landfall of Tropical Storm Pugongying did not cause any casualties in Vietnam.
The China Meteorological Administration stated that tropical storm Pugongying would slightly pass through some outer cloud systems and brush past Hainan Island before making landfall in Vietnam.

On the evening of August 23, during the bus hostage incident in Manila, the Philippine police's assault operation was indirectly affected due to the influence of the outer cloud system of Tropical Storm Kompasu.

At 8 a.m. on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded this low-pressure area to a tropical depression. At that time, it was already about 670 kilometers south of Hong Kong, within the 800-kilometer range of Hong Kong. However, due to the tropical depression's relatively weak intensity and its storm circle being concentrated only in the central South China Sea, it did not bring immediate severe weather to Hong Kong, only causing slight swells in the southern waters of Hong Kong. Therefore, the Hong Kong Observatory did not issue a tropical cyclone warning signal. However, under the influence of its outer rainbands, Hong Kong experienced showers in the following one or two days.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴圓規 (2016年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Kompasu (International designation: 1611; Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP132016) was the 11th named tropical cyclone of the 2016 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kompasu" (コンパス) was used for the third time, previously in 2004 and 2010. This name, provided by Japan, refers to the constellation Circinus. Kompasu was the 7th tropical cyclone under the "monsoon gyre" and the 6th storm to pass close to Japan, classified as a typical tropical cyclone that transformed into an extratropical cyclone after passing Japan.

On August 16, 2016, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Guam. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W at 9 PM. On the evening of the 17th at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of the 18th at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," but the Japan Meteorological Agency subsequently declared it dissipated at 8 AM. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a tropical depression at 8 PM. On the morning of the 19th at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours from "low" directly to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it at 9:25 PM. On the 20th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm at 2 AM and assigned it the number 13W. Subsequently, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm at 8 AM, naming it Kompasu and assigning it the international number 1611. At 10 PM on the 21st, Kompasu made landfall in Kushiro City, Hokkaido. The Japan Meteorological Agency assessed it as having transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 2 AM the following day.
