Article_Name: 颱風姬羅莉亞 (1996年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gloria (English: Typhoon Gloria, International Number: 9608, Taiwan Number: 9607, Mainland China Number: 9607, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 09W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Gloring) was a tropical cyclone in the 1996 Pacific typhoon season.

Typhoon Gloria formed in the northern Philippines and moved northwest. It made landfall on Taiwan's Hengchun Peninsula around 4 PM on the 26th, then continued northwest, passing through Kaohsiung, Tainan, and Taichung. It exited into the sea at the Zhuoshui River estuary at 8 PM the same day, weakened in intensity, and moved northwest toward Fujian Province, China, making landfall in Shijing Town, Nan'an City, Quanzhou. Taiwan was affected by both Typhoon Gloria's circulation and the southwest airflow, resulting in several days of heavy rain in Hualien, Taitung, and Pingtung areas. Rail, road, and air transportation in the Taitung area were disrupted. A total of three people in Taiwan died due to the typhoon.

The Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 11:30 am on July 26, when Gloria was located about 700 kilometers east of Hong Kong. Hong Kong experienced westerly winds, with sunny and very hot weather during the day. Affected by Gloria's outer rainbands, there were occasional squally showers starting from the evening. As Gloria made landfall near Xiamen early the next morning, the No. 1 Signal was canceled at 6:45 am. The unstable southwesterly winds trailing Gloria affected the coast of Guangdong, bringing cloudy and rainy weather to Hong Kong in the following one to two days. Gloria was closest to Hong Kong at 2:00 pm on July 27, located about 280 kilometers northeast of Hong Kong. The Observatory headquarters recorded a minimum instantaneous sea-level pressure of 992.8 hPa at 4:00 pm on July 26.

Article_Name: 颱風利奧 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Leo (English: Typhoon Leo, International Number: 9902, Taiwan Number: 9905, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 05W) was the 5th named tropical cyclone of the 1999 Pacific typhoon season and the earliest tropical cyclone since World War II to prompt the Hong Kong Observatory to issue the No. 8 signal. Leo was once assessed by the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center to have a central wind speed of 205 kilometers per hour, with its path directly approaching Hong Kong. However, influenced by the northeast monsoon, Leo rapidly weakened and turned northeast when approaching Hong Kong, significantly reducing its threat to the region.

A tropical depression formed about 170 kilometers southwest of the Paracel Islands on April 28 and was named Leo. It moved northeast in the South China Sea and strengthened into a tropical storm that afternoon. Two days later, Leo further developed into a typhoon. It began to weaken on May 1, becoming a severe tropical storm and moving toward the coastal waters of Guangdong. Leo subsequently approached Hong Kong via a northwesterly path but shifted to an easterly path and moved away from Hong Kong later in the afternoon of May 2. Leo then weakened into a tropical depression and made landfall near Daya Bay that evening, eventually dissipating into a low-pressure area. [1] [2]

The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9:40 am on April 29, when Leo was located about 600 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. Leo intensified into a typhoon on April 30. Under the combined influence of Leo and the northeast monsoon, strong winds were recorded in offshore waters and high ground in Hong Kong, with rough seas. The Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 4:15 pm on April 30. Leo continued to approach Hong Kong over the next two days. On May 2, winds strengthened on Waglan Island, reaching gale force before noon. In the afternoon of May 2, Leo's low-level circulation center continued to be steered by low-level easterly winds, moving northwest-northward towards Hong Kong. However, its deep convection was sheared off by upper-level westerlies, weakening it into a tropical storm. As the Observatory predicted that Leo would maintain tropical storm intensity within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong, the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal was issued at 1:30 pm that afternoon. This was the earliest issuance of a No. 8 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal since 1946. Waglan Island recorded an hourly average wind speed of 90 kilometers per hour and a maximum gust of 130 kilometers per hour between 12 pm and 1 pm on May 2. Leo then passed about 45 kilometers southeast of the Hong Kong Observatory at 5 pm. However, Leo later turned northeast and moved inland, away from Hong Kong, and winds in Hong Kong subsided. During this period, three weather stations in Hong Kong recorded gale-force winds, while three other rural weather stations recorded strong winds. As Leo weakened into a tropical depression while passing east of Hong Kong, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 5:30 pm. By 8:45 pm, Leo had moved further away from Hong Kong and made landfall near Daya Bay, with all signals being canceled.

Under Leo's influence, there were six reports of fallen trees in Hong Kong. Three men were rescued after being in distress at sea, and a woman sustained minor injuries after slipping in Chai Wan. Slippery roads also caused 13 injuries in three traffic accidents. Most ferry services were temporarily suspended during Leo's impact. Two flights to Hong Kong and Bangkok were canceled. Shark prevention nets at five beaches on Hong Kong Island were severely damaged by large waves. Additionally, a cargo ship sank about 275 kilometers southeast of Waglan Island on April 30 due to rough seas. One crew member died, 13 went missing, and seven others were rescued from the rough waves.

Many citizens were dissatisfied with the Observatory's actions, as Leo quickly weakened into a tropical depression and changed direction shortly after the No. 8 Signal was issued, which was only in effect for four hours, causing public confusion. Due to terrain shielding and the rapid collapse of Leo's wind structure, winds in Hong Kong were relatively weak, leading some citizens to question whether the No. 8 Signal was necessary. Some believed the Observatory should have observed the weather conditions in Hong Kong from noon to dusk on May 2 before deciding whether to issue the No. 8 Signal, rather than hastily issuing it when a tropical storm entered within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong, causing public confusion. In this situation, the issuance of the No. 8 Signal led citizens to mistakenly believe that winds were generally weak during such signals, prompting them to go out, and some even chased the storm along the coast. Others believed that the Observatory's prediction that Leo would enter within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong as a tropical storm justified the issuance of the No. 8 Signal.

The Observatory later explained that all relevant factors are considered when deciding whether to issue higher signals, but public safety is the primary concern. Waglan Island recorded an hourly average wind speed of 90 kilometers per hour between 12 pm and 1 pm on May 2. The Hong Kong Underground Observatory pointed out that this indicated gale-force winds had affected southern offshore areas and showed signs of possibly extending to more areas. It was not feasible for the Observatory to wait several more hours to decide whether to issue the No. 8 Signal, and from the perspective of ensuring public safety, the issuance of the No. 8 Signal was necessary.

Article_Name: 颱風柏美娜 (1954年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Pamela (English: Typhoon Pamela, International Number: 5419, Taiwan Number: 5416, Mainland China Number: 5427, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 16W) was the 19th named tropical cyclone of the 1954 Pacific typhoon season. Pamela is a female name and was the second storm in history to cause the Hong Kong Observatory to hoist the No. 9 signal in November.

On October 27, 1954, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Pamela. Initially, Pamela moved mainly northwestward. On October 28, Pamela shifted to a more westerly direction. At 8 p.m. on October 29, Pamela changed course to move northwestward. At 8 a.m. on October 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8 a.m. on October 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2 p.m. on November 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 8 p.m., Pamela reached its peak intensity with one-minute sustained winds near the center reaching 150 knots (280 km/h), and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon. At 8 p.m. on November 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2 a.m. on November 4, Pamela passed through the Bashi Channel and entered the South China Sea. At 8 a.m. on November 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 2 a.m. on November 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 p.m., Pamela made landfall along the coastal areas of Taishan County, Jiangmen City, Guangdong Province, China, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8 a.m. on November 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on November 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning.
When Parmela swept across Taiwan, the minimum pressure was 940 hPa, the maximum wind speed at the center reached 220 km/h, and 231.6 mm of rainfall was recorded.

Palma entered the South China Sea on November 5, and the Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 11:30 a.m. In the afternoon, Palma continued to move west-northwest, getting closer to Hong Kong, and the Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 7 signal at 8:20 p.m. The next day, as the Observatory predicted that Palma would come very close to Hong Kong and might bring hurricane-force winds, the Observatory hoisted the No. 9 signal at 10:15 a.m. This was the second typhoon to cause the Observatory to hoist the No. 9 signal in November and the only typhoon after World War II to lead to the hoisting of the No. 9 signal in November. Palma passed 55 kilometers southwest of the Observatory headquarters. At 3 p.m., the Royal Hong Kong Observatory replaced the No. 9 signal with the No. 8 signal. As Palma moved away, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 5 p.m. The Observatory headquarters recorded strong winds for four hours, with the highest hourly average wind speed being 87 kilometers per hour from the east. During Palma's impact on Hong Kong, the maximum storm surge and highest water level recorded at North Point and Quarry Bay were 1.16 meters and 2.83 meters, respectively. Additionally, during Palma's impact, the Royal Hong Kong Observatory recorded 93.5 millimeters of rainfall on November 6, resulting in more than double the normal rainfall for November 1954.
Affected by Parmela, Macau recorded a minimum pressure of 980 hPa, a maximum sustained wind speed of 99 km/h, and a daily rainfall of 41.5 mm.
On November 6, Palma made landfall along the coast of Taishan County, Jiangmen City, Guangdong Province, China, but no recorded impact on the area was noted.

Article_Name: 颱風法茜 (2014年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Faxai (English: Typhoon Faxai, international designation: 1403, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP032014) was the third named tropical cyclone of the 2014 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Faxai" was provided by Laos and is one of the local female names. Faxai was the first typhoon-level tropical cyclone to form in March since Typhoon Mitag in 2002.

On the evening of February 17, a slow-moving tropical disturbance was detected near Pohnpei in the Federated States of Micronesia close to the equator and was designated as "93W." Due to strong vertical wind shear in the surrounding area, the storm developed slowly until the system moved into a region with low vertical wind shear, allowing it to consolidate and develop. On February 26, the tropical disturbance was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Japan Meteorological Agency, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On February 28, the tropical depression was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and was designated as "03W." Hours later, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Faxai." Subsequently, Faxai began to intensify rapidly, being upgraded to a severe tropical storm and then a typhoon within just two days from March 3 to 4. The system transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on March 6. After Faxai transitioned into an extratropical cyclone, its remnants were absorbed by another extratropical system on March 8 in an area several thousand kilometers southeast of Japan.

Faxi hardly approached land from its formation to its end, only passing over areas such as the sea east of Guam, the Mariana Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Minami-Tori-shima, and did not cause significant impact.

Article_Name: 2000年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2000 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during the year 2000. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December.  

This article is limited to the waters of the Pacific Ocean and the South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2000 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Western Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency's Typhoon Center, with international identification numbers starting with 00xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in the region identification numbers ending with the letter W.  

For tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) assigns them a Philippine name for local warning purposes. Additionally, since China, Hong Kong, and Macau use the same translation for storm names, while Taiwan's translations may differ, the same storm may have two different Chinese names. Starting from the 2020s, Taiwan and China-Hong Kong-Macau have collaborated to confirm the Chinese names of storms. Sometimes, there may also be two different English names (the international name and the Philippine name).  

The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its strongest form during its existence.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named
Whole_Text.content: The 2000 Pacific typhoon season produced a total of 23 tropical cyclones.

PAGASA: Asiang On May 4 at 18:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the sea northeast of Palau. It moved in a northwest direction. On May 7 at 00:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm and was named Davi, becoming the first tropical cyclone in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea to receive a name from the new storm naming list effective January 1, 2000. At 06:00 UTC, Davi intensified into a severe tropical storm. On May 8 at 00:00 UTC, Davi turned northeast and developed into a typhoon. On May 9 at 06:00 UTC, Davi reached its peak with maximum sustained winds of 110 knots. It continued moving northeast and gradually weakened. After passing near Iwo Jima and the Bonin Islands, Davi weakened into a severe tropical storm at 12:00 UTC on May 11. On May 12 at 06:00 UTC, Davi weakened into a tropical storm. At 12:00 UTC, Davi transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. By May 17 at 00:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Biring On May 17 at 6:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the sea west of Luzon. The tropical depression moved northeastward. On May 19 at 0:00 UTC, it intensified into a tropical storm and was named Longwang. Longwang continued moving northeastward, maintaining tropical storm intensity. On May 20 at 6:00 UTC, Longwang transitioned into an extratropical cyclone south of Japan. The cyclone continued moving northeastward, and on May 24 at 6:00 UTC, it crossed the International Date Line.

PAGASA: At 6:00 UTC on July 2, a tropical depression formed over the sea east of the Philippines. The tropical depression moved northward. At 6:00 UTC on July 3, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm and was named "Hagibis." By 12:00 UTC, Hagibis strengthened into a severe tropical storm. At 18:00 UTC, Hagibis intensified into a typhoon southwest of Okinotorishima. At 0:00 UTC on July 5, Hagibis turned northeastward west of Okinotorishima and reached its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of 85 knots. On July 7, its center exhibited a double eyewall structure. It moved rapidly at a speed of 50 kilometers per hour, and after skimming the eastern coast of Japan on July 8, at 0:00 UTC, Hagibis weakened into a severe tropical storm. By 21:00 UTC, Hagibis transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 12:00 UTC on July 10, it completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Edeng (Talim) is the first typhoon of the season to form in the South China Sea. At 12:00 UTC on July 3, a tropical depression formed over the waters west of Luzon Island in the Philippines, moving northward. At 18:00 UTC on July 5, it slowly moved northwest of Luzon Island and quickly developed into a tropical storm, named Talim. At 00:00 UTC on July 6, Talim intensified into a severe tropical storm. By 12:00 UTC, Talim further strengthened into a typhoon. At 00:00 UTC on July 7, Talim reached its peak, with a double eyewall structure and maximum sustained winds of 75 knots. After reaching its peak, it began moving northeast. At 12:00 UTC on July 8, Talim weakened into a severe tropical storm. At 01:00 UTC on July 9, Talim made landfall near Chenggong Township, Taitung County, Taiwan. By 06:00 UTC, Talim exited near Anle District, Keelung City. At 09:00 UTC, Talim further weakened into a tropical storm. After crossing Taiwan, Talim continued moving north and made a second landfall near Shiqiaotou Town, Wenling City, Taizhou, Zhejiang Province, on July 10. Talim passed through Shanghai and then entered the Yellow Sea. By 18:00 UTC, Talim transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 06:00 UTC on July 12, it completely dissipated.

At 00:00 UTC on July 17, a tropical depression formed over the northern waters of the Northern Mariana Islands. Initially moving northwest, it later turned northward. At 00:00 UTC on July 19, the tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm near the Ogasawara Islands and was named Talim. Talim maintained its intensity as a tropical storm and continued moving northward. At 18:00 UTC on July 21, Talim weakened into a tropical depression approximately 200 kilometers southeast of Japan. By 12:00 UTC on July 23, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Huaning On July 24 at 0:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the sea east of Luzon. It moved northward, then turned to move east-northeast. On July 25 at 18:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm near Okinawa and was named Bolaven. On July 26, it passed south of Okinawa. From July 26 to 28, Bolaven performed a counterclockwise looping motion and maintained tropical storm intensity over the waters east of Okinawa. Later, Bolaven's movement slowed down. On July 29 at 6:00 UTC, Bolaven intensified into a severe tropical storm. At 12:00 UTC, Bolaven weakened back into a tropical storm. Bolaven moved further north to Amami Oshima. On July 31 at 0:00 UTC, Bolaven weakened into a tropical depression east of Busan, South Korea. At 6:00 UTC, Bolaven transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. By August 2 at 6:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

At 18:00 UTC on July 27, a tropical depression formed over the eastern waters of the Marshall Islands. The tropical depression moved in a northwest-northward direction. At 18:00 UTC on July 28, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm east of the Marshall Islands and was named Pear. Shortly after, Pear turned northward and maintained tropical storm intensity for one day. At 18:00 UTC on July 29, Pear weakened into a tropical depression east of Wake Island. By 12:00 UTC on July 30, it had completely dissipated.

At 18:00 UTC on July 31, a tropical depression formed over the sea south of Minamitorishima, moving westward. At 12:00 UTC on August 1, the tropical depression rapidly intensified into a tropical storm and was named Khanun. At 00:00 UTC on August 2, Khanun strengthened into a typhoon. Moving west-northwest, at 00:00 UTC on August 3, Khanun reached its peak over the northern Mariana Islands, with a very round and large eye approximately 100 kilometers in diameter and a maximum sustained wind speed of 85 knots. Khanun maintained typhoon strength while moving westward for several days and, at 03:00 UTC on August 6, passed north of Kitadaitōjima. Khanun then shifted to a northwestward movement. In the early hours of August 8, Khanun passed north of Okinawa, entered the East China Sea, and began to weaken. On August 10, it made landfall near Shipu Town, Xiangshan County, Ningbo City, Zhejiang Province. At 06:00 UTC, Khanun weakened into a severe tropical storm and continued to move inland. At 12:00 UTC, Khanun weakened into a tropical storm. At 18:00 UTC, Khanun weakened into a tropical depression. By 18:00 on August 12, it had completely dissipated.

At 00:00 UTC on August 9, a tropical depression formed over the sea west of Guam. Initially moving westward, it later turned northward. At 18:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm and was named Lan. Lan accelerated northward, and at 06:00 UTC on August 11, it strengthened into a severe tropical storm southwest of the Ogasawara Islands. At 12:00 UTC on August 12, Lan slowed down south of Japan and turned to move east-northeast. Lan continued moving east-northeast at the intensity of a severe tropical storm for three days. At 18:00 UTC on August 15, Lan intensified into a typhoon over the waters east of Japan, with maximum sustained winds of 65 knots. At 12:00 UTC on August 16, Lan weakened into a severe tropical storm. At 12:00 UTC on August 17, Lan weakened into a tropical storm. Shortly after, Lan turned northward. At 12:00 UTC on August 18, Lan transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. By 12:00 UTC on August 21, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: On August 18 at 12:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the northwest sea area of Yap Island. Guided by the subtropical ridge, it moved steadily northwestward. On August 19 at 06:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm and was named Bilis. At 18:00 UTC, Bilis strengthened into a severe tropical storm. On August 20 at 12:00 UTC, Bilis intensified into a typhoon northeast of Luzon Island in the Philippines, with maximum sustained winds of 110 kt. Subsequently, Bilis turned west-northwestward, heading directly toward Taiwan, while steadily intensifying under favorable atmospheric conditions. At 14:30 UTC on August 22 (local time 22:30), Bilis made landfall in Chenggong Township, Taitung County, Taiwan. Approximately four and a half hours later, it entered the Taiwan Strait near Yunlin County. Bilis was not severely damaged by Taiwan's Central Mountain Range and remained at typhoon strength upon re-entering the sea. Around 04:00 UTC on August 23 (local noon), Bilis made its second landfall near Dongshi Town, Jinjiang City, Quanzhou, Fujian Province. Subsequently, Bilis continued to move inland and rapidly weakened. At 06:00 UTC, Bilis weakened into a tropical storm. By 12:00 UTC, it had further weakened into a tropical depression. It then gradually turned north-northeastward under the influence of a westerly trough. At 18:00 UTC on August 25, Bilis transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the Yellow Sea. On August 27 at 06:00 UTC, Bilis made landfall in the Yonan County area of Hwanghae Province, North Korea. By 12:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

At 12:00 UTC on August 19, a tropical depression formed north of the Nansha Islands. Initially moving westward, it later shifted to a northwestward direction. At 12:00 UTC on August 21, the tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm 200 kilometers east of Vietnam and was named Kammuri. At 06:00 UTC on August 22, Kammuri made landfall near Son Tra District, Da Nang City, Vietnam. By 12:00 UTC, Kammuri weakened into a tropical depression. At 00:00 UTC on August 24, it completely dissipated.

PAGASA: On August 24 at 18:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the sea northwest of Yap Island. Initially moving westward, it later shifted to a northward direction. On August 26 at 18:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm near Okinotorishima and was named Pabian, changing its course to move northwestward. On August 27 at 18:00 UTC, Pabian moved northwestward and strengthened into a severe tropical storm. On August 28 at 12:00 UTC, Pabian shifted to a northward path. On August 29, Pabian accelerated northward and passed near Okinawa Island. On August 30 at 06:00 UTC, Pabian intensified into a typhoon in the East China Sea. At 12:00 UTC, Pabian reached its peak with maximum sustained winds of 70 knots. Shortly after, Pabian entered the Yellow Sea. On the evening of August 31, Pabian made landfall in Ongjin County, Hwanghae Province, North Korea, and weakened into a severe tropical storm. On September 1 at 06:00 UTC, Pabian weakened into a tropical storm. At 12:00 UTC, Pabian transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. By September 4 at 12:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

At 6:00 UTC on August 27, a tropical depression formed over the sea south of Hong Kong. The tropical depression took a southward path and strengthened into a tropical storm at 12:00 UTC, being named Maria. Maria maintained tropical storm intensity for two days, continuing to move southward in the northern part of the South China Sea. 500 kilometers west of Luzon, Maria stopped moving southward and became almost stationary. At 0:00 UTC on August 30, Maria turned clockwise. Shortly after, Maria moved northward. In the early morning of September 1, Maria made landfall near Ebu Town, Haifeng County, Shanwei City, Guangdong Province, China. At 6:00 UTC, Maria weakened into a tropical depression. By 0:00 UTC on September 3, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: On August 31 at 18:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the eastern waters of the Mariana Islands. Initially moving northward, it later shifted to a westward direction. The tropical depression followed a westward path and strengthened into a tropical storm at 12:00 UTC on September 2, receiving the name Saomai. By 12:00 UTC on September 3, Saomai intensified into a severe tropical storm. At 06:00 UTC on September 4, Saomai became a typhoon east of Saipan. At 06:00 UTC on September 5, Saomai turned southward and weakened into a severe tropical storm. At 06:00 UTC on September 6, Saomai shifted from a westward to a northwestward movement. Over the following days, Saomai maintained the intensity of a severe tropical storm and steadily moved northwestward. At 00:00 UTC on September 9, Saomai re-intensified into a typhoon, with a small but very distinct eye visible on satellite imagery. At 12:00 UTC on September 10, Saomai reached its peak south of the Daito Islands, with maximum sustained winds of 95 knots. At 10:00 UTC on September 12, Saomai made landfall in Ginoza Village, Kunigami District, Okinawa Prefecture. After entering the East China Sea, Saomai shifted to a northeastward movement. Later, Saomai turned north-northward and accelerated its movement. At 12:00 UTC on September 15, Saomai weakened into a severe tropical storm. At 20:00 UTC, Saomai made landfall near Goseong County, South Gyeongsang Province, South Korea. At 06:00 UTC on September 16, Saomai transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in northeastern North Korea. By 06:00 UTC on September 19, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Ningning On September 4 at 6:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the waters east of Luzon. Initially moving westward, it later made a counterclockwise turn on September 6, shifting to a west-northwest direction. At 18:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm south of the Daito Islands and was named "Ningning." On September 8, Ningning passed south of Okinawa Island. On September 9, Ningning made another counterclockwise turn, moving southward and crossing Iriomote Island. From the evening of September 9 to the morning of September 10, Ningning maintained tropical storm intensity as it passed east of Taiwan. At 23:00 UTC on September 10, Ningning made landfall near Santa Ana, Cagayan. At 0:00 UTC on September 11, Ningning weakened into a tropical depression. By 18:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Maring, on September 4 at 6:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the western sea of Luzon. Initially almost stationary, on September 5 at 12:00 UTC, the tropical depression made a counterclockwise turn in the South China Sea and began moving westward. On September 6 at 0:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm and was named Wukong. At 12:00 UTC, Wukong strengthened into a severe tropical storm. On September 7 at 18:00 UTC, Wukong intensified into a typhoon. On September 8 at 6:00 UTC, Wukong reached its peak with maximum sustained winds of 75 knots. On September 9, Wukong passed near Sanya City, Hainan Province. At 6:00 UTC, Wukong weakened into a severe tropical storm. On September 10 at 4:00 UTC, Wukong made landfall near Ky Anh County, Ha Tinh Province, Vietnam. At 6:00 UTC, Wukong weakened into a tropical storm. At 12:00 UTC, Wukong weakened into a tropical depression in northeastern Thailand. On September 11 at 0:00 UTC, it completely dissipated.

At 6:00 UTC on September 14, a tropical depression formed over the sea west of Iwo Jima. The tropical depression moved northward, and at 3:00 UTC on September 15, it strengthened into a tropical storm south of Iwo Jima and was named Koinu. Koinu turned northward, and at 12:00 UTC on September 16, it passed near the Ogasawara Islands. At 0:00 UTC on September 17, Koinu strengthened into a severe tropical storm south of Japan and turned to move north-northeast. At 6:00 UTC on September 18, Koinu transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the Kuril Islands. At 12:00 UTC on September 20, the cyclone crossed the International Date Line.

At 6:00 UTC on September 17, a tropical depression formed over the northeastern waters of the Marshall Islands. The tropical depression moved northwestward, and at 12:00 UTC on September 18, it intensified into a tropical storm and was named Sanba. At 0:00 UTC on September 19, Sanba strengthened into a severe tropical storm. By 12:00 UTC, Sanba intensified into a typhoon in nearby waters. Sanba further strengthened and passed over the northeastern part of Wake Island. At 12:00 UTC on September 21, Sanba reached its peak south of Wake Island, with maximum sustained winds of 95 knots. Sanba turned northeastward, and from September 22 to 23, it accelerated and gradually weakened. At 18:00 UTC on September 24, Sanba transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the northwestern waters of Midway Atoll. At 18:00 UTC on September 25, the cyclone crossed the International Date Line.

PAGASA: At 0:00 UTC on October 21, a tropical depression formed over the southern waters of the Mariana Islands. The tropical depression moved northwestward, and at 0:00 UTC on October 22, it intensified into a tropical storm over the northeastern waters of Okinotorishima and was named "Mokha." At 12:00 UTC on October 23, Mokha intensified into a severe tropical storm. Mokha continued moving northwestward, and at 12:00 UTC on October 24, it intensified into a typhoon over the southern waters of Okinawa Island. Shortly after, Mokha reached its peak with maximum sustained winds of 70 knots. Mokha changed its path from northwestward to northward. At 12:00 UTC on October 25, Mokha weakened into a severe tropical storm. From October 26 to 28, Mokha made a loop in the waters near Okinawa Island. At 12:00 UTC on October 26, Mokha weakened into a tropical storm. At 0:00 UTC on October 27, Mokha weakened into a tropical depression. At 12:00 UTC on October 28, it completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Reming On October 24 at 18:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the sea southeast of Yap Island. The tropical depression gradually developed and moved in a west-northwest direction. On October 26 at 06:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm over the sea east of the Philippines and was named Xangsane. Xangsane moved in a west-northwest direction, and at 00:00 UTC on October 27, it intensified into a severe tropical storm. At 21:00 UTC, Xangsane made landfall along the coast of Sagñay, Camarines Sur, in the southern Philippines. At 12:00 UTC on October 28, Xangsane weakened into a tropical storm. On the morning of October 29, after crossing Luzon Island, Xangsane entered the South China Sea. At 06:00 UTC, Xangsane re-intensified into a severe tropical storm. Initially, Xangsane slowed down and moved westward, later becoming almost stationary. At 18:00 UTC, Xangsane began to move in a north-northeast direction. At 00:00 UTC on October 30, Xangsane intensified into a typhoon, and shortly afterward, it reached its peak west of Luzon Island, with maximum sustained winds of 75 knots. Over the next two days, Xangsane maintained typhoon strength and continued moving in a north-northeast direction. At 00:00 UTC on November 1, Xangsane weakened into a severe tropical storm. Later that morning, Xangsane passed east of Taiwan and entered the East China Sea. Xangsane shifted to an east-northeast direction. At 12:00 UTC, Xangsane transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. By 12:00 UTC on November 2, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Seniang On October 30 at 18:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the northern waters of Palau. This tropical depression followed a process almost identical to that of Xangsane. On November 1 at 00:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm northeast of Mindanao and was named Bebinca. At 18:00 UTC, Bebinca intensified into a severe tropical storm southeast of Luzon. On November 2 at 18:00 UTC, Bebinca made landfall in Real, Quezon, Philippines, and then began to weaken. On November 3 at 00:00 UTC, Bebinca weakened into a tropical storm over western Luzon. After entering the South China Sea, Bebinca re-intensified into a severe tropical storm on November 4 at 00:00 UTC. On November 5, Bebinca shifted to a northward movement. On November 6, Bebinca turned westward and gradually weakened in intensity. At 12:00 UTC, Bebinca weakened into a tropical storm. On November 7 at 00:00 UTC, Bebinca weakened into a tropical depression southeast of Hong Kong. By November 8 at 00:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Toyang On November 27 at 18:00 UTC, a tropical depression formed over the western sea area of Palau. The tropical depression moved westward. On November 28 at 12:00 UTC, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm in nearby waters and was named Wukong. Later, Wukong turned to move in a west-northwest direction. On November 30 at 18:00 UTC, Wukong weakened into a tropical depression in Salcedo, Eastern Samar, Philippines. By December 2 at 06:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Welpring Sully formed in late December, surpassing the year's typhoon season for the first time in 15 years. At 18:00 UTC on December 28, 2000, a tropical depression formed over the sea east of Mindanao. Initially moving north, the tropical depression turned west the next day, heading toward the Philippines. On its westward path, at 00:00 UTC on December 30, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm 200 kilometers east of Leyte Island and was named Sully. Sully changed its path to move northeast, and at 18:00 UTC on December 31, Sully intensified into a severe tropical storm. Sully maintained the intensity of a severe tropical storm, moving east-northeast. At 00:00 UTC on January 2, Sully shifted to a north-northeast direction near Okinotorishima. At 06:00 UTC, Sully weakened into a tropical storm. At 18:00 UTC, Sully re-intensified into a severe tropical storm. On January 3, Sully turned to move northeast and began rapid development. At 06:00 UTC, Sully intensified into a typhoon. At 12:00 UTC, Sully reached its peak with maximum sustained winds of 80 knots. At 06:00 UTC on January 4, Sully weakened into a severe tropical storm. At 12:00 UTC, Sully weakened into a tropical storm. At 18:00 UTC, Sully weakened into a tropical depression. At 00:00 UTC on January 5, it completely dissipated.

In addition to the tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones considered tropical storms by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The information on those tropical cyclones is listed below.

PAGASA: Consing formed on May 21, approximately 330 kilometers southeast of Dongsha Island. It took a northeast path crossing the Balintang and Bashi Channels and became an extratropical cyclone the following day.

On the evening of June 18, it rapidly formed when it was located about 35 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory. The small tropical depression moved northward, passing between Lantau Island and Hong Kong Island, making landfall near Tsuen Wan after crossing Tsing Yi Island. The spiral rainbands of the tropical depression brought heavy rain and strong winds to Hong Kong, with local strong winds recorded. After landfall, the tropical depression entered Shenzhen and subsequently dissipated inland in Guangdong. This tropical depression was only upgraded by the Hong Kong Observatory. The JTWC had assessed the possibility of this disturbance developing into a tropical depression as "Fair."
PAGASA: Gloring

A low-pressure area developed into a tropical depression approximately 220 kilometers east of the Xisha Islands on the afternoon of July 15. It moved northwest and made landfall in the eastern part of Hainan Island on the evening of July 16, dissipating near Haikou.
CPHC: Wene (Vigne)

A low-pressure area developed into a tropical depression on the morning of September 29, approximately 840 kilometers northwest by north of Wake Island. It moved slowly northeastward over the Pacific and weakened into a low-pressure area on the evening of September 30.

A low-pressure area formed into a tropical depression about 500 kilometers east of Ho Chi Minh City on October 7. The tropical depression initially moved slowly, then advanced west-northwest on October 9. In the following three days, it moved northeast. After passing near the Paracel Islands, it turned westward on October 13 and weakened into a low-pressure area the next day.
A tropical depression formed approximately 310 kilometers southwest of Okinawa Island on November 9. It moved northeast and transformed into an extratropical cyclone near Okinawa Island that evening.

PAGASA: Ulpiang, a low-pressure area, developed into a tropical depression on December 5, approximately 250 kilometers southwest of the Spratly Islands. The tropical depression moved westward, passing about 150 kilometers south of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on December 7, and then weakened into a low-pressure area.

This year's Pacific typhoon season has 23 named tropical cyclones. Below is a list of all cyclones at tropical depression level or above. For severe tropical storms or below, a 10-minute average wind speed is used, while for typhoon-level cyclones, a 1-minute average wind speed is used and categorized into five levels.

Tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency's Tokyo Typhoon Center. When a tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization's Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting 10 names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. Unused names for this year are shown in gray, and names already used this year are shown in bold.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) uses its own naming system for naming tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. Unlike the Japan Meteorological Agency, PAGASA assigns names to tropical cyclones as long as they indirectly affect the Philippines or surrounding countries, regardless of their intensity. The list of names is reused every four years, so this year's list is the same as the one used in the 1996 Pacific typhoon season. Unused names for this year are shown in gray, while names already used this year are in bold.

Article_Name: 2019年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2019 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2019. Although there is no designated formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2019 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (i.e., international names) and are assigned international numbers starting with 19xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). Additionally, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan may differ. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak state during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast by the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2019 flood season is expected to be inactive, with the number of impacts and landfalls likely to be lower than usual. The possibility of individual stronger typhoons cannot be ruled out, but the likelihood of a typhoon of 17 or above, similar to Typhoon Rammasun in 2014, making landfall in Hainan is low.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that the impact of typhoons on Shenzhen in 2019 will be lighter than in 2018, overall close to a normal year. It is expected that 6-7 typhoons will enter Shenzhen's 500-kilometer defense zone in 2019 (compared to 8 in 2018), of which 3-4 will affect Shenzhen. The first typhoon to enter the defense zone is expected in June, with the main landing point west of the Pearl River Estuary. The probability of typhoons in the South China Sea affecting the area is relatively high, and their paths are complex and variable.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that 4 to 7 typhoons will enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong in 2019, which is considered normal. The number of tropical cyclones developing in April and May during El Niño events is relatively low, and their formation points are generally located further east in the northwest Pacific. Therefore, tropical cyclones usually do not affect Hong Kong before June.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that 4 to 6 typhoons will enter within 800 kilometers of Macao in 2019, some of which may reach the level of severe typhoon or above. It is expected that the first tropical cyclone to affect Macao will occur in mid-June or later, and the entire typhoon season will end around early October. It is also predicted that the El Niño phenomenon will persist until summer.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 28, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be normal to slightly above average, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan expected to be within the normal range of about 3 to 5.

At the end of 2018, a tropical depression developed in the southern South China Sea, which intensified into a tropical storm named Pabuk on New Year's Day 2019, becoming the earliest recorded tropical cyclone in the Northwest Pacific to strengthen into a tropical storm. In the following days, Pabuk moved westward into the Gulf of Thailand, crossing the 100°E longitude and leaving the Japan Meteorological Agency's area of responsibility. Meanwhile, a tropical disturbance formed east of the Gilbert Islands, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center indicated that the system intensified into a tropical depression on January 4, with expectations of further strengthening. However, the system failed to intensify further, and its low-level circulation center became difficult to identify, prompting the Joint Typhoon Warning Center to issue its final advisory. The remnants of the system generally moved westward, re-intensifying into a tropical depression east of the Philippines in mid to late January, before dissipating under the combined effects of vertical wind shear and cold air. In mid to late February, Wutip formed, moved westward, and steadily intensified, becoming the season's first typhoon on February 21. By the evening of February 23, it moved northwestward and rapidly intensified into a super typhoon. Wutip weakened on February 24 but re-intensified on the 25th, becoming the strongest February typhoon on record, reaching Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. Wutip gradually weakened and dissipated starting February 26. On March 14, a tropical depression formed near the Marshall Islands, weakened into a low-pressure area after making landfall in Mindanao, Philippines, and no tropical cyclones formed in April. In May, three tropical depressions formed but did not develop into tropical storms. In June, four tropical cyclones formed, one of which was upgraded to Tropical Storm Sepat on the 27th, with two systems absorbed by Sepat, which later transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on the 28th, while Tropical Depression 04W moved near Taiwan. The first half of 2019 saw generally quiet tropical cyclone activity, with only three cyclones reaching tropical storm strength or higher. Entering July, typhoon formation became active. A total of five tropical cyclones formed in July: Mun, Danas, one tropical depression, Nari, and Wipha. On the afternoon of July 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area in the South China Sea to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. By the evening of the next day, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named "Mun." At 12:45 a.m. on July 3, China's National Meteorological Center announced that Mun made landfall in Hele Town, Wanning City, Hainan Province. At 9 a.m. on July 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area east of the Philippines to a tropical depression. On the afternoon of July 16, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named "Danas." As Danas passed through Luzon, its circulation was affected by Luzon's terrain, splitting into two, with its low-level circulation center continuing to move northward while deep convection moved into the South China Sea. During the day, Danas slowly moved northward, merging with the tropical disturbance 90W to the east in the evening, successfully repairing its exposed circulation center. On July 18, Danas continued to move steadily northward, making landfall in Buan County, North Jeolla Province, on July 20. At 9 p.m. on the 21st, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Danas had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On July 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported the formation of a tropical depression in the Northwest Pacific south of Japan. Shortly after, a gale warning was issued, and two days later, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named "Nari." At 7 a.m. on July 27, Nari made landfall in southern Mie Prefecture, Japan. At 9 a.m. on July 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area in the central South China Sea to a tropical depression. The following morning, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named "Wipha." At 1:50 a.m. on August 1, Wipha made landfall in Wenchang City, Hainan Province, and at 5:40 p.m., it made a second landfall in Potou District, Zhanjiang City, Guangdong Province. Wipha prompted the issuance of tropical cyclone warning signal No. 8 in both Hong Kong and Macau.

Whole_Text.content: On December 28, 2018, a low-pressure area formed in the southern South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 97W. On December 30, the system absorbed the remnants of tropical depression 35W located to its northeast. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium" at 2 a.m. and further upgraded it to "high" the next day, issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 p.m. on the 31st, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 36W. The Japan Meteorological Agency followed suit at 3:15 p.m., upgrading it to a tropical depression and issuing a gale warning. On January 1, 2019, at 2:55 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 1901, and named it Pabuk. On the afternoon of January 4, the Thai Meteorological Department announced that Pabuk made landfall in Nakhon Si Thammarat Province. In the evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Pabuk had exited its area of responsibility and entered the North Indian Ocean, stating that subsequent reports would be issued by the India Meteorological Department. On the afternoon of January 6, the India Meteorological Department downgraded it to a deep depression.

PAGASA: Betty  
On February 14, a low-pressure area formed near the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 92W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center initially gave it a "low" development rating at 1:30 PM on February 16 and upgraded the rating to "medium" at 10:30 PM the following day. On February 18 at 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. That evening at 8:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan first upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on February 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 5:00 PM that same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 02W.  

At 2:00 AM on February 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1902, and named it "Butterfly." The Joint Typhoon Warning Center followed suit three hours later. At 6:00 PM that day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM on February 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM on February 23, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon.  

At 3:00 PM on February 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and it dissipated on the evening of March 2. In the post-analysis report, the Japan Meteorological Agency revised Butterfly's first peak intensity to 195 km/h with a pressure of 920 hPa and adjusted the second peak to 185 km/h with a pressure of 935 hPa. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track report released on September 16, 2020, revised Butterfly's peak intensity to 270 km/h.

PAGASA: Dodong, a low-pressure area, formed on June 16 near the waters of the Caroline Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 94W. On the evening of June 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The system moved northward, gradually shifting to a west-northwest direction over the following days, temporarily suppressed by vertical wind shear. On the 24th, the system resumed moving northward, then shifted to a northeast-north direction, quickly passing through the waters east of the Ryukyu Islands, exhibiting some extratropical cyclone characteristics. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center thus classified the system as a subtropical cyclone and never upgraded it to a tropical depression. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency, which does not have this classification, identified the system as a tropical cyclone and announced on the evening of the 27th that it had intensified into a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1903 and naming it "Sepat." Sepat moved east-northeast across the waters south of Japan's Honshu and subsequently transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On June 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that a low-pressure area had formed in the northern South China Sea. The next day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 96W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as "low." On the afternoon of July 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded the system to a tropical depression, designating it as TD09; the China Meteorological Administration followed suit at 8:30 PM, upgrading the system to a tropical depression and designating it as TD01. Due to the system's loose structure, there were significant discrepancies in positioning among meteorological agencies. The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued Signal No. 1 at 10 PM on July 1. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the classification to "medium" at 10:30 PM and further to "high" at 4:30 AM on July 2, issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Hong Kong Observatory announced at 10 AM on July 2 that a tropical depression was forming and upgraded it to a tropical depression at 4:15 PM, issuing the Standby Signal No. 1. As the system approached Hainan Island, the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal at 6 PM on July 2. The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau replaced Signal No. 1 with Signal No. 3 at 8 PM on July 2. At 9 PM on July 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international designation 1904 and naming it "Mun." At 12:45 AM on July 3, the China Meteorological Administration announced that Mun had made landfall in Hele Town, Wanning City, Hainan Province. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert and downgraded the classification to "medium." In the early hours of July 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone designation 05W. It made landfall again along the coast of Thai Binh Province, Vietnam, around 6:45 AM. At 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Mun to a tropical depression, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center subsequently issued its final warning. At noon, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Falcon  
On July 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that a low-pressure area had formed near the Mariana Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 98W. On July 14 at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 p.m. the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center gave it a development rating of "low." On July 15 at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD10. At 3 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "medium," and the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression at 5 p.m. and 8 p.m., respectively. At 11 p.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued Signal No. 1 for Isabela, Cagayan, and the Batanes Islands.  

On July 16 at 6:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 06W. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1905 and naming it "Danas." At 5 p.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued Signal No. 2 for Cagayan. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm later that night. The Central Weather Bureau soon issued a sea typhoon warning, followed by a land typhoon warning at 11:30 a.m. the next day. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration announced in a tropical cyclone warning issued at 2 a.m. on the 17th that the system had made landfall in Gattaran, Cagayan.  

As Danas passed through Luzon, its circulation was affected by Luzon's terrain, splitting into two. The low-level circulation center of Danas continued moving northward, while deep convection moved into the South China Sea. During the day, Danas slowly moved northward, merging with the tropical disturbance 90W to the east that evening, successfully repairing its exposed circulation center. On the 18th, Danas continued to move steadily northward and made landfall in Buan County, North Jeolla Province, on the 20th. At 9 p.m. on the 21st, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Danas had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On the afternoon of July 23, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern seas of Japan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 91W. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system as "low" and upgraded it to "medium" at 10 a.m. on July 24. At 5 a.m. on July 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as number 11. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 10 a.m. on July 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as tropical cyclone 07W. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a tropical storm. At 9 a.m. on July 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1906 and naming it "Nari." At 7 a.m. on July 27, Nari made landfall in southern Mie Prefecture, Japan. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and by the morning of July 28, its remnants had completely dissipated.

On July 28, a low-pressure area formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 92W. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system as "low." On the afternoon of the 29th, the rating was upgraded to "medium." On the morning of July 30 at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 11:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory also stated that the low-pressure area in the central to northern South China Sea was gradually strengthening, and a tropical cyclone seemed to be forming. The Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning at 3 p.m. At 4 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 12. 

At 6:45 a.m. on July 31, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau also upgraded it to a tropical storm at 7 a.m. that day. At 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1907, and named it "Wipha." The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm at 5 p.m. that afternoon, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 08W. 

At 1:50 a.m. on August 1, the China Meteorological Administration announced that Wipha had made landfall along the coast of Wenchang City, Hainan Province. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory stated that Wipha had moved back out to sea and was redeveloping and strengthening. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it back to a tropical storm. At 5:40 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration announced that Wipha had made landfall again along the coast of Potou District, Zhanjiang City, Guangdong Province. After moving out to sea from Zhanjiang, Wipha moved westward over the northern Beibu Gulf near the coast of Guangxi. On the evening of August 2, the China Meteorological Administration announced that Wipha had made its third landfall in Fangchenggang, Guangxi. 

At 9 p.m. on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 p.m. on August 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Wipha's remnants had completely dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Wipha's peak intensity was revised to 100 km/h.

While Tropical Storm Wipha was developing, two other tropical disturbances formed over the sea south of Japan. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center first designated the tropical disturbance near the Mariana Islands as 93W. On the afternoon of August 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning at 9 p.m. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 13. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert, upgrading the system to a tropical depression with the designation 09W at 5 a.m. the next day. On the morning of August 2, at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1908, and named it "Francisco." On the evening of August 3, at 11 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On the afternoon of August 5, at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 2 a.m. on August 6, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a strong typhoon. At 4 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Francisco made landfall in Miyazaki City, Miyazaki Prefecture. At 7:20 p.m., the Korea Meteorological Administration announced that Francisco made landfall again in Busan. On the morning of August 7, at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. In the best track analysis released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Francisco's peak intensity was revised to 150 km/h.

PAGASA: While Hanna developed into Tropical Storm Wipha, two other tropical disturbances formed over the southern seas of Japan. At 3:00 AM on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning at 3:00 PM. At 4:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 14. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. On August 4, at 9:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1909, and named it "Lekima." At 3:00 AM on August 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. In the best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency in early October, Lekima's pressure was adjusted to 925 hPa. Typhoon Lekima caused severe damage to power, water supply, and communication network infrastructure. Flights to mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Southeast Asia, and North America were canceled. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Lekima's peak intensity was adjusted to 250 km/h.

On August 4, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near the Mariana Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 95W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its development potential as "low." On the morning of August 5, at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning at 3 p.m. At 4 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 15. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system. On August 6, at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 11W. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1910, and named it "Krosa." The following afternoon, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm and further upgraded it to a typhoon in the early hours of August 8. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan, and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration followed suit shortly after. 

On the afternoon of August 9, after reaching its peak intensity, Krosa stalled, depleting the ocean's energy and causing upwelling of cooler deep water, leading to a gradual weakening of its intensity. As Krosa remained stationary, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the system to a tropical storm at 11 p.m. on August 10. The Hong Kong Observatory also downgraded it to a severe tropical storm at 2 a.m. on August 11. As Krosa began moving northwest and left the cooler waters, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it back to a typhoon at 2 p.m. on August 11, but the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm on the same day. The Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it again to a severe tropical storm at 10 a.m. on August 12. 

On August 15, at 3 p.m., Krosa made landfall near Kure City in Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan, causing at least 2 deaths and 49 injuries. After landfall, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. The following morning, at 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that the system had begun transitioning into an extratropical cyclone and issued its final warning. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Krosa had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. By midnight on August 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Krosa had completely dissipated. 

In the best track report issued by the Japan Meteorological Agency on October 3, Krosa's peak intensity was revised downward to 140 km/h, and its central pressure was revised upward to 965 hPa.

PAGASA: At 3:00 PM on August 14, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the afternoon of the 20th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 9:00 AM on August 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning at 3:00 PM. At 4:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 16. At 3:00 PM on August 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1911, and named it "Bailu." Shortly after, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 4:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on August 22, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3:45 AM on the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued Signal No. 1 for the Batanes Islands, Cagayan Province, Isabela Province, Apayao Province, Kalinga Province, northern Abra Province, and northern Ilocos Norte Province. Early the next morning, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm, and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration immediately issued Signal No. 2 for the Batanes Islands. At 9:45 PM on the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM on August 23, Bailu entered the jurisdiction of the Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center, which classified it as a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, "Bailu" entered the jurisdiction of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, which classified it as a severe tropical storm. At 7:00 AM on August 24, the storm circle of Typhoon Bailu made landfall on Taiwan's Hengchun Peninsula. At 1:00 PM on the same day, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan announced that Bailu had made landfall in Manzhou Township, Pingtung County. At 4:10 PM, the bureau announced that Bailu had exited to sea from Nanzih District, Kaohsiung City. At 12:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 3:00 AM on August 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and declared it dissipated at 9:00 PM. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Bailu's peak intensity was revised to 110 km/h.

PAGASA: Jenny, a tropical disturbance, formed in the waters east of the Philippines. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 99W. At 2:00 PM, "Podul" entered the area of responsibility of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, which classified it as a tropical depression. At 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted all storm signals.

At 3:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 3:45 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On August 31, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared that Podul had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Onyok On the afternoon of September 25, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1918, and named it "Mitag." At 9:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on September 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5:45 p.m. on September 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 9 p.m. on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m. on October 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Mitag had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.

At noon on October 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 2 a.m. on October 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 25, and issued a path forecast. At 9:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center skipped the "medium" rating and directly upgraded it to "high," issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 20W. At 2 a.m. on October 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1919, and named it "Hagibis." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a strong tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center simultaneously upgraded Hagibis to a typhoon. Although Hagibis did not enter the Hong Kong Observatory's area of responsibility, it was classified as a typhoon on the weather map. At 8 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a super typhoon. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency raised its maximum sustained wind speed to 195 km/h, making it the third storm of the year to reach the "violent" level and temporarily the strongest tropical cyclone of the year, though it was later surpassed by Super Typhoon Halong in November of the same year. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its maximum sustained wind speed to 260 km/h, classifying it as a Category 5 hurricane. It became the first storm to reach Category 5 hurricane strength since Super Typhoon Wutip in February of the same year, and Hagibis became the third-fastest intensifying tropical cyclone on record in the Northwest Pacific, following Typhoon Forrest in 1983 and Typhoon Goni in 2020. At 11 a.m. on October 8, Hagibis developed a double eyewall phenomenon, causing its intensity to slightly weaken. At noon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 hurricane. At 6 a.m. on October 9, Hagibis completed its eyewall replacement cycle, and its intensity peaked again. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center re-upgraded it to a Category 5 hurricane. At 11 a.m. on October 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Hagibis had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Hagibis's peak intensity was revised to 295 km/h, tying the record set by Typhoon Megi in 2010.
