PAGASA: Chedeng A low-pressure area formed on March 11 in the waters near the Marshall Islands and moved west-northwest under the guidance of the subtropical high-pressure ridge. Affected by vertical wind shear, the system developed slowly and had a loose structure. The low-level circulation center of the system gradually consolidated on the 13th, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within one day as "medium," skipping the "low" rating. On the afternoon of the 14th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also raised the rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. Due to the system's convective outbreak, showing the characteristics of a tropical cyclone, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center successively classified the system as a tropical depression at 2 a.m. and 8 a.m. on the 15th, assigning it tropical cyclone numbers 04 and 03W, respectively. That day, the system turned southwestward. Due to persistent vertical wind shear and weak outflow above the system, the tropical depression did not intensify further on the 16th. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded the system to a low-pressure area at 8 a.m. on the 17th. Subsequently, the system crossed Koror Island, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. on the 18th. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration announced that the system made landfall in Malitbog, Mindanao, Philippines, at 5:30 a.m. on the 19th. Affected by terrain, the system's central convection weakened, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. At this time, the system resumed a northwest-northward path, entering Moro Bay. In the evening, the system entered the Sulu Sea, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center stated that the system weakened and dissipated during the day on the 20th.  

As the system intensified into a tropical depression, the U.S. National Weather Service issued a tropical storm watch for Ngulu Atoll, Yap Island, and Kayangel Island at 11:40 a.m. on the 15th. The U.S. National Weather Service stated that the aforementioned islands were experiencing northeast winds of 4-5 levels, with stronger circulation on the northern side of the system, making Yap Island more affected than Ngulu Atoll and Kayangel Island. The U.S. National Weather Service later expanded the tropical storm watch to include Koror Island at 5:20 a.m. on the 16th. Yap Island first experienced east winds in the morning, and Ngulu Atoll and Kayangel Island experienced east winds by the early morning of the 17th. As the system moved away, the U.S. National Weather Service successively canceled the tropical storm watch for Yap Island and Ngulu Atoll at 5:35 p.m. on the 16th and 11:20 a.m. on the 17th. After the system passed Koror Island and moved west of Kayangel Atoll and the Caroline Islands, the islands began experiencing southeast winds, and the U.S. National Weather Service canceled all tropical storm watches at 5:20 p.m. The system entered the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration's area of responsibility in the early morning of the 17th, and the agency named the system "Chedeng," issuing Signal No. 1 for parts of Mindanao. The system made landfall in Malitbog, Mindanao, Philippines, at 5:30 a.m. on the 19th and soon weakened into a low-pressure area, prompting the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration to lift Signal No. 1.  

In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, the peak of 03W was adjusted to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

Once a tropical cyclone reaches tropical storm intensity in the Western Pacific, it is named by the Typhoon Committee of the Japan Meteorological Agency. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and are then sorted alphabetically by the first letter of the English name of each country. Names in bold indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. The storm names for 2019 may overlap with some storm names from 2001, 2002, 2007, 2008, 2013, and 2014.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2019, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2019. It includes the intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage caused by these tropical cyclones. All damages are measured in US dollars. Numbers in parentheses indicate indirect deaths (such as traffic accidents, landslides, etc.).

Article_Name: Tornade du 10 septembre 1896 à Paris — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata The tornado of September 10, 1896, is a violent meteorological phenomenon that affected the heart of Paris that day, a little before 3 p.m. It is the only known tornado in the history of the French capital.

Paris was already struck by a violent hailstorm on July 26, 1896, affecting the neighborhoods between Montsouris and Belleville. Numerous trees were uprooted, and the flowerbeds of the Jardin des Plantes were devastated. The press of the time reported that tramway traffic had to be interrupted at Quai Saint-Bernard due to tree trunks fallen on the roadway. Roofs were torn off in various places, such as Place d'Italie. The Bois de Boulogne and Bois de Vincennes were also affected. The event caused two deaths: an eleven-year-old girl killed in the collapse of a laundry at 85 Rue de Patay in the 13th arrondissement, and a young woman in her twenties who fell from the top of the fortifications at Porte d'Ivry.

The city is once again struck by a storm on September 10. Around 2:40 PM, at Place Saint-Sulpice, what the press of the time described as a "waterspout" or a "cyclone" forms. Likely categorized as F2 on the Fujita scale, it causes the death of at least five people and injures about a hundred others. The phenomenon, which moves almost in a straight line northward, spans a strip 150 to 300 meters wide and 6 kilometers long through the 6th, 1st, 3rd, and 10th arrondissements, affecting notably: Place Saint-Sulpice, Quai des Grands-Augustins, where trees are uprooted and booksellers' boxes scattered; the Seine, where several barges sink or are damaged; Pont Saint-Michel, Île de la Cité, Pont au Change; Place du Châtelet, where the theater's roof is partially torn off; Rue Réaumur, where the damage is most striking, Rue de Turbigo; Place de la République, Boulevard Saint-Martin, Boulevard de Magenta, then Canal Saint-Martin, where a woman and her child are thrown into the water; Hôpital Saint-Louis and Boulevard de la Villette, where a funfair is devastated. The press reports that, according to witnesses, the whirlwind does not rise higher than the treetops and notably leaves the top of the Saint-Jacques Tower intact. It also moves in the manner of a "rubber ball, by successive leaps." Among the victims are: an English jockey, Alfred Eyears, who was in an open carriage and was, according to sources, either thrown "ten meters high" or more soberly "crushed by the fall of a chimney" at Quai des Orfèvres; a laborer, Mr. Vanderhagle, killed by a lead sheet torn from a roof; a five-year-old child, Antoine Rouché, killed by a tree branch; a porter at Les Halles, suffering from a heart condition, who died the next day while recounting his accident; the wife of a bargeman, Mrs. Lefebvre, struck by a tree branch on her sinking barge. This phenomenon was the subject of several communications to the Academy of Sciences at the time.

The street cleaning work begins the next day, with broken windows needing to be replaced, scattered branches in the streets to be picked up, and wreckage from the Seine to be removed. The municipality allocates a budget of 10,000 francs and covers the funeral expenses of the victims.
On June 18, 1897, another tornado struck the Paris suburbs of Courbevoie, La Garenne-Colombes, Asnières, and Saint-Ouen. It caused around ten deaths.

Article_Name: Tornado de Córdoba de 2003, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Córdoba tornado was a meteorological phenomenon that occurred on December 26, 2003, in the city of Córdoba, Argentina.

The Argentine National Meteorological Service had warned several provinces in the central-west of the country that a system of strong thunderstorms, with heavy downpours, strong winds of 60 to 90 km/h, and occasional hail would affect the region. These storms impacted Mendoza, San Juan, La Rioja, San Luis, Catamarca, Córdoba, Santa Fe, and Buenos Aires. When the first damages were reported in the initial provinces, the people of Córdoba were almost caught off guard by the alert. The winds caused damage in other cities, such as fallen trees, power and light poles, and cars dented by hail that some said was the size of a tennis ball. The Meteorological Service extended the alert from four to seven days because it seemed to be gaining strength, and that’s when the inhabitants of La Docta began to worry.

On Friday, December 26, 2003, in the city of Córdoba, the temperature ranged between 35 and 36 °C in the shade. The oppressive heat was countered by gray and black clouds that began appearing from the mountains early in the morning, while news reports mentioned strong river surges in the mountainous areas and damage in towns like Villa Dolores, where hail and wind caused further destruction. In the capital, the occasional sound of fireworks explosions and remnants of the previous night's Christmas celebrations could still be heard. By 2:00 PM, some residents were preparing to take a nap with the drizzle that had started to fall. Then tragedy struck. At 3:15 PM, a funnel-shaped cloud began descending toward the ground. Many witnesses were stunned by the event until they started seeking shelter upon seeing houses, trees, cables, and other objects being lifted into the air. Sheets of metal from warehouses violently wrapped around trees that the winds could not uproot. The tornado moved forward with gusts exceeding 300 km/h, heavy rain, hail, and lightning. Some residents in the city center watched the phenomenon in amazement from tall buildings, while the tornado caused destruction in the area of the CPC on Route 20, particularly in the neighborhoods of Ameguino Norte, San Roque, and Villa La Tela, where most of the deaths, injuries, and damage occurred.

The National Meteorological Service informed Civil Defense authorities, Police, Emergency Services, Firefighters, and the media about what was happening in the afternoon in Córdoba. Surprised by the phenomenon, a strong rescue operation was organized for those affected by the tornado. Upon arrival at the scene, they encountered a desolate landscape: people mourning their material losses; furniture, beds, sheets, roofs scattered everywhere; fallen poles and cables; uprooted trees; etc. The tornado, which lasted 24 minutes, devastated two neighborhoods and an emergency settlement, and the winds caused damage in forty more neighborhoods, with intensity increasing as it approached the area where the funnel began. Unfortunately, five lives were lost, more than 90 people were injured, and about 5,000 were evacuated. The Police could not prevent unknown individuals from stealing belongings left outdoors after the storm. In other nearby towns like Villa Carlos Paz or La Calera, less intense damage was reported. The strong and sudden rise of rivers filled lakes and reservoirs to their limits, prompting the National Government and DIPAS to order the opening of floodgates, causing post-dam rivers to rise sharply as well. The tornado was classified as F3: that is, winds of 290 to 320 km per hour.

Article_Name: Tornado de San Carlos de 1981, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The San Carlos tornado of 1981 was a meteorological phenomenon that occurred on May 18, 1981, in the city of San Carlos, and also affected part of Cachapoal, now the Ñuble Region, Chile. This area, like the rest of the country, is not prone to this type of climatic phenomenon; however, a similar event occurred again in the city in 2013, though not as destructive as this one. It was classified as F3 on the Fujita-Pearson scale.

The tornado originated about 55 kilometers west of the city of San Carlos and disappeared 25 kilometers east of it, in the town of Cachapoal; that is, it traveled 80 kilometers from west to east in a time of 38 minutes. In San Carlos, it passed through the "Barrio Estación" and the very center of the city, passing by the potable water tank that supplies it. It originated at 10:10 local time.

In San Carlos, a large part of the San Carlos Station was destroyed, leaving it without a roof and windows. The Plaza de Armas was completely destroyed, trees over 50 years old were uprooted, the locally famous store "El Caballo" was destroyed, part of its building collapsed, as well as the municipal building and the fire station were affected. Small commercial establishments were also devastated, and many people and vehicles were thrown into the air like mere toys. It is, without a doubt, the most destructive tornado in the last 100 years in Chile, surpassing the one in Villarrica in 2011 and the one in Concepción in 1934. The power outage lasted several days due to the fall of at least 400 power poles, potable water was restored on May 22, and classes were suspended for 2 weeks. A total of 2 deaths, 1 missing person, 323 injured, and 1,524 affected individuals were estimated. About 480 homes were severely affected.

Article_Name: Tornade d'Oostmalle — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about Belgium and firefighters or civil protection. The Oostmalle tornado is the name given to a tornado that struck, on June 25, 1967, the region of Oostmalle, in the north of Belgium, in the province of Antwerp, as well as part of the south of the Netherlands, where it is known as the Tricht tornado. This natural disaster caused seven deaths. The tornado was classified as an F3 on the Fujita scale.

Article_Name: Tornado de San Carlos de 2013, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The San Carlos tornado of 2013 was a meteorological phenomenon that occurred on Friday, May 31, 2013, in the city of San Carlos, Ñuble Region, Chile. This area, like the rest of the country, is not prone to this type of climatic phenomenon; however, a similar event occurred in the city in 1981. It was classified as F2 on the Fujita-Pearson scale according to National Geographic.

On Friday, May 31, 2013, the central and southern zones of Chile were affected by a frontal system coming from the Pacific Ocean for two days. The tornado occurred around 11:20 a.m. outside the San Carlos Municipal Cemetery, where it destroyed some flower shops, moved eastward along Navotavo Street, a busy area in the city, destroying and damaging houses in its path, and disappeared about 500 meters further up, where it destroyed a large part of a hardware store. It originated from the appearance of a cloud called "Cumulonimbus," which forms after a frontal system, such as the one that affected Chile during those days. The cloud, in turn, was caused by a sudden temperature change, explained by the warming of the ground and the cold air, which creates atmospheric pressure between the ground and the air; this produces a downdraft from the cloud to the ground, which spins at speeds between 200 to 250 kilometers per hour (the San Carlos tornado reached 228 km/h) and moves randomly with a force capable of destroying everything in its path. It is worth noting that the phenomenon remains active as long as the temperature difference between the ground and the air is significant, usually lasting no more than 20 minutes (the San Carlos tornado lasted 12) before disappearing.

ONEMI declared a state of emergency in the commune and surrounding areas, including the localities of Cachapoal (where a rumor mentioned that the tornado also affected this town), Ninhue, San Fabián de Alico, San Gregorio de Ñiquén, and San Nicolás. At the time of the tornado, the "Violeta Parra Sandoval High School" was in the middle of classes, with about 600 students and staff inside, who, according to local news reports, "took cover under the tables while the windows shattered and the roof was blown off." This caused chaos among parents in the area who, in addition to the confusion caused by this unusual event, were withdrawing their children amidst the chaos, with one person injured. Other schools and high schools in the city were also forced to release students due to the collective panic in the city. Regarding damages, the Violeta Parra High School was left with some classrooms without roofs and broken windows, classes were suspended for one week, a wall on Navotavo Street collapsed, blocking part of the road, city collective transit was halted, and a power outage affected Cachapoal, Ninquihue, and San Fabián de Alico. Additionally, two community centers and about five flower shops located outside the Municipal Cemetery were affected. However, the symbol of the disaster was the "Almet Hardware Store," which was severely destroyed and became the media figure of the tornado. In terms of personal injuries, no fatalities were reported, but there were two injuries: one inspector from Violeta Parra High School who was struck by a zinc sheet from the school's roof, and one pedestrian on Navotavo Street who was injured by the collapse of a wall. In the end, 103 homes were affected to varying degrees, 47 of them uninhabitable, with a total of 412 people affected and 232 displaced.

Article_Name: Tornado de Madrid de 1886, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Madrid tornado of May 12, 1886, was a violent storm episode in the south of the Spanish city of Madrid, which triggered a tornado in the then-independent municipality of Carabanchel Alto, also affecting the municipalities of Carabanchel Bajo and the city of Madrid itself. It followed a SW-NE trajectory. It caused severe material damage and fatalities (47, according to some sources). Augusto Arcimís—in his chronicle of May 22, 1886, in La Ilustración Española y Americana—details the occurrence of two separate tornadoes that day; one that reportedly began at 6:50 PM near Carabanchel Alto and another at 7:01 PM. The phenomenon was treated by scientists of the time as "the passage of a cyclone" rather than a tornado. The event is mentioned by Benito Pérez Galdós in his novel Misericordia.

Article_Name: Tornado de Estación López de 1992, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Tornado of Estación López was an F4 category tornado that affected the town of López, in the province of Buenos Aires, on Wednesday, May 6, 1992, causing 4 deaths, more than 100 injuries, and millions of pesos in material losses. According to experts, this tornado is one of the most destructive in South America, only behind the San Justo Tornado.

Minutes before 6:30 PM (the time when the tornado struck the town), a strong and typical storm with heavy rain and hail was occurring. Later, the rain had stopped, and like the hail, according to testimonies, everything was very "calm and silent." The clock struck 6:30 PM, and a massive funnel touched down a few meters from the station, moved towards it, and destroyed everything in its path. The tornado lasted just over 2 minutes, leaving only 5 houses standing. The wind exceeded 370 km/h [citation needed], and a 15-year-old girl was sucked in by the tornado, lifted about 7 meters, and then violently thrown to the ground.

The tornado left 4 dead and more than 100 injured. Only 5 houses were left standing. The local church was also destroyed. The railway station building, a solid English brick construction with 60 cm thick walls, was demolished by the tornado. Surprised by the event, the locals organized themselves and helped the injured out from under the rubble. The dead were transported to the city of Benito Juárez and buried in the cemetery. With the help of the provincial government of Dr. Eduardo Duhalde, Mayor Santana Estanislao Zabalza carried out the reconstruction of the station in 5 months, and on October 31 of the same year, the happy reconstruction of the station was celebrated with an event attended by the entire town.

Article_Name: Tornade de Sonnac du 16 septembre 2015 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content:
Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata  
The Sonnac tornado is a moderate-intensity tornado that struck several municipalities in Charente-Maritime on Wednesday, September 16, 2015. The French Observatory of Tornadoes and Severe Storms (Keraunos) classifies it as an EF2 intensity tornado[1], on the Enhanced Fujita scale. It caused significant damage in its path, such as partially destroyed homes. It is part of a tornado outbreak (clustered tornado episode) that totaled 3 cases for the day of September 16, 2015, including the EF1 tornado in Courtenay (Loiret) and the EF1 tornado in Jandun (Ardennes)[1]. This tornado is said to have traveled more than 70 km, making it the second-longest distance traveled by a tornado in France, after the EF4 tornado in Saint-Claude on August 19, 1890[3],[4]. It formed at 4:10 PM in the municipality of Chaniers, crossed the municipalities of La Chapelle-des-Pots, Saint-Césaire, Saint-Bris-des-Bois, Villars-les-Bois, Migron, Mons, Prignac, Thors, Matha, Sonnac, Haimps, Massac, Beauvais-sur-Matha, Bazauges, Ranville-Breuillaud, Barbezières, Lupsault, Saint-Fraigne, Ébréon, Souvigné, Courcôme, Raix, La Faye before dissipating in Condac around 5:05 PM. In total, the tornado crossed 24 municipalities in Charente and Charente-Maritime[5]. Its maximum intensity seems to have been reached between the municipalities of Thors and Sonnac, where the damage was most significant.

The day of Wednesday, September 16, 2015, saw the placement of a depression trough of 985 hPa over the Bay of Biscay, inducing a strong southwesterly flow ahead of this depression. This barometric trough was located south of a large upper-level trough, which had also absorbed the former tropical storm Henri. At altitude, a fairly strong southwesterly jet stream had formed, bringing tropical and humid air. Already during the night of September 15 to 16, a succession of sometimes strong thunderstorms had formed near the Atlantic coasts, with instability becoming increasingly pronounced. These storms were quite windy with brief but strong gusts of wind. In the morning, the storms decreased slightly in intensity, but the instability was still present. The sky in La Rochelle, at dawn, was pre-stormy, with some breaks of blue sky to the west and distant lightning to the east. At 1 p.m., a few hours before the tornado formed, a new storm passed through Charente-Maritime. The electrical activity was relatively weak. In Bordeaux, Gironde, the radiosonde indicated moderate instability, with a convective available potential energy (CAPE) of 1,006 J/kg, as well as a lifting index (LI) of -5 K, which is quite significant. The jet stream was expected to reach 250 km/h. The relative helicity was measured at 535 m²/s² in the first three kilometers of altitude, and 208 m²/s² in the first kilometer, indicating a tornado risk. The temperatures at 2 meters were high in Bordeaux (27°C) but contrasted with those recorded in Blaye (18°C), for example. This strong thermal contrast is explained by the presence of a very active cold front between the two cities. The above radiosonde indicates the atmospheric conditions in Bordeaux at 2 p.m., just before the passage of the cold front. The radiosonde explains why a tornado had formed just south of the squall line. An additional warming of 1 or 2 K due to sunlight would have caused the lifting index (LI) to drop from -5 K to -7 K, which significantly increased the severity of the storms, even though the level of free convection varied little and the cumulonimbus clouds remained modest in thickness. The above radiosonde indicates that the top of the cumulonimbus was at about 300 hPa, or 9,000 m. The cumulonimbus was therefore not very thick. The photograph from the Keraunos site confirms this fact, showing that the cumulonimbus was not very spectacular.

At 1:45 PM, radar images revealed a storm cell over the Bay of Biscay, heading towards the Charente coastline. Quite active, this storm was quickly organizing into a retrograde-propagating linear system. At 3:00 PM, the storm reached the Charente coastline, initially between Rochefort and La Tremblade. Still fairly well-organized, producing gusts locally reaching 70 km/h. However, electrical activity remained low. The line was moving along a southwest/northeast axis, still in retrograde propagation. The northern part of the storm line tended to weaken, while the southern part retained its wind potential. No rotation was yet observed. At 3:30 PM, the line weakened in the north, where the rain became stratiform. Convective energy persisted in the southern part of the line, where unstable cells were developing and moving along the squall, heading northeast. These rare storms were most often embedded in the rainy mass. At 3:45 PM, a new cell developed at the extreme south of the line, near Royan. This particular cell would become tornadic several minutes later. At 4:00 PM, this same storm became quite active, with hail potential. This cell began to exhibit a low-top supercellular behavior (in English, Low Top or mini-supercell). A wall cloud quickly formed at the base of this mini-supercell. A shelf cloud was also visible ahead of the storm line. At 4:10 PM, a funnel cloud, or tuba, formed at the base of the wall cloud, followed by some debris starting to swirl. The tornado had thus formed, gaining intensity. On precipitation radars, the rotation was clearly visible above Chaniers. At 4:45 PM, the tornado reached its maximum intensity as it traveled through the commune of Sonnac and its surroundings. It was in this area that it caused the most damage. At 5:10 PM, the tornado finally dissipated, as did the storm cell, which became just a weakening rain line over the following minutes.

Article_Name: Tornade du 18 juin 1897 à Asnières-sur-Seine — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The Asnières-sur-Seine tornado of June 18, 1897, is a violent meteorological phenomenon that affected Asnières-sur-Seine and its surroundings[1].

On June 18, 1897, a depression covered the west of Europe, and storms formed in the Paris region coming from the southwest. Large hail was reported from Meudon to Choisy-le-Roi. In Paris, there was only a little rain and small hailstones while the tornado followed a path from Courbevoie, to La Garenne-Colombes, to Asnières-sur-Seine, to Gennevilliers, to Saint-Ouen, and ended in Le Bourget. The total trajectory was 21 kilometers with an average width of 150 meters but sometimes up to 250 meters. The report from the Asnières meteorological station showed that the tornado passed at 4:50 PM, with the pressure dropping to 746.3 mm Hg (994.98 hPa) and the anemometer reaching its limit of 30 meters per second (108 km/h), thus unable to provide the exact speed. Another station 500 meters from the trajectory recorded no drop at all, showing that the effect was limited to the axis of movement. Its movement speed was estimated at 180 km/h, which should be taken with caution given the limited measurement tools of the time.

Along the trajectory, trees were uprooted or broken, crops were damaged, fences were overturned, fairground rides were destroyed, and buildings were damaged or destroyed. An individual was thrown a distance and killed by the fall, a car was thrown 29 meters along with its horse, two 20 kg concrete blocks and other objects were thrown a distance. Damage was notably reported by the press: According to this damage, the winds were estimated to be between 220 and 270 km/h.

Article_Name: Tornade de Montville — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content:
Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata  
The Montville tornado, also called the Montville waterspout at the time, is the deadliest tornado ever recorded in France with seventy-five deaths. On August 19, 1845, it caused significant damage in the industrial valley of Malaunay and Montville, in Seine-Inférieure. This tornado is one of only two in France, along with the one in Palluel (Pas-de-Calais) in 1967, to have been classified (retrospectively and unofficially) at level 5 on the Fujita scale[1].

Around noon, a storm breaks out in the Rouen region, causing heavy rainfall. The tornado forms around 1 p.m. near the commune of Le Houlme and moves through the Cailly Valley towards Malaunay, quickly gaining immense strength. Along its path, it destroys homes and uproots hundreds of trees, some of which are carried away whole in the whirlwind. In the industrial valley, three textile mills are leveled. In Malaunay, the Neveu mill, a solid four-story building, is the first to be destroyed, followed by the Mare Frères workshops in the same commune and the Picquot-Deschamps mill in Montville. The latter was housed in a new brick building that could not withstand the tornado's power. The 150-meter chimney is torn down. According to analyses from the time, the tornado continues its path through the Clères forest, covering a total distance of about fifteen kilometers before dissipating in Grugny.

The damage is considerable. Debris was found in Saint-Victor and Torcy-le-Grand, 30 km from Montville, which testifies to the destructive force of the phenomenon. In the woods belonging to Deputy Charles Levavasseur, two to three hundred beeches were uprooted. The three mills in the valley, which concentrated most of the industrial activity, ceased to exist. The human toll is the heaviest ever recorded in France for a tornado. Among the 200 to 370 mill workers who were at work at the time, very few were able to take shelter, especially since, due to its large diameter, the funnel encompassed most of the valley. Dozens of bodies and injured people, sometimes horribly mutilated, were extracted from the debris by nearby residents who came to help. The interior of the factories is described as "a slaughterhouse of human flesh," according to the newspaper La Presse. Mr. Neveu himself was pulled alive from the rubble but was very shocked. He had protected his mother with his body, and she emerged unscathed. After three hours of prostration, he declared: "I know I am ruined, but I do not complain; I had the happiness of saving my mother." An ambulance service was set up, and doctors arrived from Rouen. The director of the Cheval-Noir, a local hotel, made his establishment, linens, and furniture available to them. The priest of Montville and other clergymen attended to the injured, offering prayers and comfort. The families of the victims were sent away to allow the doctors to work under the best conditions, which led to scenes of despair. As the mutilated bodies of two young girls were removed from Picquot's house, their mother recognized them and, in her grief, threw herself into the river, where she drowned. The clearing work lasted until the next day. In total, 75 deaths were counted after the disaster. On August 21, Prefect Henri Dupont-Delporte and the field marshal visited the injured and assessed the damage. A subscription for the benefit of the victims and their families was opened at the Rouen town hall, and Mayor Henry Barbet posted an appeal for donations throughout the city. Charity performances were held: in Rouen itself on September 9 and in Paris, at the Circus, on the same day, then at the Théâtre des Variétés, which was packed on September 12. The Norman writer Eugène Noël witnessed the disaster and participated in the rescue efforts with Charles Michelet (the son of historian Jules Michelet), who was among the survivors. He had been walking in the woods at the time of the tornado's passage.

Gustave Flaubert, a native of the region, mentions the event in one of his letters to Louise Colet, dated August 26, 1846: "How much I have heard, mercy! How much I endured last year of those magnificent dissertations on the Monville waterspout! – 'Why did it happen? How did it come about? Can one conceive of it? Is it the electricity from above or from below? In one second, three factories overturned and two hundred men killed! What a horror!'" The testimony of Eugène Noël was published in 1876 in the book *Trombes et cyclones* by Frédéric Zurcher and Élie Philippe Margollé.

Article_Name: Tempêtes de fin décembre 1999 en Europe — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.header: End of December 1999 storms in Europe
Whole_Text.content: For articles with the same name, see Storm of the Century. The storms of late December 1999 in Europe are two intense mid-latitude depressions with rapid development, named Lothar and Martin, which crossed Western Europe on December 26, 27, and 28, 1999. These two extremely powerful extratropical bomb cyclones caused major wind damage. The two depression systems caused the death of 140 people and nearly 19.2 billion dollars (2006) in material damage.

Although the media mentioned hurricanes, these storms did not have their structure. Indeed, no tropical cyclone can develop over waters with a temperature below 26°C. Thus, the last hurricane of the 1999 season occurred in November in the Caribbean, as mentioned in the report of the National Hurricane Center, the regional meteorological center specialized by the World Meteorological Organization for monitoring tropical cyclones in the North Atlantic. The mention of hurricanes referred by analogy only to the wind force according to the Beaufort scale.

In December 1999, Europe was hit by three strong depressions. On December 3, the Anatol storm devastated Denmark and northern Germany. At the end of that month, two other storms followed one another less than two days apart and were considered by the media as the storm of the century in Europe. The first, Lothar, was a compact depression that passed quickly without changing the zonal flow of atmospheric circulation, which allowed the next one, Martin, to follow closely. This latter storm, being of large diameter, was associated with a modification of the circulation that prevented other depressions from following it. These storms have two points in common:

Lothar is the name given to the storm that rapidly crossed northern France on the morning of Sunday, December 26, 1999. Moving from west to east along an approximate line near the forty-ninth parallel, this depression reached Finistère at around 2 a.m. and Strasbourg at 11 a.m., traveling at an average speed of 100 km/h. The most violent winds devastated a strip about 150 km wide along a curve starting from the tip of Brittany, passing through Normandy, Île-de-France, Champagne-Ardenne, Lorraine, and Alsace. Lothar continued its path toward Germany, causing significant damage to infrastructure and forests such as the Black Forest. It caused unprecedented damage to forests in France, Switzerland, Germany, and Denmark. Mountain winds reached speeds of 259 km/h. The depression formed off the coast of Newfoundland before crossing the Atlantic Ocean in less than twenty-four hours. Exceptionally in Europe, the deepening of this storm intensified over land, reaching an atmospheric pressure of 960 hPa (960 mb), likely due to strong interaction with jet streams whose speed was around 400 km/h at just 9,000 meters altitude. According to a subsequent study by the Zentralanstalt für Meteorologie und Geodynamik (ZAMG), the Austrian meteorological service, Lothar was followed by a secondary cyclogenesis trough that passed through Belgium and southwestern Germany, generating winds of over 90 km/h.

This second very deep depression (down to 965 hPa at 4 p.m. in Brittany) crossed France at a significant speed (around 100 km/h) from the afternoon of Monday, December 27, 1999, to the following night. It developed off the coast of Brittany on December 27, reaching the region's coast around 4 p.m., before moving towards Nantes (7 p.m.), Romorantin (10 p.m.), Dijon (1 a.m. on December 28), and Alsace (4 a.m.). The regions most severely affected by the wind were Brittany, the Atlantic coast, particularly Charente-Maritime and Charente (198 km/h on Île d'Oléron), and then all areas south of a La Rochelle - Mâcon line, including the Côte d'Azur (gusts of 160 km/h unofficially recorded in Cannes). The wind continued to blow in Corsica on the morning of Tuesday, December 28, causing strong waves on the western coast. The storm also affected Spain, western Switzerland, and northern Italy. North of the depression, a cold air injection caused snowfall sticking to the ground in northern Brittany and Normandy from the afternoon of the 27th. During the night, the snow reached northeastern France as far as the Genevois, leaving flakes south of the Paris region. Meanwhile, significant amounts of rain caused flooding along its path. In some areas of the Alps, snowfall lasted two days, with the snow layer reaching about two meters.

After the 1987 storm, European meteorological services improved their numerical weather prediction models. In 1999, Météo-France was able to predict the occurrence of the two storms. Based on existing models and exceptional variations in measured temperatures and pressure, Météo-France was able to issue a severe weather warning for strong winds 24 hours before the Lothar storm. Météo-France forecasters at all levels work closely with Civil Security services. On December 26 at 5:25 a.m., the Interministerial Crisis Management Operational Center (COGIC) of the Directorate of Civil Defense and Security (DDSC) received a phone call from Météo-France announcing that strong winds were heading towards Île-de-France and the eastern, northern, and central parts of the country. This phone report was confirmed by the issuance of a meteorological alarm bulletin (BAM) at 6:45 a.m., confirming a strong wind phenomenon with an average speed of 80 km/h, gusts of 120 km/h, and locally reaching up to 140 km/h. While the population was warned of an exceptional weather event, the strength of the gusts exceeded the forecasts. At 7:30 a.m., Météo-France announced an update to the BAM, reporting a windy episode that could last one to two hours in Île-de-France and the central region, with winds potentially reaching 140 km/h or even locally 160 km/h. At 8:15 a.m., Civil Security, at the request of Météo-France, prepared a press release to warn residents of the affected areas about the significant risks posed by the announced winds. The press alert, initially relayed by national bulletins from the Radio France group, came as the Lothar storm was already hitting Normandy. The short time between the alert issued by Météo-France and the occurrence of the storm did not allow for earlier communication to the population about the severity of the phenomenon. Furthermore, the alert was issued at the end of the night, the day after Christmas celebrations, a time when media consumption is low and populations are difficult to mobilize.

Thanks to the monitoring of depression systems, Météo-France issues warnings for Storm Martin on the morning of December 27. They mention wind gusts of up to 130 km/h inland and 150 km/h on the coasts and highlands. An alert bulletin is also issued for snowfall in Brittany. As was the case with Storm Lothar, the population remains largely unprepared due to insufficient anticipation in the alert chain and underestimation of the wind strength. Awareness of the intensity of the phenomenon, both by public authorities and the population, only occurs from 7:50 PM with the dissemination of the first information on major damage (collapse of the glass roof of La Rochelle station) in France Info's regular bulletins.

MeteoSwiss experienced many difficulties with this system. Its numerical weather prediction models initially indicated weak depressions coming from the Atlantic. It was only on the morning of December 26 that alerts were issued following an adjustment of these models. Several local emergency service officials did not realize the importance of the storms and did not take the necessary measures, partly because it was during the Christmas holidays. Deutscher Wetterdienst (the German service) was criticized for not issuing an alert for Lothar. A post-analysis mentions that there was a computer problem in its communication system.

In France, the human toll of the two storms amounts to 92 deaths (drownings, accidents, hypothermia, falling trees or rocks, etc.) and around 2,000 injured. Transport and distribution infrastructures are seriously damaged. The storm has significant repercussions on forestry and agricultural activities, as well as on certain sectors of commercial activity.

Nearly 540 high and very high voltage lines and more than a thousand electrical pylons are out of service, representing about 8% of the electricity transmission network. Power outages affect 3.6 million households - or 10 million French people. Some departments are largely without electricity (Orne, Creuse, Corrèze, Haute-Vienne, Cantal, Lot-et-Garonne), and some entirely (Vosges, Charente-Maritime). Due to energy shortages and pollution affecting water distribution, 2.5 million residents must obtain water from stores. To restore its network, EDF relied on the help of around twenty countries, which provided personnel (1,500 technicians) and specialized equipment. A large part of the road network is impassable on Monday, December 27, including major routes such as the A10 motorway and National Route 10. Nearly 20,000 km of roads and forest trails providing access to massifs are damaged. Out of 32,000 km of railway tracks, 20,000 km are rendered unusable. The mobilization of 18,000 railway workers allows 95% of installations to be restored by December 31. Rail traffic returns to normal after a week. The costs of restoration and operational losses for SNCF amount to 510 million francs. Numerous flights are canceled, and some airports (Bordeaux-Mérignac, Clermont-Ferrand) are closed. Nearly one million subscribers are without landline telephone service due to fallen trees on overhead telephone lines and the rapid depletion of backup batteries in telephone exchanges and relay antennas. Nearly 3,500 mobile phone relay antennas (Itinéris, SFR, Bouygues Télécom) are out of service. The restoration of telephone networks cost approximately 1 billion francs for France Télécom, 100 million francs for SFR, and nearly 20 million for Bouygues Télécom. The near-identical reconstruction of France Télécom's telephone network will not be completed until April 2001.

The forestry and agricultural damage is considerable, particularly in the timber sector. Hundreds of thousands of trees have been felled, with waterlogged soils contributing to their instability. The first estimate of this damage, carried out by the Regional Forestry and Timber Services (SRFB), evaluates the volume of felled (windthrow) and broken (breakage) wood at 140 million cubic meters (with a margin of error of 30%, i.e., between 98 and 182 million). The most affected regions are Lorraine (29.5 million cubic meters), Aquitaine (27.7), and Limousin (16.3). The resistance of trees varied depending on species and geographical areas: poplars in the Garonne and oaks in the Adour fared better than pines in Médoc and Douglas firs in Limousin, with mountainous areas faring better than plains. A subsequent and more precise assessment of the damage raised the windthrow volume to 176 million cubic meters. The extent of the damage, partly linked to poor forestry management, led foresters to question the practices that had prevailed until then. While viticulture was relatively spared, market gardeners and horticulturists saw thousands of hectares of greenhouses destroyed. Hundreds of thousands of fruit trees were felled or damaged in southwestern France, notably plum trees in Lot-et-Garonne and walnut trees in Périgord. The reconstruction of these orchards took about fifteen years. However, the livestock sector suffered the most significant damage (drowned animals, damaged or destroyed buildings). Stocks of fodder and silage were waterlogged, and cows had to be milked manually due to a lack of electricity, resulting in the loss of several million liters of milk. Power outages affected artificial incubators, freezers, and refrigeration systems. Many food businesses relying on cold storage (supermarkets, restaurants, bakeries, caterers) lost their entire stock during a period of high activity. Order and transport flows were disrupted, and the sector was affected by technical unemployment measures. On the Atlantic coast, the storm surge reached 40 to 60 cm, and 1.5 to 2 meters in Charente-Maritime. A quarter of the oyster farming facilities in the Marennes-Oléron basin were completely destroyed. However, some sectors benefited from unexpected expenditures, such as construction, public works, producers of building materials, and DIY equipment.

The cost borne by insurance companies is significantly higher than that of the 1990 storms, which amounted to 8.6 billion francs. The French reinsurance group Scor estimated the total damages at nearly 33 billion francs. In 2000, the French Federation of Insurance Companies (FFSA) estimated the damages at 44.3 billion francs (6.75 billion euros), excluding deductibles, damages whose undeclared costs remained the responsibility of individuals and businesses, operating losses due to the temporary closure of factories, workshops, and shops, as well as the partial destruction of forest heritage. Compensation in France reached 7.5 billion euros under the "storm" guarantee and 275 million euros for floods. Half of the compensation was financed by reinsurers, while the rest was covered by the reserves of insurance companies and the Central Reinsurance Fund (CCR). Insurance companies were led to define stricter loss criteria, and reinsurance companies (Munich Re, Swiss Re, etc.) increased their rates by 5 to 30%. Faced with a significant decrease in the provisions of the Central Reinsurance Fund, public authorities significantly modified the surcharge rate for natural disasters, the deductibles applicable in the event of a claim, and the conditions of reinsurance. The financial burden on the state for the restoration of French forest heritage reached 2 billion francs in emergency aid in 2000, 12 billion in subsidized loans at 1.5%, 6 billion francs in subsidies over ten years for reconstruction, and 2 billion francs in "storm" amendments to state-region plan contracts.

According to insurers and authorities in various countries: Coastal regions such as the island of Oléron have been particularly devastated. Many historical monuments have also been affected, such as the Valmy mill.

Whole_Text.header: Response of emergency and intervention services

Whole_Text.content: The first interventions were carried out by the CODIS and the operational centers of the national gendarmerie and public security, which were on constant alert. The coordination of rescue operations was relayed with varying degrees of efficiency in the departments by the prefects with the establishment of crisis command centers. At the level of defense and security zones, the implementation of rescue efforts included the use of the interregional civil security coordination centers (CIRCOSC), but several affected zones (Center-West, Center-East) did not have any. At the national level, the government activated the decision support operations center (COAD) of the Ministry of the Interior and the joint operations center (COIA) under the Chief of Defense Staff. The COAD organized the dispatch of reinforcement columns of firefighters from the SDIS of departments spared by the storm and the assembly of civil security military units (UIISC) dispersed across various operational theaters (floods in Venezuela, the Erika shipwreck in Brittany). The army's intervention began quickly with the spontaneous engagement of units, initiated by corps commanders or base commanders, in the form of patrols aimed at ensuring the safety of people and the preliminary clearing of the road network. Within 48 hours, the COIA took over the coordination of army interventions in liaison with the military defense districts. Additionally, local initiatives attempted to compensate for the delayed arrival of rescue efforts in some isolated areas: creation of essential supply hubs at the cantonal level (Doubs, Charente-Maritime), visits to residents without means of contact by postal workers (Creuse), and a generator exchange market (Cantal).

The French public service Météo-France implemented a system of vigilance maps on its website and on television in October 2001 to call for vigilance in the affected departments. This concept has been adopted by many national meteorological services in Europe since then. Following these storms, a specific safety plan was established in French schools starting in 2002. Its objective is to prepare teaching teams, staff, and children in educational facilities for a crisis situation. As early as 2000, EDF, then the manager of the electricity distribution network in France, set up a Rapid Electricity Intervention Force (FIRE) composed of 2,500 volunteer technicians (2,300 initially), divided into 16 autonomous regional teams that can be mobilized at any time to restore electricity distribution to subscribers using heavy logistical means (generators, helicopter resources). By early 2007, although some areas remained untreated, most of the zones with fallen trees had been cleared.

Article_Name: Sécheresse somalienne de 2021 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The 2021 Somali drought is a drought that affected more than 2.3 million people, facing food shortages in Somalia after four consecutive failed rainy seasons. This article is an orphan. Fewer than three articles are linked to it (March 2025). In the affected areas, up to 20% of the population experienced shortages of water, food, and pasture, and then more than 80% of the country suffered from severe drought, which led to the displacement of approximately 100,000 people.
The major cause of this drought is due to climate change with an increase in climate-related risks.

During the Deyr season, most agricultural areas are expected to experience poor harvests, and there is little prospect for cereal production. In the central regions and Puntland, communities rely on boreholes as most shallow wells and berkads have dried up. Water levels in the Shabelle and Juba rivers have become low and are expected to decrease gradually.

About 71% of Somalis live below the poverty line. The number of people requiring assistance is expected to gradually increase in 2022, rising from 5.9 million to about 7.7 million[7]. By December 2021, a situation similar to the 2017 Somali drought is anticipated with much concern[5]. As of November 2021[8];

November 2021, the United Nations resident and humanitarian coordinator for Somalia, Adam Abdelmoula, called for urgent action, as the United Nations warned that the situation could become extreme by April 2022. Also in November 2021, the Somali humanitarian response plan for 2021 was funded at 66%.

Humanitarian aid for Somalia amounted to 14 million dollars, including: the Somali Humanitarian Fund allocated 6 million dollars, and the United Nations Emergency Response Fund allocated 8 million dollars to relief efforts.

Article_Name: Inondations de 2010 au Bénin — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The floods in Benin in 2010 began at the start of October 2010. They caused at least 43 deaths and nearly 100,000 homeless people, 800 cases of cholera, several victims of malaria, and thousands of hectares of land destroyed during these floods that affected the entire country. Furthermore, these 2010 rains caused floods with devastating consequences in the sub-region, with Benin experiencing the most disastrous in its history, affecting 55 out of 77 municipalities. It caused 46 fatalities and affected more than 680,000 people, including around 60,000 children spread across several municipalities in the country.

Whole_Text.header: Evolution of flood risks and meteorology

Whole_Text.content: Large areas of southern Benin are flood-prone. The rainy seasons tend to increase the risk of flooding in urban areas, especially when demographic pressure is combined with poor urban planning. Flooding is exacerbated by the rising waters of the Niger, the Ouémé, and their tributaries. Among the major floods affecting West Africa, Benin is the most affected country. The press reports a recent increase in the phenomenon. Informal and newly developed neighborhoods are more affected and suffer significant damage.

The phenomenon is explained by the combination of natural factors (rainfall, soil porosity, and the city's horizontal topography) and human factors (wild housing, mangrove retreat, lack of purification of pipelines and water currents, plastic waste). There is a lack of site evaluation tools before urbanization and flood management during rainy seasons. 2010 recorded the highest number of victims.
Many isolated homes are saved by canoe[2]. Areas considered non-floodable, such as Kopto and Zangnanado in the center of the country, are flooded.

More than half of the municipalities are affected by floods caused by rainfall twice as high as usual during the rainy season. Victims are sometimes under more than 2 meters of water. 680,000 people are affected, including 200,000 in need of shelter. The UN reports 43 deaths, 358,621 people affected in Benin, and 1.5 million victims in the region (Nigeria, Guinea, Mali, Chad, and Togo). The UNHCR records 680,000 victims in early October. The organization is setting up an air bridge to distribute aid and provide 3,000 tents and mosquito nets. Flooded latrines contaminate bathing and drinking water, causing epidemics. More than 800 cases of cholera are reported, including 51 in Cotonou. The country's poverty in an informal economy exacerbates the issue of access to healthcare. The difficulty in affording paid healthcare leads to risky behaviors, such as self-medication to treat diarrhea and fevers.

OCHA allocates funds to provide water, food, various items, and sanitation. CARE distributes water purification tablets, soap, and insecticide-treated nets for 10,000 people and appeals for funds to assist 100,000 people. IDA finances construction work.

The government is launching infrastructure projects to limit the impact of floods. An ORSEC plan has existed since 1987, but it has never been implemented. However, there is no specific flood prevention plan or broader prevention plan. No gabions are built to mitigate the impact of floods and improve resilience, like in the village of Port-à-Piment in Haiti. The disappearance of mangroves, as in Douala, increases the risks of flood severity and damage related to flooding.

The floods of 1963, the worst previously recorded, caused less damage. The floods caused by the rains of 2010 affected 55 municipalities out of the 77 spread across several municipalities in the country, impacting the municipalities of Dogbo, Lalo, and Lokossa in southern Benin. In 2019, Benin experienced new large-scale floods.

Article_Name: Inondations de 2020 à Douala — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Floods are a recurring phenomenon in Douala, as in some other major cities in Cameroon such as Yaoundé and Maroua.

Rainy seasons tend to increase the risk of flooding in urban areas, especially when population pressure combines with poor urban planning. An analysis of the national press since 1980 reveals a recent increase in the phenomenon in Douala, with the Cameroon Tribune mentioning a maximum of one flood per year until 1999. Occurring mostly between June and September, they have been increasing in scope and intensity since the early 2000s. Informal and recent neighborhoods are more affected. They cause significant damage. Thousands of hectares of the city of Douala are flood-prone. The phenomenon is explained by a combination of natural factors (rainfall, soil porosity, and the city's flat topography) and human factors (informal housing, mangrove deforestation, lack of drainage system maintenance, and waterways filled with plastic waste).

The flooding of August 20 and 21, 2020, is a meteorological event caused by heavy rains and the tide. The National Observatory on Climate Change (ONACC) had warned a few days earlier of a "very high risk of flooding across Cameroon." Many popular and residential neighborhoods are flooded, the Wouri Bridge and the main road to the Douala port are underwater, and the Sandaga-Ancienne customs direction, Bonakouamouang-Akwa party hall, and New Bonabassem-Makèpe road axes are among the many roads cut off from traffic. The governor calls on the population to leave high-risk areas and sets up a Regional Crisis Committee.

The Ministry of Decentralization and Local Development has communicated to 360 town halls and municipalities in the country to proceed with the cleaning of rainwater drainage channels. This natural disaster has caused significant material damage, disrupted traffic, and left many families homeless. No deaths have been officially recorded.
